GENERALLY



§ 31.01  MEETINGS TO BE PUBLIC; EXCEPTIONS.



   All meetings of the city council, of any standing or special committee
of the Council, and of any zoning or other board, committee, or agency of the
city shall be open to the public, except for:



   (A)   Collective bargaining sessions between employees and the city
or its representatives.



   (B)   Meetings or portions of meetings where the acquisition of real
property is being considered.



   (C)   Meetings or portions of meetings where a pending court
proceeding against or on behalf of the city is being considered.



   (D)   Meetings to consider information regarding appointment,
employment, or dismissal of an employee or officer, provided that no final
action thereon may be taken except at a public meeting.



('69 Code, § 2-40)



Statutory reference:



   Meetings of public agencies, ILCS Ch. 5, Act 120, §§ 1 et seq.



§ 31.02  NOTICE.



   (A)   A schedule of all regular Council meetings shall be prepared
at the beginning of each fiscal year, setting forth dates, times, and places
thereof.



   (B)   Notices of any special meeting, rescheduled regular meeting,
reconvened meeting, or adjourned meeting shall be given at least 48 hours
before the meeting by posting a notice of the meeting at the city hall, and
by delivering a copy thereof to any local newspaper of general circulation.



   (C)   Notice of changes in the date, time, or place of any regular
meeting set forth in the schedule prepared at the beginning of each fiscal
year shall be published 10 days prior to the change of the date, time, or
place in a local newspaper of general circulation, and shall be posted at the
city hall.



('69 Code, § 2-41)  (Amend. Ord. O-16-00, passes 5-4-00)



§ 31.03  DAY; HOUR.



   The city council may prescribe, by ordinance, the times and places of
the council meetings and the manner in which special council meetings may be
called.  The mayor or any three aldermen may call special meetings of the
city council.  In addition to any notice required by the city council,
public notice of meetings must be given as prescribed in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 120,
§§ 2.02 and 2.03.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-25)  ('69 Code, § 2-42)



§ 31.04  LOCATION.



   Meetings of the city council shall be held and conducted at the City of
Palos Heights Administrative Center, located at 7607 College Drive, Palos
Heights, Illinois. However, upon written notice posted at the designated
meeting place at least 10 days prior to any meeting, the place of the meeting
may be changed and designated to be held in another assembly room within the
territorial limits of the city.



('69 Code, § 2-43)



§ 31.05  SPECIAL MEETINGS.



   Special meetings of the city council shall be held on the call of the
mayor, or upon the call of any 3 aldermen in writing, filed in the office of
the City Clerk at least 36 hours before the meeting.



('69 Code, § 2-44)



§ 31.06  CHAIRMAN PRO TEM.



   (A)   If the mayor is temporarily absent because of an incapacity to
perform official duties, but the incapacity does not create a vacancy in the
office, the corporate authorities shall elect one of their members to act as
a mayor or President Pro Tem.  The mayor pro tem, during this absence or
disability, shall perform the duties and possess all the rights and powers of
the mayor but shall not be entitled to vote both as mayor and as alderman or
trustee.



   (B)   In the absence of the mayor, acting mayor, or mayor pro tem,
the city council may elect one of their members to act as a temporary
chairman.  The temporary chairman shall have only the powers of a presiding
officer and a right to vote only in the capacity as alderman or trustee on
any ordinance, resolution, or motion.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-35)  ('69 Code, § 2-45)



§ 31.07  CONVENING OF MEETINGS; LACK OF A  QUORUM.



   Each meeting of the Council shall convene at the time appointed for the
meeting.  The Clerk, or someone appointed to fill his place by the presiding
officer, shall thereupon immediately call the roll of the members.  If no
quorum is present, the Council shall not stand adjourned, but the members
present shall be competent to adjourn or recess the council by a majority
vote.



('69 Code, § 2-46)



Cross-reference:



   Quorum, § 31.19



§ 31.08  STANDING COMMITTEES ENUMERATED.



   The following shall be the standing committees of the Council:



   (A)   Finance.



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: Budgeting, appropriation
tax levy, audits, purchases, insurance, personnel, collection and
depositories, administration of city (departments and services), fiscal
oversight of general government programs and all city fiscal operations, and
vehicle purchase and maintenance.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards: All city commissions and
boards through Council committees.



      (3)   Related city department: General government and all city
departments through Council committees.



      (4)   Supervisors providing liaison to committee:  Office
manager, all department supervisors as needed to insure fiscal integrity,
director, vehicle maintenance.



      (5)   Governmental department related to committee.  General
government.



      (6)   Supervisors of department and duties:  The supervisors
shall be the office manager and director of vehicle maintenance. The office
manager shall supervise all employees assigned to general government
including clerical employees, such as typists, bookkeepers, secretaries,
bookkeeping machine operators, and all other employees as may be assigned.



      (7)   Departmental responsibilities:  The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be the city's fiscal operations
(collections, purchases, disbursements, depositories, insurance, general
administration) and the operational maintenance of all city motorized
equipment and vehicles.



   (B)   Municipal grounds and property.



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities:  Develops policies for
utilization and maintenance of all city owned or leased building structures,
parks, and parkways, and the weed control program. Provides the fiscal
oversight of department of grounds and property and vehicle maintenance.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards: Lake Katherine TIF
district committee.



      (3)   Related city department: Department of municipal grounds
and property and water and sewer department (aka department of public works).



      (4)   Supervisor providing liaison to committee:  Municipal
grounds and property.



      (5)   Governmental department related to committee: 
Municipal grounds and property, department of parks and recreation and
swimming pool department.



      (6)   Supervisor of department and his or her duties:  The
supervisor shall be the director of municipal grounds and property. He shall
supervise all city employees assigned to the department of municipal grounds
and property and to the water and sewer department.



      (7)   Departmental responsibilities: The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be the maintenance of all city owned
or leased buildings, structures, parks, and parkways, weed control, and
vehicle maintenance, and establish and maintain a formal system listing all
of the city's general fixed assets.



      (8)   General guidance: Although the department of municipal
grounds and property, with guidance and policies established by this
committee and/or the city council, is responsible for the establishment,
utilization, maintenance and renovation of all city buildings and grounds,
this does not in any way preclude the appropriate department or council
committee from establishing rules of development of programs, use, and
operation of the property; or for purchase and maintenance of equipment
appropriate to the function of the specific property. Regular liaison between
department supervisors and this committee is essential in order to assure
appropriate maintenance problems are promptly addressed.



   (C)   Planning and zoning.



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: The planning and zoning
committee shall be responsible for annexations, subdivisions, variations,
dedications, vacations, plan commission liaison, zoning board of appeals
liaison, zoning commission liaison, and Chicago Area Transportation Study
liaison.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards: Plan commission, zoning
board of appeals, zoning commission.



      (3)   Related city department: Roads and construction.



      (4)   Supervisor providing liaison to committee:  Building
commissioner.



   (D)   Public safety.



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: Safety, civil defense,
police department, traffic control, fire district liaison, police commission
and police pension board liaison, health inspections, and parades. Provides
fiscal oversight of police and health departments programs.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards: Police pension board,
board of police and fire commissioners, and board of health.



      (3)   Related city department: Police.



      (4)   Supervisors providing liaison to committee:  Chief of
police and health inspector.



      (5)   Governmental department related to committee: Police.



      (6)   Supervisors of department and duties:  The supervisors
shall be the chief of police and the health inspector.  The chief of police
shall supervise all city employees assigned to the police department.



      (7)   Departmental responsibilities:  The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be to enforce all orders relative to
the preserving of peace, health, good order, and quiet, and to prosecute all
violations of the ordinances of the city.



   (E)   Recreation (civic activities).



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: Recreation programs,
parks, library board liaison, chamber of commerce liaison, city picnics,
social functions, swimming pool operation including recommendations for
employment of director, swimming pool programs, and providing fiscal
oversight of the swimming pool program.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards: Youth commission and
recreation board.



      (3)   Related city departments: Recreation and parks, building
and grounds, and swimming pool.



      (4)   Supervisor providing liaison to committee:  Director,
parks and recreation.



      (5)   Governmental department related to committee:  Roads
and construction, and swimming pool.



      (6)   Supervisor of department and duties:  The supervisor
shall be the director of parks and recreation.  He shall supervise the
assistant directors, supervisors, and all city employees assigned to the
recreation department, and swimming pool department.



      (7)   Departmental responsibilities:  The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be to develop and maintain all city
parks, to develop and operate all city recreation programs, to operate the
city swimming pool in accordance with city ordinances, state statutes and
guidelines and to provide swimming programs for all participants.



   (F)   Roads and construction.



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: Road maintenance program,
flood control programs, provides fiscal oversight of department of roads and
construction.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards: None.



      (3)   Related city departments: Roads and construction and
building.



      (4)   Supervisors providing liaison to committee: Director of
road and construction.



      (5)   Governmental department related to committee:  Roads
and Construction.



      (6)   Supervisors of department and duties:  The supervisor
shall be the director of roads and construction.  The director of roads and
construction shall supervise all city employees assigned to the department of
roads and construction.



      (7)   Departmental responsibilities:  The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be road development and maintenance,
drainage and flood control.



   (G)   Licenses, permits and franchises.



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: Provides recommendations
to council as needed, permits and inspections for buildings, sites, signs,
business licenses.



      (2)   Related city department: Building.



      (3)   Supervisors providing liaison to committee: The building
commissioner.



      (4)   Supervisor of department and duties: The supervisor
shall be the building commissioner. The building commissioner shall supervise
building inspectors, health inspector, fire inspector, and any city employees
assigned to the building commissioner.



      (5)   Departmental responsibilities: The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be general charge of and supervision
of all private and public construction or alterations of all structures and
buildings within the city, enforcement of all city ordinances, and issuance
of all city permits.



   (H)   Water and sewer (utilities).



      (1)   Legislative responsibilities: Operation and development
of sewer and water system, recommends usage rates and fees, provides fiscal
oversight of water and sewer department.



      (2)   Related commissions or boards.



None.



      (3)   Related city department: Water and sewer.



      (4)   Supervisor providing liaison to committee:  Director,
water and sewer.



      (5)   Governmental department related to committee:  Water
and sewer.



      (6)   Supervisor of department and duties:  The supervisor
shall be the director of water and sewers.  He shall supervise all city
employees assigned to the water and sewer department.



      (7)   Departmental responsibilities:  The responsibilities of
the department and its personnel shall be to operate and maintain in a safe
and efficient manner the city water.



(Res. R-4-69, passed 5-20-69; amend. Ord. O-19-73, passed 4-17-73; amend.
Ord. O-28-81, passed 11-3-81; amend. Ord. O-8-82, passed 4-6-82; amend. Ord.
O-01-83, passed 4-19-83; amend. Ord. O-04-83, passed 4-29-83; amend. Ord.
88-16A, passed 3-16-88; amend. Ord. O-40- 02, passed 12-17-03; amend. Ord.
O-06-16, passed 3-1-16)



§ 31.09  (RESERVED).



§ 31.10  CREATION OF SPECIAL COMMITTEES.



   (A)   Special committees shall be created from time to time as
directed by the Council. 



('69 Code, § 2-49)



   (B)   The following shall be special committees of the Council:



      (1)   Business development.



         (a)   Legislative responsibilities:  Promotes the city,
liaison with business community and provides recommendations to Council as
needed.



         (b)   Related commissions or boards:  All.



         (c)   Related city departments:  All.



         (d)   Supervisor providing liaison to committee:  mayor.



      (2)   Insurance.



         (a)   Legislative responsibilities:  Monitors liability
claims against city or employees and provides recommendations to Council as
needed.



         (b)   Related commissions or boards.  All.



         (c)   Related city departments:  All.



         (d)   Supervisor providing liaison to committee: 
Office manager.



      (3)   (a)   There shall be created a Tax Increment Economic
Development Advisory Committee.  The members of such committee shall be in
such number as the mayor may direct, with the consent of the majority of the
city council and the members of that committee shall be appointed by the
mayor with the consent of the majority of the members of the city council.



         (b)   The members of the Committee shall be appointed
for initial one, two, three, four and five years respectively in such numbers
to provide that the terms of not more than one third of all such members
shall expire in any one year.  Their successors shall be appointed for a
term of five years.



         (c)   The Committee shall serve in advisory capacity
only, as provided by ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-74.4-4 (O).  The Committee
may advise the city council and other municipal officials regarding
development issues and opportunities within any redevelopment project area or
the area within any State Sales Tax Boundary.  The Committee may also
promote and publicize development opportunities in the redevelopment project
areas or the areas within a State Sales Tax Boundary.



(Ord. 0-28-81, passed 11-3-81; amend. Ord. 0-04-83, passed 4-29-83; amend.
Ord. 90-34, passed - -90)



§ 31.11  DEFERRING COMMITTEE REPORTS.



   Upon the request of any 2 aldermen present, any report of a committee
of the council shall be deferred, for final action thereon, to the next
regular meeting of the council after the report is made.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-35)  ('69 Code, § 2-50)



§ 31.12  [RESERVED].



§ 31.13  VOTE REQUIRED; YEAS AND NAYS.



   The passage of all ordinances for whatever purpose, and of any
resolution or motion to create any liability against the city or for the
expenditure or appropriation of city money, shall require the concurrence of
a majority of all members then holding office on the city council, including
the mayor, unless otherwise expressly provided by law.  Where the council
consists of an odd number of aldermen, however, the vote of the majority of
the aldermen shall be sufficient to pass an ordinance.  The passage of an
ordinance, resolution or motion to sell any school property shall require the
concurrence of three-fourths of all aldermen then holding office.  The yeas
and nays shall be taken upon the question of the passage of the designated
ordinances, resolutions, or motions, and recorded in the journal of the city
council.  In addition, the corporate authorities at any meeting may by
unanimous consent take a single vote by yeas and nays on the several
questions of the passage of any two or more of the designated ordinances,
orders, resolutions or motions placed together for voting purposes in a
single group.  The single vote shall be entered separately in the journal
under the designation "omnibus vote", and in that event the clerk may enter
the words "omnibus vote" and in the that event the clerk may enter the words
"omnibus vote" or "consent agenda" in the journal in each case instead of
entering the names of the members of city council voting "yea" and those
voting "nay" on the passage of each of the designated ordinances, orders,
resolutions and motions included in the omnibus group or consent agenda. 
The taking of a single or omnibus vote and the entries of the words "omnibus
vote" or "consent agenda" in the journal shall be a sufficient compliance
with the requirements of the section to all intents and purposes and with
like effect as if the vote in each case had been taken separately by yeas and
nays on the question of the passage of each ordinance, order, resolution and
motion included in the omnibus group and separately recorded in the
journal.  Likewise, the years and nays shall be taken upon the question of
the passage of any other resolution or motion at the request of any alderman,
and shall be recorded in the journal.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-40)  ('69 Code, § 2-52)



§ 31.14  APPROVAL OR VETO OF ORDINANCES; RESOLUTIONS, MOTIONS.



   All resolutions and motions that create any liability against the city,
that provide for the expenditure or appropriation of city money, or that sell
any city or school property, and all ordinances passed by the city council,
shall be deposited with the city clerk.  Except as provided in ILCS Ch. 65,
Act 5, §§ 4-1-1 et seq. and 5-1-1 et seq., if the mayor approves of them,
he shall sign them.  Those of which he disapproves shall be returned to the
city council, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the
city council occurring not less than 5 days after their passage.  The mayor
may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance,
resolution, or motion making an appropriation, and, if so, the remainder
shall be effective.  However, the mayor may disapprove entirely of an
ordinance, resolution, or motion making an appropriation.  If the mayor
fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with his
written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective
despite the absence of his signature.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-45)  ('69 Code, § 2-53)



§ 31.15  RECONSIDERATION AND PASSAGE OVER VETO.



   Every resolution and motion specified in § 31.14, and every ordinance
which is returned to the city council by the mayor, shall be reconsidered by
the city council.  If, after reconsideration, 2/3 of all the aldermen then
holding office on the city council agree to pass an ordinance, resolution, or
motion, notwithstanding the mayor's refusal to approve it, then it shall be
effective.  The vote on the question of passage over the mayor's veto shall
be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the journal.



('69 Code, § 2-54)



Statutory reference:



   Similar provisions, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-50



§ 31.16  ORDINANCES TO BE PUBLISHED.



   All ordinances imposing any fine, penalty, imprisonment, or forfeiture,
or making any appropriation, shall be published as is required by statute.



('69 Code, § 2-55)



§ 31.17  WHEN ORDINANCES TAKE EFFECT.



   No ordinance which must be published to comply with the foregoing
section shall go into effect  until 10 days after it is published, except as
is otherwise provided by law, and all other ordinances shall go into effect
upon the passage thereof, as is provided by statute. 



('69 Code, § 2-56)



§ 31.18  CENSURE OR EXPULSION OF ALDERMEN.



   Any alderman acting or appearing in a lewd or disgraceful manner, or
who uses opprobrious, obscene,  or insulting language to or about any member
of the council, or who does not obey the order of the chair, shall be, on
motion, censured by a majority vote of the members present, or expelled by
2/3 vote of all members elected.



('69 Code, § 2-57)



Statutory reference:



   Expulsion of aldermen, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-10



§ 31.19  QUORUM ESTABLISHED.



   A majority of the council shall constitute a quorum to do business.  A
small number, however, may adjourn from time to time and may compel the
attendance of absentees under penalties (including a fine for a failure to
attend) prescribed by the council by ordinance.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-40-20)  ('69 Code, § 2-58)



§ 31.20  SUPERVISION OF CODE OF ORDINANCES.



   The legislative responsibility for the supervision and revision of
specific sections of the code of ordinances shall be the responsibility of
the respective committee of the city council designated in the chart of
organization which is hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth
herein.



(Ord. 0-28-81, passed 11-3-81)



§ 31.21  GRANTING OF PERMISSION FOR MAINTENANCE OR CONSTRUCTION OF
TEMPORARY STRUCTURES ON CITY-OWNED RIGHTS-OF-WAY.



   The city council may grant to a property owner authority to erect a
fence, shed or other structure on city-owned rights-of-way provided that the
property owner shall have entered into an acceptable lease/license agreement
with the city and further provided that the property owner shall remove such
structures at the direction of the city council if the area is required for
use by the city.



(Ord. O-38-98, passed 8-18-98)



§ 31.22  ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS RULES.



   (A)   Rules statement.  It is the decision of the city council that
any member of the corporate authority may attend any open or closed meeting
of the corporate authority via electronic means (such as by telephone, video
or internet connection) provided that such attendance is in compliance with
these rules and any applicable laws.



   (B)   Prerequisites.  A member of the corporate authority may
attend a meeting electronically if the member meets the following conditions:



      (1)   The member should notify the city clerk at least 72
hours before the meeting, unless impractical, so that necessary
communications equipment can be arranged.  Inability to make the necessary
technical arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote
attendance.



      (2)   The member must assert one of the following three
reasons why he or she is unable to physically attend the meeting.



         (a)   The member cannot attend because of personal
illness or disability; or



         (b)   The member cannot attend because of employment
purposes or the business of the city; or



         (c)   The member cannot attend because of a family or
other emergency.



   (C)   Authorization to participate.



      (1)   The city clerk, after receiving the electronic
attendance request, shall inform the corporate authorities of the request for
electronic attendance.



      (2)   After establishing that there is a quorum physically
present at meeting where a member of the corporate authorities desires to
attend electronically, the presiding officer shall state that (i) a notice
was received by a member of the corporate authorities in accordance with
these rules, and (ii) the member will be deemed authorized to attend the
meeting electronically unless a motion objecting to the members electronic
attendance is made, seconded, and approved by two-thirds of the members of
the corporate authorities physically present at the meeting.  If no such
motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to achieve the
required vote by the members of the corporation authorities physically
present at the meeting, then the request by the member to attend the meeting
electronically shall be deemed approved by the corporate authorities and the
presiding officer shall declare the requesting member present.  After such
declaration by the presiding officer, the question of a members electronic
attendance may not be reconsidered.



   (D)   Adequate equipment required.  The member participating
electronically and other member of the corporate authorities must be able to
communicate effectively, and members of the audience must be able to hear all
communications at the meeting site.  Before allowing electronic attendance
at any meeting, the corporate authorities shall provide equipment adequate to
accomplish this objective at the meeting site.



   (E)   Minutes. Any member attending electronically shall be
considered an off-site attendee and counted as present electronically for
that meeting if the member is allowed to attend.  The meeting minutes shall
also reflect and state specifically whether each member is physically present
or present by electronic means.



   (F)   Rights of remote member.  A member permitted to attend
electronically will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting
and participate in the same capacity as those members physically present,
subject to all general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted
and adhered to.  The member attending electronically shall be heard,
considered, and counted as to any vote taken.  Accordingly, the name of any
member attending electronically shall be called during any vote taken, and
his or her vote counted and recorded by the city clerk and placed in the
minutes for the corresponding meeting.  A member attending electronically
may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any member, provided the
member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and
returning.



(Ord. O-05-08, passed 3-4-08)



RULES OF PROCEDURE



§ 31.30  ORDER OF BUSINESS.



   The order of business for the council shall be as follows:



   (A)   Call to order.



   (B)   Invocation.



   (C)   Pledge of allegiance.



   (D)   Roll call.



   (E)   Presentation of the journal of the proceedings of the last
meeting, or meetings, and correction and approval of the same.



   (F)   Special presentations, if any.



   (G)   Consent calendar.



   (H)   Opening of sealed bids, if any.



   (I)   Reports of city officials.



   (J)   Communications.



   (K)   Citizens wishing to present questions to the council. 
(Discussion on any one subject shall be limited to 10 minutes, unless by a
majority vote of the council it is extended.  Procedure for addressing the
council: rise, be recognized by the mayor, give name and address.)



   (L)   Reports of standing committees.



   (M)   Reports of special committees.



   (N)   Business deferred from previous meeting.



   (O)   New business.



   (P)   Citizens wishing to ask questions re: the evening's business.



   (Q)   Adjournment.



('69Code, §2-69; amend. Ord. O-15-94, passed 3-1-94; amend. Ord. O-06-05,
passed 3-1-05)



§ 31.31  PRESIDING OFFICER TO PRESERVE ORDER, DECIDE QUESTIONS.



   The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum, and shall
decide all points of order, subject to appeal.



('69 Code, § 2-70)



§ 31.32  PRESIDING OFFICER MAY CLEAR CHAMBER.



   In case of any disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding officer
shall have the power  to  require the chamber to be cleared. 



('69 Code, § 2-71)



§ 31.33  LEAVING, WALKING AROUND CHAMBER  WHILE QUESTION BEING PUT.



   While the presiding officer is putting the question, no member shall
walk across or out of the council chamber.



('69 Code, § 2-72)



§ 31.34  RECOGNITION REQUIRED BEFORE  SPEAKING.



   Every member, prior to speaking, or making a motion, shall address
himself to the presiding officer and say: "Mr. Mayor," and shall not proceed
with his remarks until recognized and named by the chair.



('69 Code, § 2-73)



§ 31.35  SCOPE OF DEBATE.



   The speaker shall confine himself to the question under debate,
avoiding personalities, and refraining from impugning the motives of any
other member's argument or veto.



('69 Code, § 2-74)



§ 31.36  PRESIDING OFFICER TO DECIDE WHO SPEAKS.



   When 2 or more members address the presiding officer at the same time,
he shall name the member who is to speak first.



('69 Code, § 2-75)



§ 31.37  VISITORS ADDRESSING COUNCIL.



   No person, other than a member of the council, shall address that body,
except as provided in § 31.30.



('69 Code, § 2-76)



§ 31.38  PRESENTATION OF NEW MATTER.



   When a member wishes to present a communication or petition, he shall
send it to the desk of the clerk, who shall read the  matter when reached in
its proper order.



('69 Code, § 2-77)



§ 31.39  DEBATE REGULATED.



   No member shall speak more than twice on the same question, except by
unanimous consent, and then not until every other member desiring to speak
shall have had an opportunity to do so; provided that the proponent of the
matter under consideration, or the chairman of the committee whose report is
under consideration, as the case may be, shall have the right to open
debate.  No member shall speak longer than 10 minutes at any one time,
except by consent of the council. 



('69 Code, § 2-78)



§ 31.40  DISTRACTING MEMBERS WHILE SPEAKING.



   While a member is speaking, no member shall hold any private 
discussion nor pass between the speaker and the chair.



('69 Code, § 2-79)



§ 31.41  CALLING A MEMBER TO ORDER.



   A member, when called to order by the chair, shall thereupon
discontinue speaking and take his seat, and the order or ruling of the chair
shall be binding and conclusive, subject only to the right of appeal.



('69 Code, § 2-80)



§ 31.42  APPEALS FROM THE CHAIR.



   Any member may appeal to the council from a ruling of the chair, and,
if the appeal is seconded, the member making the appeal may briefly state his
reason for the same, and the chair may briefly explain his ruling; but there
shall be no debate on the appeal, and no other member shall participate in
the discussion.  The chair shall then put the question, "Shall the decision
of the chair be sustained?".  If a majority of the members present vote
"no," the decision of the chair shall be overruled; otherwise it shall be
sustained.



('69 Code, § 2-81)



§ 31.43  QUESTIONS OF PERSONAL PRIVILEGE.



   The right of a member to address the council on a question of personal
privilege shall be limited to cases in which his integrity, character, or
motives are assailed, questioned, or impugned.



('69 Code, § 2-82)



§ 31.44  VOTING REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.



   Every member who shall be present when a question is stated from the
chair shall vote thereon, unless excused by the council, or unless he is
personally interested in the question, in which case he shall not vote.



('69 Code, § 2-83)



§ 31.45  SPECIAL ORDER OF BUSINESS.



   Any matter before the council may be set down as a special order of
business at a time certain, if 2/3 of the aldermen present vote in the
affirmative, but not otherwise.



('69 Code, § 2-84)



§ 31.46  SECONDING OF MOTIONS; WHEN MOTIONS TO BE WRITTEN.



   No motion shall be put or debated in the council unless it is
seconded.  When a motion is seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding
officer before debate, and every motion in the council, except motions of
procedure, shall be reduced to writing, if required by a member, and the
proposer of the motion shall be entitled to the floor.



('69 Code, § 2-85)



§ 31.47  WITHDRAWAL OF MOTIONS.



   After a motion or resolution is stated by the presiding officer, it
shall be deemed to be in possession of the council, but it may be withdrawn
at any time before decision by consent of the council.



('69 Code, § 2-86)



§ 31.48  DIVISION OF QUESTIONS.



   If any question under consideration contains several distinct
propositions, the council, by a majority vote of the members present, may
divide the question.



('69 Code, § 2-87)



§ 31.49  NAME OF MOVANT TO BE ENTERED IN JOURNAL.



   In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered in the journal,
the name of the movant of the same, as well as the member seconding, shall be
entered.



('69 Code, § 2-88)



§ 31.50  TAKING, ENTERING OF VOTES; EXPLANATION OF VOTES NOT PERMITTED.



   When the clerk has commenced to call the roll of the council for the
taking of a vote by "yeas" and "nays," all debate on the question before the
council shall be deemed concluded, and, during the taking  of the vote, no
member shall be permitted to explain his vote, but shall respond to the
calling of his name by the clerk by answering "yea" or "nay," as the case may
be.



('69 Code, § 2-89)



§ 31.51  ANNOUNCEMENT AND CHANGES OF VOTES.



   The result of all votes by "yeas" and "nays" shall not be announced by
the clerk, but shall be handed by him to the chairman for announcement, and
no vote shall be changed after the tally list has passed from the hands of
the clerk.



('69 Code, § 2-90)



§ 31.52  PRECEDENCE OF MOTIONS.



   When a question is under debate, the following motions shall be in
order, and shall have precedence over each other in order, as listed:



   (A)   To fix the time to which to adjourn (not debatable, when
privileged).



   (B)   To adjourn (not debatable).



   (C)   To take a recess (not debatable, when privileged).



   (D)   To lay on the table (not debatable).



   (E)   The previous question (not debatable).



   (F)   To defer or postpone to a specific time (2/3 vote required).



   (G)   To defer or postpone without reference to a specific time
(majority vote).



   (H)   To refer to a committee.



   (I)   To amend an amendment.



   (J)   To amend.



   (K)   To defer or postpone indefinitely. 



('69 Code, § 2-91)



§ 31.53  MOTIONS TO ADJOURN.



   (A)   A motion to adjourn the council shall always be in order
except:



      (1)   When a member is in possession of the floor;



      (2)   While the yeas and nays are being called;



      (3)   When the members are voting;



      (4)   When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and



      (5)   When it has been decided that the previous question
shall be taken.



   (B)   A motion simply to adjourn shall not be subject to amendment
or debate.



('69 Code, § 2-92)



§ 31.54  MOVING THE PREVIOUS QUESTIONS.



   When the previous question is moved on the main question, and seconded,
and on amendments, if pending, it shall be put in this form: "Shall the
question now be voted upon?".  If the motion is carried by 2/3 of the
aldermen present and voting, all further amendments, and all further motions
and debate shall be excluded, and the question put without delay, upon the
pending amendments in proper order, and then upon the main question.



('69 Code, § 2-93)



§ 31.55  MOTIONS TO LAY ON THE TABLE AND TAKE FROM THE TABLE.



   (A)   A motion to lay a question on the table shall not be debatable.



   (B)   A motion to take any motion or other proposition from the
table may be proposed at the same meeting at which the motion or proposition
was laid upon the table, or at the next succeeding meeting; if not taken from
the table by the close of the next session, the motion laid on the table dies.



   (C)   A motion to lay any particular motion or proposition on the
table shall apply to any main motion or proposition, or to an appeal.  When
a motion is laid on the table, all adhering motions go to the table with it.



('69 Code, § 2-94)



§ 31.56  MOTIONS TO POSTPONE OR DEFER.



   (A)   When consideration of a motion or other proposition is
postponed indefinitely, it shall not be again taken up at the same meeting.



   (B)   A motion to postpone indefinitely shall open the main question
to debate.



('69 Code, § 2-95)



§ 31.57  MOTIONS TO REFER TO COMMITTEE.



   A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take precedence over a
similar motion to refer to a special committee.



('69 Code, § 2-96)



§ 31.58  MOTIONS TO AMEND.



   (A)   A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but to amend
an amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained.



   (B)   An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in
order; but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.



   (C)   On an amendment to "strike out and insert," the paragraph to
be amended shall first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be
stricken out, then those to be inserted, and finally the paragraph as it will
stand, if so amended, shall be read.



   (D)   An amendment to the main question or other pending question
may not be referred to a committee without the main question.



('69 Code, § 2-97)



§ 31.59  MOTIONS TO RECONSIDER.



   (A)   A vote or question may be re-considered at any time during the
same meeting, or on the next calendar day, a holiday not being counted as a
day.



   (B)   A motion to reconsider must be made by members who voted on
the prevailing side of the question to be reconsidered, unless otherwise
provided by law; provided that where a motion has received a majority vote in
the affirmative, but is declared lost solely on the ground that a greater
number of affirmative votes is required by statute for the passage or
adoption of the motion, then in that case a motion to reconsider may be made
and seconded only by those who voted in the affirmative on the question to be
reconsidered.



('69 Code, § 2-98)



§ 31.60  FILLING OF BLANKS.



   When a blank is to be filled, and different sums or times proposed, the
question shall be taken first on the greatest sum or the longest time.



('69 Code, § 2-99)



§ 31.61  ROBERT'S RULES ADOPTED.



   The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest published
edition of Robert's Rules of Order  Revised shall govern the council in all
cases to which they are applicable, and in which they are not inconsistent
with this code and the special rules of the council.



('69 Code, § 2-100)



§ 31.62  SUSPENSION, AMENDMENT OF RULES.



   These rules may be temporarily suspended by a vote of 2/3 of all the
aldermen entitled by law to be elected, and shall not be repealed, altered,
or amended, unless by concurrence of majority of all the aldermen entitled by
law to be elected.



('69 Code, § 2-101)

MAYOR




§ 32.01  TERM.



   The chief executive officer of the city shall be a mayor.  The mayor
shall hold office for four years and until a successor is elected and has
qualified.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-15-10)  ('69 Code, § 2-18)



§ 32.02  RIGHT TO INSPECT RECORDS.



   The mayor at all times may examine and inspect the books, records and
papers of any agent, employee or officer of the city.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-20)  ('69 Code, § 2-19)



§ 32.03  (RESERVED.)



§ 32.04  MAYOR TO PRESIDE; RIGHT TO VOTE.



   (A)   The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the city council. 
He shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution, or motion except:



      (1)   Where the vote of the aldermen has resulted in a tie; or



      (2)   Where 1/2 of the aldermen elected have voted in favor of
an ordinance, resolution, or motion, even though there is no tie vote; or



      (3)   Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate
authorities is required by law to adopt an ordinance, resolution, or motion.



   (B)   In the absence of the mayor, meetings of the Council, regular,
special or meetings of the Council as a committee of the whole in public or
executive session shall be presided over by the senior alderman or such other
alderman as the mayor may designate in writing delivered to the City Clerk. 
Such designation by the mayor may be changed at the mayor's discretion.



('69 Code, § 2-21)  (amend. Ord. O-17-93, passed 6-15-93)



§ 32.05  REMOVAL OF OFFICERS.



   Except where otherwise provided by statute, the mayor may remove any
officer appointed by him on any written charge, whenever he is of the opinion
that the interests of the city demand removal, but he shall report the
reasons for the removal to the council at a meeting to be held not less than
5 days, nor more than 10 days, after the removal.  If the mayor fails or
refuses to report to the council the reasons for the removal, or if the
council by a 2/3 vote of all its members authorized by law to be elected,
disapproves of the removal, the officer shall be restored to the office from
which he was removed.  The vote shall be by yeas and nays, which shall be
entered upon the council's journal.  Upon restoration, the officer shall
give a new bond, and take a new oath of office.  No officer shall be removed
a second time for the same offense.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-10)



§ 32.06  DESIGNATION OF DUTIES, POWERS OF OFFICERS.



   Whenever there is a dispute as to the respective duties or powers of
any appointed officer of the city, this dispute shall be settled by the mayor
after consultation with the city attorney; and the mayor shall have the power
to delegate to any appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when
no specific officer has been directed to perform that duty.



('69 Code, § 2-23)



§ 32.07  ELECTION, POWERS OF MAYOR PRO TEM.



   (A)   If the mayor is temporarily absent because of an incapacity to
perform official duties, but the incapacity does not create a vacancy in the
office, the city council shall elect one of their members to act as mayor or
mayor pro tem.  The mayor pro tem, during this absence or disability, shall
perform the duties and possess all the rights and powers of the mayor but
shall not be entitled to vote both as mayor pro tem and as alderman or
trustee.



   (B)   In the absence of the mayor, acting mayor, acting mayor or
mayor pro tem, the city council may elect one of their members to act as
temporary chairman.  The temporary chairman shall have only the powers of a
presiding officer and a right to vote only in the capacity as alderman or
trustee on any ordinance, resolution, or motion.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-35)  ('69 Code, § 2-24)



§ 32.08  REPRESENTATION OF CITY ON FORMAL OCCASIONS.



   The mayor shall act for and on behalf of the city on formal occasions
and receptions; but in his absence or inability to attend any function, the
council may select any other city officer to so act.



('69 Code, § 2-25)



§ 32.09  MAYOR TO REVOKE LICENSES, PERMITS WHEN NOT OTHERWISE PROVIDED.



   Unless otherwise provided, the mayor shall have the power to revoke, on
behalf of the city, any license or permit which may be revoked.



('69 Code, § 2-26)



§ 32.10  MAYOR TO SIGN LICENSES, CONTRACTS AND WARRANTS.




   The Mayor shall sign, on behalf of the city, all licenses, contracts to
which the city is a party, and all warrants; and no such instruments shall be
valid without the mayor's signature, in the absence of a specific ordinance
or statutory provision to the contrary.





(Ord. O-10A-97, passed 5-20-97)




§ 32.11  AUTHORITY TO RELEASE PRISONERS.



   The mayor may release any person imprisoned for violation of an
ordinance and shall report the release, together with the reasons for the
release, to the city council at their first meeting after the release.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-15)  ('69 Code, § 2-28)



§ 32.12  ADDITIONAL POWERS, DUTIES.



   In addition to the above and foregoing, the mayor shall perform all
other duties and have all additional powers that are or may be prescribed by
the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city.



('69 Code, § 2-29)



Statutory reference:



   Mayor to call out militia, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-25



   Mayor to designate person to sign instruments, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §
3.1-35-30




CITY CLERK




§ 32.20  ELECTION.



   The city clerk shall be elected at the same time that the mayor is
elected.  If a vacancy occurs in the office of the city clerk, it shall be
filed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.  The
person so appointed shall hold office for the unexpired term of the officer
elected.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-20-5) ('69 Code, § 2-112)



§ 32.21  SALARY.



   The city clerk shall receive as an annual salary the sum of $7,500,
effective as of 5-1-85.



('69 Code, § 2-113; amend. Ord. O-10-73, passed 3-6-73; amend. Ord. O-22-73,
passed 4-17-73; amend. Ord. O-51-76, passed 12-21-76; amend. Ord. 0-23-80,
passed 11-4-80; amend. Ord. 0-02-85, passed 1-30-85)



§ 32.22  SEALING, ATTESTATION OF DOCUMENTS.



   The city clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the city, and all
licenses, permits, and other documents that require this formality.



('69 Code, § 2-114)



§ 32.23  DUTY TO PAY MONEY OVER TO TREASURER.



   The clerk shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the
city to the city treasurer promptly on receipt of the same; and with the
money, he shall give a statement as to the source thereof.



('69 Code, § 2-115)



§ 32.24  ACCOUNTS.



   The clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him on
behalf of the city, and the source and disposition thereof; and other
accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance.



('69 Code, § 2-116)



§ 32.25  RECORDS.



   In addition to the record of ordinances and other records that the
clerk is required by statute to keep, he shall keep a register of all
licenses and permits issued, and the payments thereon; and other records as
may be required by the council.



('69 Code, § 2-117)



§ 32.26  SEAL; COPIES.



   (A)   The city clerk shall keep the corporate seal, to be provided
by the corporate authorities, and all papers belonging to the city the
custody and control of which are not given to other officers.  The clerk
shall attend all meetings of the corporate authorities including executive
sessions and keep a full record of their proceedings in the journal, except
if the clerk is the subject matter of the meeting and his or her presence
creates a conflict of interest.  The record of those proceedings shall be
made available for public inspection within ten days after being approved or
accepted by the corporate authorities as the official minutes of the
proceedings.



   (B)   The city clerk shall have other duties prescribed by the city
council.



   (C)   Copies of all papers duly filed in the clerk's office and
transcripts from the journals and other records and files of the clerk's
office, certified by the clerk under the corporate seal, shall be evidence in
all courts in like manner as if the originals were produced.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-90)  ('69 Code, § 2-118)



§ 32.27  CUSTODY OF DOCUMENTS, OFFICERS' BONDS.



   The clerk shall be the custodian of all documents, books, records, and
papers belonging to the city, which are not assigned to the custody of some
other officer of the city by law.  The clerk shall be the custodian of all
bonds required to be filed with the city, except his own bond, which shall be
filed with the treasurer.



('69 Code, § 2-119)



§ 32.28  CITY FUNDS.



   The clerk shall exercise general supervision of all officers of the
municipality with regard to the manner of receipt, collection, or
disbursement of city funds, and the collection and return of city funds.



('69 Code, § 2-120)



§ 32.29  PERSONNEL RECORDS.



   The city clerk shall keep full personnel records on all city officers
and employees.



('69 Code, § 2-121)



§ 32.30  INDEXES REQUIRED.



   The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and
records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be
had. 



('69 Code, § 2-122)



§ 32.31  RECORDING OF ORDINANCES.



   The city clerk shall record, in a book used exclusively for that
purpose, all ordinances passed by the council. Immediately following each
ordinance, the clerk shall make a memorandum of the date of the passage and
publication, where required, of the ordinance.  This record and memorandum,
or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of the contents,
passage, and publication of ordinances.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 1-2-5)  ('69 Code, § 2-123)



§ 32.32  CLERK TO KEEP JOURNAL, FURNISH COPIES.



   The clerk shall keep the journal of the proceedings of the council. 
Within not more than 10 days after each meeting of the council, the clerk
shall supply to each member a copy of the proceedings.



('69 Code, § 2-124)



§ 32.33  ADDITIONAL DUTIES.



   In addition to the duties herein provided, the clerk shall perform the
duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 



('69 Code, § 2-125)



CITY TREASURER



§ 32.40  ELECTION, TERM.



   The city treasurer shall be elected and serve a 4-year term, and until
his successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute.



('69 Code, § 2-140)



Statutory reference:



   Election and term of treasurer, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5,  § 3.1-20-5



   Duties of treasurer, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-40



§ 32.41  GENERAL DUTIES.



   The treasurer shall perform the duties as may be prescribed for him by
statute or ordinance.  He shall receive all money paid in to the city,
either directly from the person paying it or from the hands of an officer as
may receive it, and he shall pay out only on warrants, vouchers, or orders
properly signed by the city comptroller or the city clerk, and by the mayor.



('69 Code, § 2-141)



§ 32.42  DEPOSIT OF FUNDS; INTERMINGLING PROHIBITED; APPROVAL OF MAYOR AND
COUNCIL  REQUIRED FOR TRANSFER; WITHDRAWAL OR INVESTMENT OF SUM IN EXCESS OF
$5,000.



   (A)   The treasurer shall deposit the city funds in the depositories
as may be selected from time to time, as is provided by law, and he shall
keep the city money separate and distinct from his own, and shall not
intermingle his own money with it, or make private or personal use of the
city funds.



   (B)   The treasurer shall not transfer or withdraw or invest any sum
without the approval of the mayor and city council. Whenever the treasurer
shall come into possession of sums, he shall, after depositing the same,
report the fact and amount of the deposit, and the name of the depository at
the next regular or special meeting of the city council, and the mayor and
city council shall either approve the deposit or shall direct the treasurer
as to the further disposition of the deposit.



(Ord. O-47-73, passed 11-6-73; amend. Ord. 0-6-81, passed 3-17-81)



§ 32.43  RECORDS REQUIRED.



   The treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him, the
source from which it was received, and the purpose for which it was paid out;
and he shall keep a record showing at all times the financial status of the
city.  The treasurer shall keep additional books and accounts as may be
required by the city council, and shall keep them in the manner required by
the council.



('69 Code, § 2-143)



§ 32.44  RECORDS OF BONDS, ORDERS, VOUCHERS.



   The treasurer shall keep a register of all bonds or orders filed with
him or paid by him, and of all vouchers.



('69 Code, § 2-144)



§ 32.45  BOOKS OF APPROPRIATIONS, EXPENDITURES, RECEIPTS REQUIRED;
AVAILABILITY FOR INSPECTION.



   The city treasurer shall open and keep, in a neat and methodical
manner, a complete set of books, in which, among other things, shall be set
forth the appropriations of the fiscal year, each distinct object and branch
of expenditure, and also the receipts from each and every source of revenue,
so far as he can ascertain the same.  The books, and all other papers kept
in his office, shall be subject to the examination of the mayor, the city
council, or any committee thereof.



('69 Code, § 2-145)



§ 32.46  ACCOUNTS OF FUNDS, DEBTS.



   The city treasurer shall keep a detailed account of the city revenue
and of each separate fund, crediting the same with all receipts or
appropriations and charging it with all warrants drawn thereon, and he shall
charge each warrant to the fund or appropriation against which it is drawn,
to the extent authorized by an appropriation ordinance.  He shall also keep
an accurate account of all debts due from or owing to the city, and shall
keep a book in which he shall enter a correct list of all bonds, notes, or
other obligations given by or payable to the city, with the date thereof, the
person to whom or by whom payable, the rate of interest, the time and manner
in which the principal and interest are payable, and all other particulars as
may be necessary to the full understanding thereof.



('69 Code, § 2-146)



§ 32.47  MONTHLY STATEMENTS REQUIRED; RECORDS OF WARRANTS.



   At the end of every month, and oftener if required by the council, the
city treasurer shall render an account under oath to the council or to the
officer as may be designated by ordinance, showing the state of the treasury
at the date of the account, and the balance of money in the treasury.  He
shall accompany the account with a statement of all money received into the
treasury, and on what account, together with all warrants redeemed and paid
by him.  On the day he renders an account, these warrants, with all vouchers
held by him, shall be delivered to the city clerk and filed, together with
the account, in the clerk's office.  He shall return all warrants paid by
him marked "paid."  The treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants,
which shall describe each warrant, showing its date, amount, and number, the
fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom paid, and when paid.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-45) ('69 Code, § 2-147)



§ 32.48  ANNUAL REPORTS.



   (A)   Within six months after the end of each fiscal year, the
treasurer shall prepare and file with the city clerk an account of moneys
received and expenditures incurred during the preceding fiscal year as
specified in this section.  The treasurer shall show in the account:



      (1)   All moneys received by the city, indicating the total
amounts, in the aggregate, received in each account of the city, with a
general statement concerning the source of the receipts.  In this division
(A), the term "account" does not mean each individual taxpayer, householder,
licensee, utility user, or other persons whose payments to the city are
credited to a general account; and



      (2)   Except as provided in division (A)(3) below, all moneys
paid out by the city where the total amount paid during the fiscal year
exceeds $2,500 in the aggregate, giving the name of each person to whom
moneys were paid and the total paid to each person; and



      (3)   All moneys paid out by the city as compensation for
personal services, giving the name of each person to whom moneys were paid
and the total amount paid to each person from each account except that the
treasurer may elect to report the compensation for personal services of all
personnel by name, listing each employee in one of the following categories:



         (a)   Under $25,000.00;



         (b)   $25,000.00 to $49,999.99;



         (c)   $50,000.00 to $74,999.99;



         (d)   $75,000.00 to $99,999.99;



         (e)   $100,000.00 to $124,999.99; or



         (f)   $125,000 and over.



      (4)   A summary statement of operations for all funds and
account groups of the city, as excerpted from the annual financial report as
filed with the appropriate state agency.



   (B)   Upon receipt of the account from the treasurer, the clerk
shall publish the account at least once, in one or more newspapers published
in the city, or, if no newspaper is published therein, then in one or more
newspapers having a general circulation within the city.



(ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-65)  ('69 Code, § 2-148)



§ 32.49  PURCHASE; SALE OF SECURITIES.



   (A)   The treasurer is authorized from time to time, when the
treasury contains funds set aside for use for particular purposes, but which
are not immediately necessary for such purposes, to apply the funds to the
purchase of interest-bearing treasury bills of the United States.



   (B)   Upon the sale of the treasury bills, the money redeemed shall
be credited to and placed in the fund used to purchase the bills.



('69 Code, § 2-149)



DEPUTY CLERK



§ 32.60  DEPUTY CLERK.



   There is created the position of deputy city clerk. The deputy clerk
shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council.



(Ord. O-2-02, passed 2-5-02)



§ 32.61  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The deputy clerk, in the absence or unavailability of the city clerk
shall exercise all powers and duties granted to the city clerk as set forth
in §§ 32.22 through 32.33 of the city code.



(Ord. O-2-02, passed 2-5-02)



§ 32.62  EXECUTION OF DOCUMENTS.



   A deputy clerk may execute all documents required by law to be executed
by the city clerk and may affix the seal of the clerk wherever required. In
signing any document, a deputy clerk shall sign the name of the clerk
followed with the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the words
"deputy clerk."



(Ord. O-2-02, passed 2-5-02)

CITY COLLECTOR



§ 33.10  OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTED.



   There is created the office of city collector, an executive office of
the city. The city collector shall be appointed by the mayor with the
approval of the city council.



('69 Code, § 2-160)



Statutory reference:



   Duties, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-35-120



§ 33.11  POWERS, DUTIES.



   (A)   The city collector is empowered and authorized to collect all
sums and moneys due the city.



   (B)   The city collector shall perform all duties provided by law,
and shall preserve all warrants returned to him, and shall maintain books and
accounts reflecting receipts and disbursements.



   (C)   All warrants, books, vouchers, and accounts, and all papers
pertaining to his office may be examined at any time by the mayor, city
clerk, or any member or committee of the city council.



   (D)   The city collector shall pay over weekly to the city treasurer
all moneys collected by him from any source whatever, taking the city
treasurer's receipt therefor, in duplicate, and filing one copy thereof with
the city clerk.



('69 Code, § 2-162)



§ 33.12  REPORT; ANNUAL STATEMENT.



   (A)   Between April 1 and April 10 of each year, the city collector
shall file with the city clerk a statement of:



      (1)   All the money collected by him during the year.



      (2)   The particular warrant, special assessment, or account
on which collected.



      (3)   The balance of money uncollected on all warrants in his
possession.



      (4)   The balance remaining uncollected at the time of the
return on all warrants which he returned  to the city clerk during the
preceding fiscal year.



   (B)   The city clerk shall publish the statement at least once,
within 10 days, in one or more newspapers published in the municipality.



('69 Code, § 2-163)



§ 33.13  SALARY.



   The city collector shall receive as his salary for his services the sum
of $3,600 per annum.



('69 Code, § 2-164; amend. Ord.O-29-71, passed 4-20-71; amend. Ord. O-55-71,
passed 12-21-71; amend. Ord. O-11-73, passed 3-6-73)



DIRECTOR OF BUILDING AND GROUNDS



§ 33.20  CREATION.



   For provisions concerning the director of building and grounds see §
38.12.



DIRECTOR OF ROADS AND CONSTRUCTION



§ 33.30  CREATION.



   For provisions concerning the director of roads and construction see §
38.42.



BUILDING COMMISSIONER



§ 33.40  CREATION OF OFFICE OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER; APPOINTMENT; REMOVAL.



   The office of building commissioner is created, and the executive
official in charge shall be known as the building commissioner. The building
commissioner shall be appointed as required by law.  His appointment shall
continue during good behavior and satisfactory service.  He shall not be
removed from office except for cause, after full opportunity has been given
him to be heard on specific charges.  Whenever the office of building
commissioner is or becomes vacant, or in the event that the occupant of that
office is absent or unavailable, all building, occupancy, or other similar
permits shall be issued by the chairman of the license and permits committee
of the city council.



(Ord. O-25-70, passed 9-15-70; amend. Ord. O-14-72, passed 2-29-72)



Statutory reference:



   Building commissions, ILCS Ch. 50, Act 15, § 1 et seq.



§ 33.41  DUTIES OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER.



   The duties of the building commissioner shall be:



   (A)   To have general charge and supervision of the erection,
construction, alteration, repair, removal, use, and inspection of all
buildings, structures, or portions thereof and accessories thereto within the
city, and to enforce all ordinances relating thereto.



   (B)   The building commissioner shall examine all plans for building
and zoning permit purposes.  He shall have charge of building inspections on
all buildings, structures, or portions thereof in connection with work that
has been authorized by a permit.



   (C)   The building commissioner shall perform further duties as the
building and zoning ordinances require.



(Ord. O-25-70, passed 9-15-70)



Cross-reference:



   Supervision of department of roads and construction, see § 38.42



§ 33.42  COMPENSATION OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER.



   Compensation of the building commissioner shall be determined by the
corporate authorities.



(Ord. O-25-70, passed 9-15-70)



§ 33.43  DEPUTY BUILDING COMMISSIONERS.



   The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may appoint
one or more deputy building commissioners and inspectors. They shall hold
office for such periods as may be designated in their appointment.  They
shall receive compensation as may be established by the municipal
authorities. They shall assist the building commissioner in the performance
of his duties.



(Ord. O-25-70, passed 9-15-70)



HEALTH OFFICER



§ 33.50  OFFICE CREATED.



   The office of city health officer is created.



('69 Code, § 15-32)



§ 33.51  ASSISTANT HEALTH OFFICERS.



   Assistant health officers may be appointed from time to time.



('69 Code, § 15-33)



§ 33.52  INSPECTIONS; COMPENSATION.



   The health officer and any assistant health officers shall inspect each
business subject to inspection on one occasion during the first six months of
each calendar year and shall make a second inspection during the last six
months of every calendar year.  They shall make such reinspections as are
necessary in order to respond to a complaint.  The health officer and any
assistant health officers shall be compensated at the rate of $40 for each of
the two semiannual inspections to be conducted annually and an additional $10
for each reinspection by the health officer.  The compensation shall not
exceed $80 for inspections for any business and a maximum of $20 for the
aggregate of reinspections or a total not to exceed $100 of compensation for
each business inspected.



('69 Code, § 15-34; amend. Ord. O-4-94, passed 2-1-94)



§ 33.53  DUTIES.



   It shall be the duty of the health officer:



   (A)   To enforce and observe all rules, regulations, and orders of
the Illinois Department of Public Health, and all state laws pertaining to
the preservation of the health of the people within the city.



   (B)   To execute and enforce all ordinances of the city relating to
nuisances, public health, and sanitation.



   (C)   To investigate the existence of any contagious or infectious
disease within the city, and to report the same promptly to the city council
and to the department of health of the state, and to act without delay in
carrying out measures for arresting the progress of the same as either or
both of said bodies shall adopt.



   (D)   To make all necessary sanitation and health investigations and
inspections within the city.



('69 Code, § 15-35)



§ 33.54  DECLARED CONSERVATOR OF PEACE.



   The health officer and his assistants shall have the powers of a police
officer, and conservator of the peace.



('69 Code, § 15-36)



Cross-reference:



   Police, Ch. 35



§ 33.55  ASSISTANCE OF POLICE.



   City policemen shall assist the health officer or his assistants in the
performance of the duties of his office when called upon by the health
officer, or by the mayor, or any member of the city council.



('69 Code, § 15-37)



DIRECTOR OF MOTOR VEHICLE MAINTENANCE



§ 33.60  DUTIES.



   The director of motor vehicle maintenance shall have such duties as may
be prescribed from time to time by the mayor, with the consent of the city
council, or by ordinance adopted by the city council.



(Ord. 44-86, passed 11-18-86)



§ 33.61  APPOINTMENT AND REPORTAGE.



   He shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the
city council. The director of motor vehicle maintenance shall report solely
to the municipal grounds and property committee of the city council and to no
other committee.



(Ord. 44-86, passed 11-18-86)



CITY ADMINISTRATOR



§ 33.70  OFFICE CREATED.



   The office of city administrator is hereby created subject to the
provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.71  QUALIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The city administrator shall be chosen by the mayor and
aldermen on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with
special preference to specific professional education for, actual experience
in, and knowledge of accepted practice in the administration of local
government and to the duties of the office as specified below. The
appointment shall be made without consideration of the candidates' race, sex,
politics, or religious beliefs. Neither the mayor nor any member of the city
council shall receive appointment during their terms of office or within two
years after the expiration of that term.



   (B)   The administrator must posses a bachelor's degree in public
administration or related field; plus four years of progressive municipal
management or administrative experience, with at least two years in an
administrative/supervisory capacity.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01; amend. Ord. O-14-01, passed 3-6-01)



§ 33.72  APPOINTMENT AND TERM.



   The city administrator shall be appointed by the mayor to a term of
office as provided for by law, and with the approval of the city council by a
majority vote. The administrator shall, in all cases, be subject to the
authority and direction of the mayor and the official actions of the city
council.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.73  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The city administrator shall receive such compensation for the
performance of his/her duties as set by the corporate authorities with
adjustments from time to time as the corporate authorities deem appropriate.
The adjustments to salary shall be at a rate of no less than the average
percentage Increases afforded all city department heads for the year.



   (B)   The city and the administrator shall enter into an employment
agreement which shall detail compensation, fringe benefits, and other
appropriate agreements describing the working relationship between the city
administrator and the corporate authorities.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.74  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.



   The city administrator shall be subject at all times to removal from
office by the mayor.  However, an appeal of the decision by the mayor, and
to so override that decision, can be accomplished by a vote of two-thirds of
the city council, except as otherwise provided by city ordinance, Illinois
statute, or other law.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.75  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The city administrator shall be responsible to the mayor and city
council for the proper administration of the city. In discharging this
responsibility, the city administrator as administrative head of all
departments shall:



   (A)   Direct, supervise, and coordinate the administration of all
departments, offices, and agencies of the city, except as otherwise provided
by law;



   (B)   Attend all city council meetings. The city administrator shall
have the right to take part in all discussions, but shall not vote;



   (C)   Serve as the city budget officer and prepare and submit to the
city council by the date  set by the council, a recommended annual budget
for city operations and a recommended capital  program. When the annual
budget or capital  program have been approved by the city council, the city
administrator shall be responsible for the administration of the budget and
capital program;



   (D)   Direct, supervise, and oversee the city's application for, and
administration of all federal, state, county, and other monetary grants;



   (E)   Be responsible for all contract negotiations for the city;



   (F)   Submit to the city council and make available to the public a
complete report on the administrative activities of the city within 90 days
of the end of each fiscal year;



   (G)   Make such other reports as the city council may require
concerning the operations of city departments, offices, and agencies;



   (H)   Keep the city council fully advised as to the present
financial condition and future needs of the city;



   (I)    (1)   Be responsible for procurement of commodities and
services for all city departments, offices, and agencies, and promulgate
purchasing rules which shall be followed by employees in the procurement of
goods and services:



      (2)    As a duly appointed purchasing agent for the city, the
administrator is authorized to make purchases as provided for in the annual
budget in an amount not to exceed $5,000;



   (J)   Propose to the finance committee of the city council such
personnel rules and regulations, as the administrator deems necessary to
manage the personnel policies of the city;



   (K)   Advise the city council on pending decisions of public policy
and recommend to the council the adoption of such measures as the
administrator may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety, or
welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services;



   (L)   Be responsible for the conduct of all collective bargaining
processes of the city, in conjunction with any other officers appointed by
the mayor and/or city council, and recommend to the city council collective
bargaining agreements for approval by the council, and shall be responsible
for administering all contracts reached throughout the collective bargaining
process;



   (M)   Provide staff support services for the mayor and members of
the city council;



   (N)   Serve as the public information officer for the city;



   (O)   Be responsible for, and oversee information technology
including, but not limited to, computer systems, cable television, and
telecommunications; and



   (P)   Perform such other duties as may be specified by law or
assigned by the mayor and/or city council.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.76  BOND.



   The city administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the amount of
$10,000 to be approved by the city council.  The bond shall be conditioned
on the faithful performance of the duties of the office.  The city shall pay
the premium for the bond.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.77  ACTING ADMINISTRATOR.



   If, because of a temporary absence, disability, or illness, the city
administrator is unable to carry out the function of this office, the mayor,
with the approval of the city council may appoint a member of the city's
administrative staff to serve as acting administrator and carry out the
duties of the administrator during the administrator's absence.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)



§ 33.78  AUTHORITY OF OTHER OFFICERS.



   Nothing in Ord. O-1-01 shall be deemed to diminish or detract from the
statutory powers and authority of the city's elected officials.



(Ord. O-1-01, passed 1-2-01)
