BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS



§ 34.01  CREATION.



   The board of local improvements in and for the city is created.  The
board shall consist of the mayor and all of the aldermen elected to the city
council.  The board shall do and perform the duties and functions incumbent
upon the board of local improvements as provided in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 9,
as from time to time amended.



('69 Code, § 2-5; amend. Ord. 89-34, passed 7-18-89)



PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION



§ 34.10  CREATED; NAMED.



   A planning and zoning commission is created for the city, which shall
be known as "The Palos Heights Planning and Zoning Commission."



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.11  MEMBERSHIP.



   The planning and zoning commission shall consist of seven members in
addition to the mayor and one alderman, who will be nonvoting members.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.12  APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS.



   The members of the planning and zoning commission shall be appointed by
the mayor by and with the consent of the council.  In making appointments,
consideration shall be given to members of school boards, zoning board of
appeals, and other existing agencies.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.13  TERM OF OFFICE.



   Members shall be appointed for a period of five years.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.14  RESIGNATION; VACANCY.



   Any member of the planning and zoning commission may resign from his
office. If a vacancy in office occurs by reason of death, resignation, or
removal from office for cause, the vacancy shall be filled by appointment by
the mayor by and with the consent of the council.  The appointee shall serve
for the remainder of the term of office which has become vacant.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.15  COMPENSATION; EXPENDITURES.



   Members of the planning and zoning commission shall serve without
compensation. No expenditures may be made or contracted for by the commission
except upon approval of the city council, or some designated officer.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.16  MEETINGS; PLACE, TIME.



   Meetings of the planning and zoning commission shall be held at the
city administrative building. Meetings shall be held every month.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.17  AREA COVERED BY PLAN.



   The area to be covered by the planning and zoning commission's
functions shall include all area within the corporate limits of the city and
contiguous unincorporated territory, no more than one and a half miles beyond
the corporate limits, and not included in any municipality.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.18  POWERS, DUTIES GENERALLY.



   It is the duty and within the power of the planning and zoning
commission:



   (A)   To study, with the aid of maps of the city and contiguous
unincorporated areas, the following: past growth and changes in land and
building uses, present conditions and zoning, and trends of development which
are especially pertinent to the commission's work; and to estimate the
probably amount, character, and location of future growth.



   (B)   To determine and describe the kind of character of community
that is desired by the citizens of the city that is feasible to achieve in
major part, setting forth or outlining the policies and objectives with
respect to public improvements and regulations which will bring about and
maintain such a community.



   (C)   To prepare and recommend as part of a comprehensive plan:



      (1)   A program of public improvements designed to meet the
present and future needs of the city, including a schedule showing the
approximate year or period when each improvement should be made, a rough
estimate of the cost and methods of financing.



      (2)   Additional and revised regulations governing the
development of private property, including subdivision development, zoning,
building, redevelopment, and maintenance.



      (3)   The above programs and regulations shall be described to
further the policies and objectives desired by the city. Proposals therein
shall be those for which authority and means of financing exist, or could be
obtained. The plan may be prepared and adopted in whole or separate
geographical or functional parts.



   (D)   To consider and report on current or special matters relating
to regulations and development within the city and contiguous unincorporated
territory, as may arise during the preparation of the comprehensive plan, or
which may be referred to the commission by the mayor, city council, or other
corporate authorities.



   (E)   To exercise all other powers germane to the powers granted by
§§ 34.10 through 34.19 as may exist under state statute, or as may be
conferred by the city council.



   (F)   To perform all duties and responsibilities as authorized and
directed under §§ 153.120 through 153.130 as it pertains to planned
residential developments; §§ 153.240 through 153.247 as it pertains to
planned unit developments; and §§ 153.210 through 153.213 as it pertains to
zoning amendments.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



§ 34.19  OFFICIAL PLAN.



   The comprehensive plan or any part thereof when adopted by the city
council shall be designated and known as the official plan or part thereof of
the city.  From time to time thereafter, the planning and zoning commission
may prepare and recommend to the city council, and other corporate
authorities, changes in the official plan, or any of its parts, or plans for
specific improvements in pursuance of the official plan.  The commission may
further the making of improvements, give aid to city officials charged with
their direction, and generally may promote the realization of the official
plan.



(Ord. O-36-15, passed 10-6-15)



BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS



§ 34.30  CREATED.



   There is created a board of fire and police commissioners for the city.



('69 Code, § 2-245)



Statutory reference:



   Board of fire and police commissioners, ILCS Ch.



     65, Act 5, § 10-2.1-1



Cross-reference:



   Police department, Ch. 35



§ 34.31  COMPOSITION; TERM.



   The board of fire and police commissioners shall consist of 3 members,
whose terms of office shall be for 3 years each. Members shall serve until
the respective successors have been appointed and qualified.



('69 Code, § 2-246)



§ 34.32  APPOINTMENT.



   The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be
appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the city council, provided that
no appointment shall be made within 30 days prior to expiration of the
mayor's term of office.



('69 Code, § 2-247)



§ 34.33  CONSIDERED MUNICIPAL OFFICERS; OATH; BOND.



   The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be
considered officers of the city, and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond
in an amount as may be required by the corporate authorities of the city.



('69 Code, § 2-248)



§ 34.34  DUTIES, POWERS.



   The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers
and members of the fire and police departments of the city, if any, with the
exception of the chief of the fire department and the chief of police, and
shall have the powers and duties as are prescribed by law.



('69 Code, § 2-249)



§ 34.35  REMOVAL.



   A member of the board of fire and police commissioners shall not be
subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an
opportunity to be heard within 30 days in his own defense, before a regular
meeting of the city council.  A majority vote of the elected members of the
city council shall be required to remove any member or members from office.



('69 Code, § 2-250)



YOUTH COMMISSION



§ 34.40  CREATION AND APPOINTMENT.



   There is created a youth commission for the city.  The youth
commission shall consist of five members (three adults and two teens, defined
as 13 to 19 years old) to serve out a complete term, and to be appointed by
the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.  One adult
chairman shall be appointed for a two-year term, two adults shall be
appointed for three-year terms, and two teens shall be appointed for one-year
terms.  In the appointment of the members, the mayor and city council shall
give consideration to the broad representation of all groups and individuals,
lay and professional, from within the social and religious structure of the
community.



(Ord. O-11-77, passed 2-1-77)



§ 34.41  POWERS OF THE COMMISSION.



   The city youth commission shall have the following powers and duties:



   (A)   To encourage youth of the city by publicizing and otherwise
focusing attention upon accomplishments of youth groups and individuals
within the city;



   (B)   To engage in such fact- finding and studies as may be
necessary to provide information about the nature and extent of the city's
youth needs, and to suggest programs necessary or desirable to promote the
interest and well-being of the youth of the city;



   (C)   To cooperate with all public and private youth organizations
within the community; to work with all agencies and organizations, both
public and private, in the community, which serve youth; to promote
interagency cooperation and communication; and to promote full utilization of
the existing community facilities for the benefit of the youth of the city;



   (D)   To give consideration to unmet needs of youth, and to
recommend programs to the city council for meeting those needs;



   (E)   To conduct public education and information programs to inform
the community of youth accomplishments and needs;



   (F)   To submit a semiannual report to the mayor and the city
council on all activities of the youth commission, together with
recommendations as the commission shall wish to transmit;



   (G)   To accept and expend contributions and gifts for programs and
purposes of the commission with city council approval;



   (H)   To make recommendations to the mayor and to the standing
committees for approval by the city council.



(Ord. O-11-77, passed 2-1-77)



PARKS AND RECREATION



§ 34.50  PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD; CREATION, APPOINTMENT, TERMS.



   There is created a parks and recreation advisory board for the city,
which board shall be comprised of seven members, each whom shall be a
resident of the city.  The members of the board shall be appointed by the
mayor of the city, appointment of whom shall be confirmed by the majority of
the council. All members of the board shall serve without compensation and
shall not hold any other municipal office, except that members of the parks
and recreation advisory board may serve on other temporary committees, task
forces, or similar ad hoc groups. Members shall have staggered terms of five
years.



(Ord. O-41-15, passed 11-3-15)



§ 34.51  AUTHORITY TO ADOPT REGULATIONS.



   The parks and recreation advisory board shall have the authority to
adopt rules of procedure governing its proceedings, and will conduct all of
its proceedings in accordance with such rules.



(Ord. O-41-15, passed 11-3-15)



§ 34.52  MEETINGS.



   (A)   The parks and recreation advisory board shall meet at least
once each calendar month in regular meetings at a time and place it shall by
order designate. It may also hold special meetings from time to time as it
deems necessary; special meetings shall be at the call of the chairman of the
board, or on request of three members. A complete record shall be kept at the
city offices of all proceedings of the board, which record shall be available
for public examination at all times.



   (B)   In the event there is no business pending before the board,
the regular monthly meeting may be cancelled.



(Ord. O-41-15, passed 11-3-15)



§ 34.53  OFFICERS.



   The board shall choose one of its members to act as chairman and one
member to serve as vice chairman.  The chairman shall preside at all
meetings of the board, except in his absence the vice chairman shall preside.



(Ord. O-41-15, passed 11-3-15)



§ 34.54  DUTIES OF THE BOARD.



   The primary purpose of the parks and recreation advisory board shall be
to serve in an advisory capacity to the mayor and city council, with
reference in the planning and development of parks and recreation programs
that promote and stimulate public interest therein, and solicit to the
fullest extent possible the cooperation of school authorities and public and
private agencies.



(Ord. O-41-15, passed 11-3-15)



§ 34.55  DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION; ASSISTANT.



   (A)   There is created the office of director of parks and
recreation.



   (B)   The director of parks and recreation shall:



      (1)   Supervise the work of the park and recreation board in
accordance with the general policies established by the board. Survey the
community for needs and wants, and organize and direct an efficient
administration for the board.  Establish, review, and coordinate procedures
so that maximum service may be provided at reasonable cost.



      (2)   Develop and organize a broad diversified program of
recreation activities under active leadership and other programs which
primarily require provision of space facilities and general administrative
service.  Supervise the safety and quality of programs.



      (3)   Recruit, select, and employ or recommend the employment
of personnel. Organize, assign, and train personnel, and develop and maintain
good work relationships among staff members.  Establish and develop a
program for continuing use of volunteers in the recreation program.



      (4)   Direct the acquisition, planning, design, and
construction of recreation and park facilities under the control of the
board.  Operate and maintain all areas and facilities under board control
for optimum use in support of the community recreation program.  Establish
close working relationships with and serve ex officio as a consultant on
recreation and park matters to public and voluntary community agencies
concerned with city planning, housing, public welfare, education, and other
subjects closely related to community recreation.



      (5)   Study and analyze the effectiveness of the board's
services.  Prepare and recommend adoption of long-range and immediate plans
to meet community needs.



      (6)   Direct and account for the expenditure of board funds in
accordance with budget appropriations.  Prepare and justify budget estimates
and work programs. Supervise the keeping of complete financial records for
the board.  Recommend establishment of necessary fees for various services,
and supervise their use.



      (7)   Interpret to the public the community recreation program
and its philosophy and objectives through all suitable means, including the
use of volunteers and staff members as well as the news media.  Promote the
public use of recreation facilities.  Establish and maintain cooperative
planning and working relationships with other local community agencies as
well as state, regional, and national agencies concerned with recreation and
related fields.  Organize, promote, and cooperate with neighborhood groups
identified with recreation and parks.



      (8)   Maintain systematic, complete, and accurate records of
board activities and services, personnel, and property.  Prepare and issue
regular and special reports for use by the board, the community, officials,
and others, and for the information of the community.  Attend regular and
special board meetings.



   (C)   The employment of a director of parks and recreation shall be
subject to approval by the mayor and city council, and his services may be
terminated upon action by the mayor, subject to the approval of the city
council, and his salary and term of employment shall be as determined by the
mayor and city council.  (Ord. O-31-72, passed 5-16-72)



   (D)   There is created the office of assistant director of parks and
recreation. The assistant director shall have such duties as may be
prescribed from time to time by the mayor and city council.



§ 34.56  RULES, REGULATIONS, CHARGES, AND FEES FOR MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOL;
PENALTY FOR VIOLATION.



   (A)   The operation of the swimming pool shall be in accordance with
the rules and regulations set forth in exhibit A is on file with the
city clerk and incorporated in this section as if fully set forth herein.



   (B)   Charges and fees for the use of the swimming pool shall be in
accordance with exhibit B on file with the city clerk, and incorporated
in this section as if fully set forth herein.



   (C)   Any person who violates any rule or regulation incorporated
herein or hereinafter adopted shall be subject to a penalty of a fine of not
less than $5 nor more than $200.



(Ord. O-36-72, passed 6-6-72; amend. Ord. O-7-84, passed 5-1-84; amend. Ord.
O-17-85, passed 5-21-85; amend. Ord. O-4-99, passed 1-19-99)



§ 34.57  VEHICLES PROHIBITED IN PARK AND RECREATION AREA; VEHICLES DEFINED;
PENALTY FOR VIOLATION.



   (A)   As used in this section, VEHICLE means any vehicle propelled
other than by human power, and shall include, but not be limited to, motor-
driven vehicles, motorcycles, snowmobiles, and horse-drawn vehicles.



   (B)   No vehicle shall be operated in or upon any city park or
recreation area, other than a designated parking area, except for those
vehicles for which written permission to so operate has been issued by the
city clerk at the direction of the city council, or a vehicle which is
exempted from the operation of this section.



   (C)   The prohibition of this section shall not apply to vehicles
operated by public utility companies while installing, repairing,
maintaining, or inspecting public utility facilities, or to vehicles operated
by employees of the city, park, and recreation board, or the city youth
baseball league, while maintaining the premises or cutting grass or weeds
thereon.



   (D)   Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall
be fined not less than $10 nor more than $200 for each offense.



(Ord. O-15-75, passed 2-4-75)



§ 34.58  CLOSING TIME OF PARKS.



   (A)   All city parks, the buildings at the parks, and the parking
lots serving the parks, except the Lake Katherine Nature Preserve, shall be
closed between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. unless a permit for the
use thereof is issued by the city council.



   (B)   The Lake Katherine Natural Preserve, the buildings at  Lake
Katherine, and the parking lot serving Lake Katherine shall be closed each
day from dusk to dawn, unless a permit for the use thereof is issued by the
city council.



   (C)   It is unlawful for any person or vehicle to remain on the Lake
Katherine Nature Center and Botanic Gardens property, or any city park, after
they are closed, except as authorized by permit.



   (D)   Persons who violate the provisions of this section shall be
fined not less than $25 and not more than $500 for each such offense.



(Ord. O-35-77, passed 10-18-77; amend. Ord. O-29-98, passed 7-7-98; amend.
Ord. O-37-02, passed 12-3-02; amend. Ord. O-18- 03, passed 3-4-03; amend.
Ord. O- 29-13, passed 11-19-13)



§ 34.59  PERMIT REQUIRED; ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.



   (A)   Any organization or individual desiring exclusive use of a
city recreational facility or park or a portion thereof shall make
application therefor on a form approved by the City Council, obtainable from
the Parks and Recreation Department. The application shall contain an
agreement by the organization indemnifying the city from liability resulting
from the organizations/groups use of the recreation facility or park.
Permits shall be available upon such charges as may be determined from time
to time by the Parks and Recreation Department, which charges may include the
posting of a reasonable security deposit and rental fees.



   (B)   (1)   The cost of a per- day rental permit for use of the
picnic shelter shall be:



         (a)   For residents          $25



            of the city



         (b)   For nonresidents      $100



            of the city



      (2)   The cost to rent a ball field for a period not to exceed
four hours in length shall be:



         (a)   For residents          $15



            of the city



         (b)   For nonresidents      $50



            of the city



      (3)   The cost of the use of ball field lights shall be $25
per hour for all users.



      (4)   All persons that rent the picnic shelter or ball field
shall also deposit the sum of $100 at the time the rental permit is issued to
cover any damages.



   (C)   The deposit fee is for damages and is refundable on inspection
if no damage has occurred.



   (D)   (1)   (a)   The City Council designates the Recreation
Orchard Room as a permitted location for alcohol service and consumption in
connection with rentals to be held at the facility, subject to the prior
issuance of a permit for the event. Permits may be subject to such conditions
as may, from time to time, be approved by the local Liquor Control
Commissioner to promote and ensure compliance with all applicable ordinances
of the city and laws of the state. Permit applicants shall be required to
execute a written agreement accepting such conditions prior to the issuance
of any permit. Permits shall be available upon such charge as may be
determined from time to time by the Parks and Recreation Department, which
charges may include the posting of a reasonable security deposit and
purchase, through the city, liability insurance, naming the city as
additional insured on the policy.



         (b)   In addition to any condition imposed from time to
time by the local Liquor Control Commissioner on the service and consumption
of alcoholic beverages in connection with permits for events at which such
service and consumption is contemplated, the service and consumption of
alcoholic beverages at such permitted events shall be subject to the
following requirements at all listed city locations within this code:



            1.   No bottles or glass containers are permitted;



            2.   Alcohol must be served in plastic cups;



            3.   Only beer and wine are permitted to be served
or consumed;



            4.   The sale of alcohol in exchange for any form
of consideration is prohibited;



            5.   All applicable ordinances and laws must be
followed;



            6.   Alcohol must be contained within the Orchard
Room;



            7.   The required security deposit will be
forfeited if the facility is damaged or not cleaned properly after the event;
and



            8.   Posting of a reasonable security deposit and
purchase of liability insurance, through the city, naming the City of Palos
Heights as



additional insured on the policy.



         (c)   The city further designates the following city
owned locations as eligible locations for the service and consumption of
alcoholic beverages pursuant to a special event permit, subject to all
applicable provisions of this chapter and this code, and further subject to
the prior issuance of a permit by the city to use the location in question
for the special event. Special event permits may be subject to such
conditions as may be from time to time approved by the local Liquor Control
Commissioner to promote and ensure compliance with all applicable ordinances
of the city and laws of the state. Special event permit applications shall be
required to execute a written agreement accepting such conditions prior to
the issuance of the permit.



            1.    Recreation Center Orchard Room;



            2.   City Hall parking lot;



            3.    Community Park and Pavilion;



            4.   Meyers Park and Pavilion; and



            5.   Memorial Park and Gazebo.



         (d)   The city further designates the following city
owned locations as locations from which the city or its authorized agents or
contracted parties may serve alcoholic beverages in connection with events
conducted by the city at such locations to invitees of the city for
consumption:



            1.    Recreation Center Orchard Room;



            2.   City Hall parking lot;



            3.    Community Park and Pavilion;



            4.   Meyers Park and Pavilion; and



            5.   Memorial Park and Gazebo.



         (e)   All permits issued hereunder must be approved by
the local Liquor License Commissioner prior to the event.



      (2)   Any person who violates the provisions of this division
(D) shall be fined not less than $10 or more than $200 for each offense.



(Ord. O-9-79, passed 3-6-79; amend. Res. R-13-79, passed 4-17-79; amend. Ord.
O-09-80, passed 4-15-80; amend. Ord. 34-85, passed 10-1-85; amend. Ord.
O-18-01, passed 4-17-01; amend. Ord. O-21-01, passed 5-1- 01; amend. Ord.
O-11-17, passed 3-7-17)



POLICE PENSION FUND



§ 34.60  ESTABLISHED.



   A police pension fund is established.



('69 Code, § 14-55)



§ 34.61  BOARD OF TRUSTEES - ESTABLISHED; ADMINISTRATION OF FUND.



   There is established a board of trustees of the police pension fund of
the city.  The board shall administer the police pension fund, and designate
the beneficiaries thereof, in accordance with law.



('69 Code, § 14-56)



Statutory reference:



   Board created, ILCS Ch. 40, Act 5, § 3-128



§ 34.62  COMPOSITION.



   The  board of trustees of the police pension fund shall be composed of
five members, a majority of whom shall be residents of the city.  Two
members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor; one member of the board
shall be elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund, if any; two
members of the board shall be elected from the regular police force by the
full-time members thereof, provided that neither of the members so elected
need be residents of the city.



('69 Code, § 14-57) (amend. Ord. O-9-76, passed 4-20-76)



§ 34.63  TERM OF APPOINTIVE MEMBERS.



   Members of the board of trustees of the police pension fund shall serve
for respective two-year terms, or until their successors are appointed and
qualified.



('69 Code, § 14-58)



§ 34.64  ELECTED MEMBERS - ELECTION; TERM.



   The two members of the board of trustees of the police pension fund who
are to be elected from the police force by the active members thereof, and
the one member to be elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund,
shall be elected at an election held biennially in even- numbered years on
the third Monday in April.  The election shall be held at a place within the
city as shall be prescribed by the members of the board appointed by the
mayor, and shall be conducted under the Australian ballot system, and other
regulations as shall be prescribed by the two members of the board appointed
by the mayor.  Members shall be elected for a term of two years, the term
beginning on the second Tuesday of May, after the election.



('69 Code, § 14-59)



§ 34.65  VOTING.



   All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote only
for the police force members of the board of trustees of the police pension
fund.  All beneficiaries of legal age shall be entitled to vote only for the
member chosen from among the beneficiaries.  No person shall be entitled to
cast more than one ballot at the election.



('69 Code, § 14-60)



§ 34.66  SUCCESSION TO OFFICE.



   Upon the death, resignation, or inability to act of any elected member
of the board of trustees of the police pension fund, his successor shall be
elected for the unexpired term at a special election, to be called by the
board, which shall be conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial
election.



('69 Code, § 14-61)



§ 34.67  POWERS, DUTIES OF BOARD.



   The board of trustees of the police pension  fund  shall have the
powers and duties as set forth in ILCS Ch.  40,  Act 5, §§ 3-132 through
3-140, as well as other and further powers as are in accordance with and
prescribed by law.



('69 Code, § 14-62)



Statutory reference:



   Policemen's pension fund, ILCS Ch. 40, Act 5, §§ 3-101 et seq



SUMMERFEST REVIEW COMMITTEE



§ 34.85  RULES OF PROCEDURE.



   The summerfest review committee shall adhere to the following rules in
conducting all hearings and meetings:



   (A)   There shall be no closed-door hearings, meetings, or sessions
except with the unanimous consent of all members present at the time the vote
is taken.



   (B)   Robert's Rules of Order shall be followed at all times except
as modified herein.



   (C)   Members of the audience at any hearing, meeting, or session of
the committee shall be given a reasonable opportunity to participate in the
proceedings, but no member of the audience shall have any voting rights on
the committee.



(Res. R-28-82, passed 11-9-82)



CITY TREE BOARD



§ 34.100  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PARK TREES.  Trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation in
public parks, having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to
which the public has free access as a park.



   STREET TREES.  Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on
land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or
ways within the city.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



§ 34.101  CREATION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A CITY TREE BOARD.



   There is hereby created and established a city tree board which shall
consist of six members, five of which shall be citizens and residents of this
city, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city
council and building commissioner.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90; amend. Ord. O-36-03, passed 8-19-03)



§ 34.102  TERM OF OFFICE.



   The term of the five persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be
three years except that the term of two of the members appointed to the first
board shall be for only one year and the term of two members of the first
board shall be for two years.  In the event that a vacancy shall occur
during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the
unexpired portion of the term.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



§ 34.103  COMPENSATION.



   Members of the board shall serve without compensation.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



§ 34.104  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate,
counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for
the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition
of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas.  Such
plan will be presented annually to the city council and upon their acceptance
and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan. 
The board, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate,
make finding, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming
within the scope of its work.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



§ 34.105  OPERATION.



   The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and
regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings.  A majority of the
members shall be quorum for the transaction of business.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



§ 34.106  PUBLIC TREE CARE.



   The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove
trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues,
lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public
safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public
grounds.  The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed,
any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason
of its nature is injurious sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water
lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious
fungus, insect or other pest.  This section does not prohibit the planting
of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and
location of said trees in accordance with §§ 34.106 through 34.110.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



§ 34.107  TREE TOPPING.



   It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city
department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public
property.  Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs
larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree
so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree.  Trees severely
damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or
other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be
exempted from this subchapter at the determination of the city tree board.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)  Penalty, see § 34.999



§ 34.108  PRUNING, CORNER CLEARANCE.



   Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right- of-way within
the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct
the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street
intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of 8 feet above the
surface of the street or sidewalk.  Said owners shall remove all dead,
diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a
menace to the safety of the public.  The city shall have the right to prune
any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper
spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with
visibility of any traffic- control device or sign.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)  Penalty, see § 34.999



§ 34.109  DEAD OR DISEASED TREE REMOVAL ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.



   The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or
diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees
constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which
constitute a potential threat to the trees within the city.  The city will
notify in writing the owners of such trees.  Removal shall be done by said
owners at their own expense within 15 days after the date of service of
notice.  In the event of failure to owners to comply with such provisions,
the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of
removal.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90; amend. Ord. O-19-04, passed 4-20-04)  Penalty,
see § 34.999



§ 34.110  REMOVAL OF STUMPS.



   All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface
of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the
surface of the ground.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)  Penalty, see § 34.999



§ 34.111  INTERFERENCE WITH CITY TREE BOARD.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with
the city tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the
planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street
trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this
subchapter.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)  Penalty, see § 34.999



§ 34.112  ARBORISTS LICENSE AND BOND.



   It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business
or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street or park trees within
the city without first applying for and procuring a license.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)  Penalty, see § 34.999



§ 34.113  REVIEW BY CITY COUNCIL.



   The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and
decisions of the city tree board.  Any person may appeal from any ruling or
order of the city tree board to the city council who may hear the matter and
make the final decision.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



VETERANS COMMISSION



§ 34.120  CREATED.



   There is hereby created a Veterans Commission composed of nine members.



(Ord. O-40-94, passed 5-17-94)



§ 34.121  APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.



   The members of the Veterans Commission shall be appointment by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.  The Veterans
Commission shall annually elect from their members a Chairman.



(Ord. O-40-94, passed 5-17-94)



§ 34.122  TERM OF OFFICE.



   The term of office of each member of the Veterans Commission shall be
for three years.  Initially, three members shall be appointed to one-year
terms, three members to two-year terms, and three members to three-year
terms.  Thereafter, all members shall be appointed to three-year terms,
except in the case of an appointment to fill a vacancy, when the appointee
shall be appointed for the remainder of the vacated term.



(Ord. O-40-94, passed 5-17-94)



§ 34.123  RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.



   Each member of the Veterans Commission shall have resided in the city
for at least one year  prior to their appointment and shall have received an
Honorable Discharge from the Armed Forces of the United States.



(Ord. O-40-94, passed 5-17-94)



§ 34.124  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of the Veterans Commission shall be:



   (A)   To recognize the contribution of residents of the city who
have served in the Armed Forces of the United States.



   (B)   To assist veterans in preserving their rights in obtaining
benefits from various governmental agencies by cooperating with such agencies
for the benefit of such veterans.



   (C)   To educate the citizenry as to the accomplishments and
contributions of veterans.



   (D)   To study, consider, and support activities which may be
planned relating to Veteran affairs.



   (E)   Provide recognition to city residents who become accepted to
or graduated from the military academies of the United States.



(Ord. O-40-94, passed 5-17-94)



§ 34.125  MEETINGS.



   The Veterans Commission shall meet monthly or as necessary in the City
Hall, or in some other suitable location.



(Ord. O-40-94, passed 5-17-94)



PUBLIC ARTS COMMISSION



§ 34.130  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is hereby established the City of Palos Heights public arts
commission



(Ord. O-16-12, passed 10-16-12)



§ 34.131  QUALIFICATIONS FOR MEMBERSHIP.



   Members of the public arts commission shall be residents of the city,
18 years or older, and possess knowledge and experience related to the arts.



(Ord. O-16-12, passed 10-16-12)



§ 34.132  MEMBERSHIP, APPOINTMENT, REMOVAL, TERMS, AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The public arts commission shall be composed of five members
to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
Members of the city council may submit names of qualified candidates to the
mayor. The city reserves the right to appoint a liaison to the commission.



   (B)   Members may be removed prior to the expiration of their term
of appointment by a majority vote of the corporate authorities.



   (C)   Members shall be appointed for three-year terms. Initially
terms will be staggered as follows: one appointment for one year; two
appointments for two years; and two appointments for three years. At the
conclusion of any term, a member shall serve until a respective successor has
been appointed and qualified.



   (D)   Members shall serve without compensation or benefits.



   (E)   The public arts commission shall elect a chairman from its
membership annually.



(Ord. O-16-12, passed 10-16-12)



§ 34.133  DUTIES.



   The public arts commission created hereunder shall perform the
following functions:



   (A)   Create a mission statement.



   (B)   Recommend guidelines for the selection of public art and sites
based on preservation, enhancement, embellishment and commemoration of the
historic, cultural, development and architectural characteristics of the city
and its people.



   (C)   The commission will report to the buildings and grounds
committee on the sustainability of locations for public art, as well as
present proposals for public arts projects and/or programs. All projects and
programs must have final approval from the city council.



   (D)   The commission shall determine the costs of artistic
acquisitions and projects, as well as recommend funding options for lease or
purchase of said public art. A budget and plan must be prepared for the
fiscal period January 1 through December 31 annually.



   (E)   The commission may partner with and/or promote educational
outreach programs to benefit residents of all ages.



   (F)   The public arts commission is authorized to seek public and
private funding assistance for the acquisition and maintenance of programs
and works of art.



   (G)   The public arts commission shall keep an inventory of all
pieces of public art and provide an annual report to the city regarding its
activities and plans.



(Ord. O-16-12, passed 10-16-12)



§ 34.999  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of §§ 34.100 through 34.113 shall
be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a fine not to exceed $500.



(Ord. 90-43, passed - -90)



CHAPTER 35:  POLICE DEPARTMENT

   35.01   Police department - established

IN GENERAL



§ 35.01  POLICE DEPARTMENT - ESTABLISHED.



   The police department of the city is established.  The department
shall consist of police officers as may be appointed, as provided in this
chapter. 



('69 Code, § 14-1)



Cross-reference:



   Board of fire and police commissioners, §§ 34.30 through 34.35



§ 35.02  DUTIES.



   It shall be the duty of each member of the police department of the
city to enforce all orders relative to the preserving of the peace, health,
good order, and quiet, and to prosecute all violations of the ordinances of
the city.



('69 Code, § 14-2)



§ 35.03  CHIEF OF POLICE - APPOINTMENT; TERM.



   The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may appoint
an officer of the city, to be styled "chief of police," who shall hold office
during the pleasure of the mayor and city council.  The chief of police
shall be the superintendent of the police department of the city.



('69 Code, § 14-3)



§ 35.04  DUTIES.



   The chief of police shall be the superintendent of the city police
department. He or she shall keep records and make reports concerning the
activities of his or her department as may be required by statute, or by the
city council, or by the mayor.  He or she shall be responsible for the
performance by the police department of all its functions.



('69 Code, § 14-4)



§ 35.04-1  DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE; ADMINISTRATIVE APPOINTMENT; TERM.




   (A)   The chief of police may appoint up to two current members of
the city police department to the administrative position of "deputy chief of
police" who shall hold this exempt position at the pleasure of the chief.





   (B)   Any appointment to the administrative position of deputy chief
of police shall be from the existing sworn full time officers of the city.
The appointee shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police and may be
removed as deputy chief at any time by the chief of police.





   (C)   In the event the chief of police shall appoint an officer to
fill one or both deputy chief of police positions created herein, the
appointee to any such position shall maintain his or her then current rank
within the department and shall revert to said rank upon the termination of
his or her appointment to deputy chief. In the event an officer is appointed
to the deputy chief of police position, that officer's current rank shall not
be filled as said officer shall maintain his or her current rank while
serving as deputy chief of police.





(Ord. O-25-97, passed 8-19-97; amend. Ord. O-18-04, passed 4-20-04)




§ 35.05  CLASSIFICATION, COMPENSATION OF PERSONNEL.



   (A)   Personnel of the police department shall be classified and
compensated in the manner and amounts prescribed by the city council.



   (B)   No provision of this code or of the ordinance adopting this
code shall be construed to repeal, amend, or supersede any ordinance or any
provision of any ordinance relating to police salaries, including ordinances
numbered  O-70-68, O-48-67, O-28-66, O-36-65, and O-17-63.



('69 Code, § 14-5) (amend. Ord. O-06-97, passed 5-1-97)



§ 35.06  NUMBER OF FULL-TIME POLICE OFFICERS.



   (A)   The police force of the city shall consist of not more than 28
full-time regular police officers.



   (B)   The police force shall consist of:



      (1)   One Chief of Police;



      (2)   Two Lieutenants;



      (3)   Five Sergeants; and



      (4)   Twenty Patrol Officers.



   (C)   From the above ranks, the chief of police may appoint no more
than two deputy chiefs of police as set forth in § 35.04-1.



(Ord. O-53-71, passed 12-7-71; amend. Ord. O-24-73, passed 4-24-73; amend.
Ord. O-24-74, passed 7-2-74; amend. Res. R-15-77, passed 6-7-77; amend. Ord.
O-50-99, passed 11-16-99; amend. Ord. O-18-04, passed 4-20-04; amend. Ord.
O-05-09, passed 2-17-09)



§ 35.07  MAXIMUM AGE OF SWORN OFFICERS.



   The maximum age for employment of sworn officers of the Police
Department shall be the age of seventy.



(Ord. O-02-08, passed 1-15-08)



§ 35.08  [RESERVED].



§ 35.09  CITIZEN ASSISTANCE.



   It shall be the duty of any person in the city, when called upon by any
member of the city police department, to promptly aid and assist the
policeman in the execution of his police duties.



('69 Code, § 14-6)



§ 35.10  CITATION IN LIEU OF COMPLAINT.



   (A)   Whenever a police officer is authorized to arrest a person
without a warrant because of a violation of an ordinance in respect of any of
the following subjects:



      (1)   Prohibiting the parking of a vehicle in a designated
area.



      (2)   Restricting the length of time a vehicle may be there
parked (overnight parking).



      (3)   Regulating and licensing dogs.



      (4)   Regulating and licensing businesses.



      (5)   Restricting illegal garbage-burning.



      (6)   Regulating the nuisance ordinance.



      (7)   Handicapped parking.



   (B)   The police officer may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint
in court, in the first instance issue to the alleged violator, a citation:



      (1)   Advising the person that he has violated a specified
ordinance.



      (2)   Requesting him to make payment in an amount applicable
to the alleged violation, as set forth in § 35.14 of this chapter, as
settlement of the violation claim.



      (3)   Informing him that upon failure to settle, a complaint
will be filed in the Circuit Court of Cook County, charging him with a
violation.



('69 Code, § 14-7; amend. Ord. 0-16-85, passed 6-4-85)



§ 35.11  SETTLEMENT.



   (A)   Pursuant to a citation issued under § 35.10, the person
accused of a violation may settle and compromise the violation claim by
paying to the city the applicable amount, as shown in the schedule set forth
in § 35.14, within a period to be specified in the citation, not more than 7
days of the time after the alleged offense was committed.



   (B)   The payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions
contained in the citation, at the office of the city clerk, who shall issue a
receipt for the money received and promptly remit the amount to the city
treasurer to be  credited to the proper municipal fund.



('69 Code, § 14-8)



§ 35.12  PROOF OF AUTOMOBILE OWNERSHIP.



   The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which is illegally
operated or parked is registered with the secretary of state in the name of
the alleged violator; or, in the alternative, in the event that a vehicle
sticker issued by the municipality has been issued in the name of and to the
alleged violator, shall be considered prima facie proof that the alleged
violator was in control of or was the operator of the automobile or motor
vehicle at the time of any alleged automobile violation.



('69 Code, § 14-9)



§ 35.13  SERVICE OF NOTICE TO APPEAR;  FILING COMPLAINT.



   In the event that the person to whom any citation is issued fails to
settle and pay the violation claim within the prescribed time, or within a
period of time specified in a final notice (if one is served upon him), then
the peace officer is authorized to cause a notice to appear to be served upon
the alleged violator, and is authorized to file a complaint and to prosecute
the complaint in the Circuit Court of Cook County.



('69 Code, § 14-10)



§ 35.14  FINE SCHEDULE.



   The violation claim described in the citation issued pursuant to §
35.10 may be settled, compromised, and paid in the amounts set forth in the
following schedule:



   (A)   In the event that payment is made prior to the mailing by the
city or by the peace officer of a final notice, the following amounts shall
be accepted as settlement:



   Improper parking            $ 20



   Overnight parking              20



   No dog license                 20



   Dog running at large              20



   No business license              20



   Illegal garbage-burning           20



   Nuisance ordinance              20



   Handicapped parking             100



   (B)   In the event that payment has not been made prior to the
mailing of the final notice and, in fact, final notice has been mailed, the
following amounts shall be accepted as settlement:



      Improper parking        $   40



      Overnight parking         40



      No dog license            40



      Dog running at large         40



      No business license         40



      Illegal garbage-burning      40



      Nuisance ordinance         40



      Handicapped parking         Court appearance



   (C)   In the event that payment is not made within the time
prescribed in the final notice, and a notice to appear has been served and a
complaint filed in the Circuit Court of Cook County, payment of any fine and
costs shall be in the amounts as may be determined and established by the
Circuit Court of Cook County with the minimum fine being $50, except for
handicapped parking, where the minimum fine shall be $100.



('69 Code, § 14-11; amend. Ord. O-16-85, passed 6-4-85; amend. Ord. O-05-96,
passed 3-5-96)



§ 35.15  RULES AND REGULATIONS MANUAL ADOPTED.



   The manual entitled "Palos Heights Police Department Proposed Rules and
Regulations" shall be accepted as the basic document for the city's police
department.



(Ord. 0-22-87, passed 5-26-87)



PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS



§ 35.20  ESTABLISHMENT; APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   There is established an office of part-time policeman. Upon
recommendation of the chief of police, part-time policemen may be appointed
by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council in such number
as the mayor and city council may from time to time determine to be
necessary. The number of hours a part-time officer may work within a calendar
year is restricted. Prior to appointment, all proposed part-time police
officers shall be fingerprinted, and their fingerprints shall be checked for
any possible criminal record. No person shall be appointed as a part-time
police officer if he or she has been convicted of a felony or other crime
involving moral turpitude. No one shall be appointed as a part-time police
officer who fails to meet the following hiring standards:



      (1)   Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of
sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.



      (2)   Be at least 21 years of age.



      (3)   Pass a medical examination.



      (4)   Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.



      (5)   Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license.



      (6)   Have been honorably discharged if he or she has served
in the U.S. military.



      (7)   Meet any other entrance requirements established from
time to time by the police department.



   (B)   The appointment of any or all part-time police officers may be
terminated in accordance with the provisions of the city's personnel manual.



(Ord. 0-01-82, passed 1-5-82; amend. Ord. O-12-11, passed 2-15-11; amend.
Ord. O-10-12, passed 6-19-12)



§ 35.21  POWERS.



   (A)   Part-time policemen shall be members of the regular police
department of the city except for pension purposes. They shall have the same
authority and powers in performance of their duties as are prescribed for
regular members of the police department Part-time police officers shall not
be assigned under any circumstances to supervise or direct full-time police
officers. Part-time officers shall not be used as permanent replacements for
permanent full-time police officers.



   (B)   Part-time police officers shall be trained under the
Intergovernmental Law Enforcement Officer's In-Service Training Act in
accordance with the procedures for part-time police officers established by
the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board. Part-time officers
that have not yet received certification shall be directly supervised.



(Ord. 0-01-82, passed 1-5-82; amend. Ord. O-12-11, passed 2-15-11; amend.
Ord. O-10-12, passed 6-19-12)



§ 35.22  BENEFITS.



   Part-time police officers shall receive such compensation and other
benefits as may be prescribed from time to time by the mayor and city council.



(Ord.0-01-82, passed 1-5-82; amend. Ord. O-12-11, passed 2-15-11)



POLICE PENSION FUND



§ 35.50  EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS TO BE PICKED UP BY MUNICIPALITY.



   (A)   In accordance with Section 3.125.1 of Chapter 108-1/2, Article
3 of the Illinois Pension Code, the municipality will pick up the employee
contributions now being paid to the Police Pension Fund.  Upon receipt of a
favorable ruling in regard to Section 414 (h) from the Internal Revenue
Service by the Police Pension Fund, the municipality, as soon as practicable,
will exclude these contributions from the gross pay of policemen and will
withhold federal and state income taxes on the gross pay less the
contributions.  This pickup of contributions will apply to all policemen
that are members of the Police Pension Fund.



   (B)   The Police Pension Fund has applied for a ruling from the
Internal Revenue Service in regard to the pickup of contributions.



(Res. R-07-83, passed 8-2-83)

§ 37.01  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.

except where otherwise provided for by labor agreement.



('69 Code, § 2-195; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord.
O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend. Ord. O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)

Municipal Retirement Fund, effective January 1, 1967.



('69 Code, § 2-196; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.

§ 37.03  CITY DEPARTMENTS.



   The following offices and places of employment in the city are
established:



   (A)   Roads and construction.



   (B)   Sewer and water.



   (C)   Police Department.



   (D)   Vehicle maintenance.



   (E)   Department of general government.



   (F)   Department of recreation.



   (G)   Department of municipal grounds and property.



   (H)   Swimming pool.

('69 Code, § 2-197; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-33-81, passed 12-1-81; amend. Ord. O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord.

O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)



§ 37.04 APPOINTMENT TO OFFICES NOT MANDATORY.



   The establishment of the offices and places of employment set forth in
this chapter shall not require the appointment be made thereto or to any of
them, but appointments thereto may be made only as conditions,
appropriations, and necessity dictate.



('69 Code, § 2-198; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord.
O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend. Ord. O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)



§ 37.05  APPOINTMENTS GENERALLY.



   The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council, shall
appoint all personnel with departmental, supervisory, or official capacity,
except as otherwise provided by statute or ordinance of the city.



('69 Code, § 2-200; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord.
O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend. Ord. O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)



§ 37.06  HIRING AUTHORITY OF DEPARTMENT DIRECTORS.



   (A)   The department directors, subject to review by the City
Administrator and approval by the standing committee of the Council under
whose jurisdiction the department comes, shall have the authority, when
authorized by Council action, to employ the necessary personnel to perform
the necessary duties of their respective departments.



   (B)   Procedures shall be for the department directors, after
consulting with the City Administrator, to work through the standing
committee of the Council, to present to the Council need for additional
personnel; upon recommendation of the committee, Council would authorize the
department director to employ the necessary personnel, subject to the
approval of the standing committee under whose jurisdiction the department
comes; the department director shall direct all new employees as well as all
terminating employees to the personnel office for the purpose of filling out
all the necessary forms for payroll and insurance and also for terminating
their employment with the city.



   (C)   Upon the termination or resignation of an employee of a
department, the department director, after consulting with the City
Administrator and notification made in writing to the Mayor and his or her
committee chairperson, shall hire replacement personnel.



   (D)   Fingerprints and/or background checks shall be required of all
employees and volunteers prior to appointment or hiring. Upon applying for
any position within the city, each employee, prospective employee, volunteer
or prospective volunteer, shall be asked to sign a consent form authorizing
the city to conduct such checks.



('69 Code, § 2-201; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord.
O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend. Ord. 92-07, passed 2-18-92; amend. Ord.
O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)



§ 37.07  CITY RESIDENTS PREFERRED AS CITY EMPLOYEES; RECORD OF ADDRESS.



   Whenever possible, it shall be the policy of all department directors
to employ personnel who are bona fide residents of the city. All city
personnel shall maintain an up-to-date record of residence address with the
department of general government.



('69 Code, § 2-202; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord.
O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend. Ord. O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)



§ 37.08  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION.



   (A)   Medical examination may be required for all permanent
full-time employees of all departments. A report of the physician's finding
shall be made on a standard form provided by the city. The physician's
examination fees shall be paid for by the city. The purpose of the physical
examination is to enable the city and its insurers and physicians to
anticipate and help to prevent health problems, which is in the interest of
both the employees and the city. It is therefore mandatory that every
employee cooperate with this program and consent to periodic physical
examinations as requested by the city, its physician or its insurers.



   (B)   It shall be just cause to terminate any employee who refuses
to participate in a medical/physical examination, upon receiving a written
notice not less than five days before that examination is required.



('69 Code, § 2-203; amend. Ord. O-76-72, passed 12-19-72; amend. Ord.
O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend. Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord.
O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend. Ord. 92-08, passed 2-18-92; amend. Ord.
O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)



§ 37.09  DEPARTMENT DIRECTORS SALARY ADJUSTMENT.



   Annually, as part of the budget process, a salary adjustment will be
recommended by the Mayor. The City Council acting as a committee of the whole
in executive session will review the Mayor's recommendation. The
establishment of the salary will be acted upon at a Council meeting. The
adjustment shall be effective on January 1 of the fiscal year using data
provided by the City Administrator regarding comparable external and internal
salaries for like positions and the city's ability to pay.



(Ord. O-08-80, passed 4-15-80; amend. Ord. O-13-82, passed 4-20-82; amend.
Ord. O-20-86, passed 6-17-86; amend. Ord. O-90-07, passed 4-17-90; amend.
Ord. O-06-06, passed 5-2-06)

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 38.01  DEPARTMENT HEADS UNDER SUPERVISION OF THE MAYOR.

shall operate under the supervision and direction of the Mayor.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



MUNICIPAL GROUNDS AND PROPERTY DEPARTMENT



§ 38.10  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is established the Municipal Grounds and Property Department.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81; amend. Ord. 0-9-82, passed 4-6-82)



§ 38.11  RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Municipal Grounds and Property Department shall be responsible for
the maintenance of all city owned or leased buildings, structures, parks and
parkways; control of weeds within the city; and the operational maintenance
of all motorized equipment and vehicles.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81; amend. Ord. 0-9-82, passed 4-6-82)



§ 38.12  SUPERVISION.



   There is created the Director of Municipal Grounds and Property who
shall supervise all city employees assigned to the Department of Municipal
Grounds and Property.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81; amend. Ord. O-9-82, passed 4-6-82)

(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



Cross-reference:

§ 38.21  RESPONSIBILITIES.



   Responsibilities of the Department of General Government and its
personnel shall be the city's fiscal operation (collections, purchases,
disbursements, depositories, insurance, general administration).



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81; amend. Ord. O-9-82, passed 4-6-82)



§ 38.22  DIRECTOR OF ACCOUNTING.



   (A)   There is created the Office of Director of Accounting who
shall report to the City Administrator.



   (B)   Responsibilities include:  accounting and related information
systems, payroll, accounts payable and receivable, financial reporting,
investment analysis, grant procurement, and general government duties as
directed.



(Ord. O-15-00, passed 4-18-00; Am. Ord. O-06-10, passed 3-2-10)



§ 38.23  OFFICE MANAGER/CITY COLLECTOR.



   (A)   Responsibilities include:  benefits administration,
administrative services, payroll, and accounts payable and receivable.
Responsible to the City Administrator for day-to-day administration of city
office administration.



   (B)   Strong administrative and communications skills required. Must
work well in a team-oriented environment.



   (C)   Directly oversees all employees assigned to the Department of
General Government.



(Ord. O-06-10, passed 3-2-10)

DEPARTMENT OF ROADS AND CONSTRUCTION



§ 38.40  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is established the Department of Roads and Construction.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



§ 38.41  RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Department of Roads and Construction shall be responsible for the
maintenance of all city roadways, implementation of flood control programs,
the issuance of permits and inspections for all buildings, sites, and signs,
the issuance of all business licenses, and related activities.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



§ 38.42  SUPERVISION.



   There is created a Director of Roads and Construction and a Building
Commissioner who shall supervise the Department of Roads and Construction. 
The Director of Roads and Construction shall supervise all city employees
assigned to this Department. The Building Commissioner shall supervise all
building inspectors and such other city employees as may be assigned to
him.  The Director of Roads and Construction shall be in charge of all
public construction.  The Building Commissioner shall be in charge of the
issuance of all licenses and permits for construction, signs and business
licenses.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)

   For provisions concerning the Health Department, see §§ 37.40 through
34.59.



SWIMMING POOL DEPARTMENT

   There is established the Swimming Pool Department.

§ 38.56  SUPERVISION.



   The Swimming Pool Department shall be supervised in accordance with the
provisions of §§ 34.56 through 34.59.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)




WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT

   There is established the Water and Sewer Department.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



Cross-reference:



   Schedule of salaries, see § 37.31



§ 38.61  RESPONSIBILITIES.



   The Water and Sewer Department shall be responsible for the maintenance
and operation of all sewer and water systems owned or operated by the city or
located within the boundaries of the city and related matters.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



§ 38.62  SUPERVISION.



   There is created the office of Director of the Water and Sewer
Department who shall be in charge of all city employees assigned to the
Department.



(Ord. O-33-81, passed 12-1-81)



CHAPTER 39:  PURCHASING



Section



   39.01   Policy



   39.02   Bids and specifications



   39.03   Vendor performance



   39.04   Formal purchases; competitive bids



   39.05   Contracts not requiring competitive bids



   39.06   Specifications



   39.07   Invitation to bid



   39.08   Opening of bids



   39.09   Awarding of the contract



   39.10   Semi-formal purchases



   39.11   Purchase requisitions



   39.12   Securing the purchase



   39.13   Receipt of purchase



   39.14   Payment of purchase



   39.15   Emergency purchases
