   39.17   Petty cash purchases



   39.18   Local businesses or suppliers



   39.19   IDOT provisions incorporated by reference



§ 39.01  POLICY.



   The purchasing policy is set up to establish a system and control for
all purchases and contracts.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.02  BIDS AND SPECIFICATIONS.



   When required, formal bids for all departments should be requested
through the designated committee. The department requesting a product or
service shall provide the department's committee with the desired
specifications.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-62; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.03  VENDOR PERFORMANCE.



   Complaints about unsatisfactory product quality or service from vendors
should be made promptly to the City Administrator.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.04  FORMAL PURCHASES; COMPETITIVE BIDS.



   A FORMAL PURCHASE is any purchase of capital equipment which exceeds
$20,000, or any supply, material, or service which exceeds $20,000. Except as
otherwise provided, all purchase orders or contracts of whatever nature, for
labor, services or work, the purchase or lease of personal property,
materials, equipment or supplies, involving amounts in excess of $20,000,
shall be let by free and open competitive bidding after advertisement, to the
lowest responsible bidder. All such purchase orders or contracts, as defined
above, which shall involve amounts of $20,000 or less, shall be let in the
manner described above whenever so directed by the Mayor or City Council. 
The requirements for formal purchases shall not be circumvented (e.g., two or
more purchases from the same vendor on the same date for items which have a
total that exceeds $20,000.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 21-86, passed 6-17-86; amend.
Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord. O-01-10, passed 1-5-10; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5-15)



§ 39.05  CONTRACTS NOT REQUIRING COMPETITIVE BIDS.



   Contracts which by their nature are not adapted to award by competitive
bidding, such as but not limited to contracts for the services of individuals
possessing a high degree of professional skill where the ability or fitness
of the individual plays an important part, contracts for the supplies,
materials, parts or equipment which are available only from a single source,
contracts for utility services such as water, light, heat or telephone, shall
not be subject to the competitive bidding requirements. A city department may
be authorized to procure from any federal, state or local government unit or
agency thereof such materials, supplies, commodities or equipment as may be
made available from an authorized purchase plan without conforming to the
competitive bidding requirements.



(Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord. O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.06  SPECIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The preparation of specifications shall be determined by the
nature of the purchase.



      (1)   All specifications pertaining to the construction,
alteration, or repair of any real property shall be prepared by the building
commissioner, the director of buildings and grounds, or a professional
architect or engineer hired on a contractual basis, who will also supervise
the performance, inspection, and testing of the contracts.



      (2)   All specifications pertaining to automotive purchases
shall be prepared by the department head (in charge of the department) or his
designee. The department head shall also supervise the performance,
inspection, and testing of the contracts in cooperation with the motor
vehicle maintenance department head.



      (3)   All other specifications should be prepared by the
department head, or his designee, of the department for which the purchase
will be made.



   (B)   All specifications shall adhere to certain guidelines to
insure proper communications with the vendors.



      (1)   Specifications should set out the essential nature of
the items and not call for features or a quality level which is not necessary.



      (2)   Standard specifications are to be used whenever possible
and should be developed from a combination of user department needs, samples
of state and federal specifications, and the input of industry.



      (3)   Specifications should consider both the design and
performance features of the desired purchase.



      (4)   Any trade names, brand names, or catalog numbers shall
be used only as comparison points for certain quality levels. Bids shall be
considered for any product which meets the desired quality.



      (5)   Samples can be required whenever product testing is
needed to assure a quality level.



      (6)   Specifications shall be submitted in accordance with
state statutes regarding the posting requirements prior to the bid opening
date.



   (C)   The committee, staff and any assigned consultants shall assume
responsibility for reviewing the specifications.



      (1)   Specifications shall be checked for restrictiveness and
appropriate quality levels.



      (2)   The committee and staff may suggest any changes in
requirements to the user department.



      (3)   City council has the right to make any changes in
language construction or format, without the direct approval of the user
department, as long as those changes do not alter the inherent meaning of the
specifications.



   (D)   The committee or department head shall acknowledge addenda
(i.e. modifications or clarifications to specifications after bid invitations
have been sent) when necessary.



      (1)   The department head, or his designee, shall send the
addenda to the bidders prior to the bid opening date.



      (2)   Bids already received shall be returned by certified
mail.



      (3)   If the addenda cannot be submitted with sufficient time
for bidders to respond prior to the opening date, then the bid opening shall
be rescheduled.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.07  INVITATION TO BID.



   (A)   Public notice shall be given for all formal purchase bids.



      (1)   Advertisement for bids shall be placed only when the
committee, department head, or designee has all applicable documents,
specifications, and drawings in its possession.



      (2)   Advertisements for bids shall either describe the nature
of the proposed bid in sufficient detail or give reference to the
specifications on file.



      (3)   The notice shall state the time, place, and date
assigned for the opening bids.



   (B)   Vendors shall be selected as follows.



      (1)   Any responsible vendor who meets the specifications and
requirements of the bid and who deals in the product or service requested is
an eligible bidder.



      (2)   Past bid files, trade magazines, trade shows,
promotional advertising, phone directories, and the recommendations of the
user department are all potential sources for bidders.



   (C)   The request for bid shall include three parts: the bid
form on which the proposal will be made, a copy of the specifications, and
instructions for bidding.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.08  OPENING OF BIDS.



   (A)   The bid opening is scheduled by the specifications in the bid
packet or by the committee or city council if rescheduled.



   (B)   The sealed bids are received by the city clerk or city
designee. They are date- and time-stamped and held insecurity.



   (C)   The sealed bids are opened as scheduled.



   (D)   All qualified bids are tallied on the bid tabulation sheet by
department head, city clerk, or city designee. Bid tabulation sheets are
distributed to the appropriate city officials and to the members of city
council.



   (E)   Disqualification can occur in one of the following ways:



      (1)   Failure to submit a bid bond or other required documents
when requested.



      (2)   Failure to meet the specifications or schedule.



      (3)   Failure to meet the appointed deadline.



      (4)   Any act of collusion (intent to defraud).



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.09  AWARDING OF THE CONTRACT.



   (A)   The mayor and city council shall accept the lowest responsible
bids or reject all bids.



      (1)   The council may recommend referral to the department
head and his staff for review and advisement at the next regular council
meeting.



      (2)   When warranted, the user department shall prepare a memo
to the mayor and city council of an ultimate recommendation on the bids
received.



      (3)   Upon the awarding of a bid, the user department shall
forward a purchase requisition to the Finance Department/Accounts Payable
Office.



   (B)   The responsibility of a bidder shall include consideration of
past performance, experience, service, and the ability to meet time tables,
as well as financial considerations.



   (C)   If only one qualified bid is submitted, a re-bid may take
place.



   (D)   A bid-award file shall be kept by the department head and
Finance Department and include the following:



      (1)   The original request for bid form and all addenda.



      (2)   A copy of the advertisement for bid with the publisher's
statement.



      (3)   The original bids.



      (4)   A completed tabulation sheet.



      (5)    A copy of the contract and/or purchase order to the
successful bidder.



      (6)   Certified mail receipts on bids requiring securities.



      (7)   Any pertinent correspondence.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.10  SEMI-FORMAL PURCHASES.



   A SEMI-FORMAL PURCHASE is any purchase of capital equipment which
ranges between $5,000 and $20,000, and for any contract for supplies,
materials, or services which ranges between $5,000 and $20,000. Each
semi-formal purchase calls for at least three price quotations if vendors or
suppliers are available. Quotations for an identical purchase in the last
three months may be considered. The finance department shall honor the user
department's choice for supplier. Semi-formal purchases are subject to review
and approval by the city council committee with legislative responsibility
for the user department.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-02-10, passed 1-5-10; amend. Ord. O-16-15, passed 5-5-15)



§ 39.11  PURCHASE REQUISITIONS.



   (A)   Purchase requisitions must be submitted to the purchasing
service when the purchase is placed.



   (B)   The purchase requisition shall be submitted with all necessary
information completed.



      (1)   The supplier's name, address, phone number and contact
person.



      (2)   A detailed quantity and description which specifically
identifies the desired items shall be typed onto the purchase form.



      (3)   An account number which signifies available funds which
shall be used to pay for the purchase, shall be typed onto the purchase form.



      (4)   The purchase should be indicated as either a pickup or
delivery with the date by which the purchase must be received.



      (5)   The name of the party placing the requisition with the
date of the request.



      (6)   The approval of the appropriate department head and the
date of the approval.



   (C)   When an invoice is received for which no previous approval or
purchase requisition is on file from the city council, committee, city
administrator, or department head approval, the finance department shall
inform the city administrator by memo with a copy of the invoice attached.
The user department shall inform the city administrator and the finance
department, by memo, of the reason for not submitting a purchase requisition
if one was required.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.12  SECURING THE PURCHASE.



   (A)   The purchasing of materials, equipment, and services shall be
in the best interest of the city and provide for the best quality product or
service at the best possible price.



      (1)   Each purchase calls for at least three price quotations.
Quotations for an identical purchase in the last three months may be
considered.



      (2)   Each purchase of $1,500 to $5,000 should require
informal bidding or more than one proposal whenever possible.



      (3)   Past vendors will receive greater consideration when
competitive prices or quality are equal.



   (B)   Before the order is placed it must be verified and approved.



      (1)   The city administrator or designee will check the
account specified for appropriateness and sufficient funds.



      (2)   A purchase number shall be assigned, logged, and stamped
into the purchase form as needed.



   (C)   The department head or his designee places all orders.



      (1)   The finance department may confirm an order by phone.



      (2)   The department head shall confirm all properly
requisitioned orders within three working days.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.13  RECEIPT OF PURCHASE.



   (A)   Upon receipt of goods, the items should be checked for
quantity, correctness, and quality and/or tested by the user department to
insure satisfaction.



   (B)   Upon receipt of goods, the receiving copy of the purchase
order shall be signed, dated, and forwarded to accounts payable in the
finance department as soon as the items are checked.



   (C)   Depreciable items shall be tagged and recorded as a fixed
asset by the user department for inventory purposes.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.14  PAYMENT OF PURCHASE.



   (A)   All purchases are billed directly to the city department or
accounts payable in the finance department. User departments do not hold
their receiving copies expecting to receive direct billing.



   (B)   Bills are paid in semi-monthly disbursements which follow the
approval of vouchers at regular semi-monthly council meetings. Bills which
are received after a meeting but which have been approved per this ordinance
may be paid with appropriate department head approval, city administrator,
and administrative office manager approval.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 1-23-82; amend Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.15  EMERGENCY PURCHASES.



   In the case of an emergency affecting the public health or safety so
declared by the mayor, contracts may be let to the extent necessary to
resolve such emergency without public advertisement.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16 passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.16  STANDING OR BLANKET PURCHASES.



   Departments shall issue standing or blanket purchase orders when the
contracts will serve the best interests of the city.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-16-15, passed 5-5- 15)



§ 39.17  PETTY CASH PURCHASES.



   Out-of-pocket purchases in amounts of $75 or less may be authorized by
department heads and will be reimbursed from the city's petty cash fund upon
the presentation of necessary documentation.



(Ord. O-31-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-16, passed 7-3-90; amend. Ord.
O-21-07, passed 7-17-07; amend. Ord. O-16-15, passed 5-5-15)



§ 39.18  LOCAL BUSINESSES OR SUPPLIERS.



   For all contracts, which shall include contracts of $20,000 or less,
and which are not competitively bid, the city shall make all reasonable
efforts to secure the services or goods from businesses or suppliers that
have their offices within the city.



(Ord. O-32-07, passed 11-20-07; amend. Ord. O-16-15, passed 5-5-15)



§ 39.19  IDOT PROVISIONS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE.



   The Illinois Department of Transportations Chapter 5,
Agreements of the Bureau of Local Roads and Street Manual for
compliance with federally funded municipal projects is hereby incorporated by
reference, the same as if set out in full herein.



(Ord. O-20-18, passed 12-18-18)

§ 50.01  MAKING RULES, REGULATIONS FOR CONNECTIONS, LATERALS.



   The mayor and city council are authorized to make such rules and
regulations consistent with §§ 50.01 through 50.29 for the connections to
the waterworks and sewage systems, and to amend the same from time to time. 
The regulations may specify the types and sizes of pipes and all the other
appurtenances and extensions thereto.



('69 Code, § 20-1)



§ 50.02  COMPLIANCE WITH RULES, REGULATIONS.



   All service pipes and connections to shall comply with the
specifications and the combined waterworks and sewage system rules set forth
by the mayor and city council.  Any persons not complying with the
specifications and rules for connection to the waterworks and sewerage system
shall be subject to a penalty as § 10.99 provides.



('69 Code, § 20-2)



§ 50.03  WATER, SEWER CONNECTION APPLICATION; PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall make any connection to water mains or the sewer mains
of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the city except upon
written application to the city collector and upon the issuance of a permit
by the collector for the connection.



('69 Code, § 20-3)



§ 50.04  APPLICATION INFORMATION.



   Each application for a water or sewer connection permit shall state the
name of the applicant, the permit desired, the location where the permit is
to be used, and the fee to be paid, and each application shall contain such
additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the city
officials in the issuance of a permit.



('69 Code, § 20-4)



§ 50.05  SIGNED PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No connection shall be made with the combined waterworks and sewerage
system without the signed permit of the city collector.  Any connection or
opening made with the waterworks and sewerage system without a signed permit
or in any manner different from the mode prescribed for the opening or
connection, shall subject the maker to the penalties set forth in § 10.99.



('69 Code, § 20-5)



§ 50.06  CHARGES.



   (A)   All water and sewer tap-in fees shall be as determined by the
city council. Agreements for the installment payment of water or sewer tap-in
fees shall be set forth in written contracts executed by the city and the
respective parties responsible for payment of the fees. 



   (B)   The charges for making connections to the water mains of the
system shall be as follows:



      (1)   Residence water tap-in.



         (a)   Single-family residence, multi-family residence
each unit, condominium each unit, when adjacent city-owned water lines are
available:



Rate:  $2,200 per single-family residence, multi-family residence each unit,
condominium each unit.



         (b)   Single-family residence, multi-family residence
each unit, condominium each unit, when adjacent city-owned water lines are
not available:



Rate:  $2,200 per single-family residence, multi-family residence each unit,
condominium each unit, plus the cost of extending the water lines to the
property from the nearest existing termination point of city-owned lines. 
This shall be paid for entirely by the property owner.  The lines shall be
deeded to and maintained by the city.



      (2)   Residence sewer tap-in.



         (a)   Single-family residence, multi-family residence
each unit, condominium each unit, when adjacent city-owned sewer lines are
available:



Rate:  $1,800 per single-family residence, multi-family residence each unit,
condominium each unit.



         (b)   Single-family residence, multi-family residence
each unit, condominium each unit, when adjacent city-owned sewer lines are
not available:



Rate:  $1,800 per single-family residence, multi-family residence each unit,
condominium each unit, plus the cost of extending the sewer lines to the
property from the nearest existing termination point of city-owned lines. 
This shall be paid for entirely by the property owner.  The lines shall be
deeded to and maintained by the city.



      (3)   Business developments water tap-in.



         (a)   $.32 per square foot of land area, when adjacent
city-owned water lines are available.



         (b)   $.32 per square foot of land area, when adjacent
city-owner water lines are not available, plus the cost of extending the
water lines to the property from the nearest existing termination point of
city-owned lines.  This shall be paid for entirely by the property owner. 
The lines shall be deeded to and maintained by the city.



      (4)   Business developments sewer tap-in.



$.26 per square foot of land area, when adjacent city-owned sewer lines are
available.



$.26 per square foot of land area, when adjacent city-owned sewer lines are
not available, plus the cost of extending the sewer lines to the property
from the nearest existing termination point of city-owned lines.  This shall
be paid for entirely by the property owner.  The lines shall be deeded to
and maintained by the city owner.



   (C)   All of the above rates are based on a one-inch tap-in.  The
additional cost involved in any larger size tap-in than the minimum one inch
shall be paid by the developer.



   (D)   Miscellaneous fees and charges:



      (1)   $50 for filling swimming pools and for contractors or
landscapers to tap into a fire hydrant;  and



      (2)   $600 a meter for new construction.



('69 Code, § 20-6; amend. Ord. O-3-70, passed 1-20-70; amend. Ord. O-20-72,
passed 3-21-72; amend. Ord. O-73-72, passed 11-21-72; amend. Ord. O-4-78,
passed 2-7-78; amend. Ord. 90-15, passed 7-2-90; amend. Ord. O-28-99, passed
7-6-99; amend. Ord. O-35-99, passed 8-17-99; amend Ord. O-41-01, passed
9-4-01)



Cross-reference:



   Impact fees for construction of residential building on newly
subdivided lot or resubdivided lot, see § 150.24



§ 50.07  INSPECTION BOND REQUIRED FOR PLUMBER OR SEWER CONTRACTOR DOING
WORK IN UNINCORPORATED AREAS.



   Any plumber or sewer contractor doing work on homes in unincorporated
areas, which plumbing is to be hooked into the water and sewer systems of the
city, shall be required to post with the city a bond in the amount of $200
cash per meter to cover the inspection of the connections to the water or
sewer systems of the city.  Upon completion of the inspection by the city of
the plumbing connection to the city's water and sewer systems, and if the
connection is found to be properly installed, the $200 bond shall be returned
to the plumber or sewer contractor.



(Ord. O-13-74, passed 4-2-74)



§ 50.08  CITY CLERK TO RENDER BILLS, COLLECT MONEYS.



   It is made the duty of the city clerk to render bills for water and
sewer service, and for all rates and charges in connection therewith, and to
collect all moneys due thereon. 



('69 Code, § 20-7)



§ 50.09  REVENUES NOT TO BE COMMINGLED; TO BE DELIVERED TO CITY TREASURER.



   All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the combined
waterworks and sewage system shall be held by the city clerk separate and
apart from his private funds and from all other funds of the city.  All of
such sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the city
treasurer not more than 5 days after receipt of the same, or at more frequent
intervals as may from time to time be directed by the city council.



('69 Code, § 20-8)



§ 50.10  TREASURER TO MAINTAIN, ADMINISTER SEPARATE FUND.



   The city treasurer shall receive all revenues from the combined
waterworks and sewerage system, and all other funds and moneys incident to
the operation of the system, as the same may be delivered to him. He shall
deposit the funds in a separate fund designated as the "Waterworks and
Sewerage Fund of the City of Palos Heights."  The treasurer shall administer
the fund in every respect in the manner provided by state law.



('69 Code, § 20-9)



§ 50.11  RECORD KEEPING; AUDIT.



   The city treasurer shall establish proper systems of accounts and shall
keep proper books, records, and accounts, in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the combined waterworks
and sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause an audit
of the books to be made by an independent auditing concern, to show the
receipts and disbursements of the combined waterworks and sewerage system.



('69 Code, § 20-10)



§ 50.12  FEES AND CHARGES TO GO INTO SPECIFIC FUND.



   All fees and charges prescribed in this chapter shall be paid into
waterworks and sewerage fund, operation and maintenance account. 



('69 Code, § 20-11)



§ 50.13  CITY INSPECTOR TO BE PRESENT AT TAP.



   The city plumbing inspector must be present at any and all taps which
are made into the waterworks and sewerage system of the city, and shall
inspect all taps.



('69 Code, § 20-12)



§ 50.14  TAP TO BE MADE BY LICENSED, BONDED PLUMBER.



   All connections into the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall
be done by a licensed plumber, who has a properly executed bond on file in
the office of the city clerk. 



('69 Code, § 20-13)



§ 50.15  APPLICANTS TO BEAR WATER LATERAL CONSTRUCTION COST.



   All applicants for water service shall provide and pay the cost of
construction, both labor and material, of the water and sewer service from
the property line of the premises to the interior of the premises.



('69 Code, § 20-14)



§ 50.16  LATERAL PIPE DIAMETER.



   The water service pipe from the street main to the water distribution
system for all buildings in the city shall be of sufficient size to furnish
an adequate flow of water to meet the requirements of the building at peak
demand, and in no case shall be less than one inch nominal diameter, with one
coupling allowed if need be. 



('69 Code, § 20-15; amend. Ord. 0-19-72, passed 3-21-72)



§ 50.17  SHUTOFF VALVES GENERALLY.



   A main shutoff valve on the water service pipe shall be provided at or
near the curb.  All extension curb boxes shall be of the Minneapolis Pattern
#5622 with the base tapped to 2 inches bushed down to 1-1/2 inches, with
stationary road and Model #5623 type lid, or an approved equivalent, to be
included, an accessible shutoff valve shall be provided inside, near the
entrance of the water service pipe into the building.  The curb valve shall
be installed in an approved cast-iron valve box or valve manhold, easily
accessible, and protected from frost.



('69 Code, § 20-16; amend. Ord. O-5-71, passed 1-5-71)



§ 50.18  REPAIRS.



   All repairs on that portion of the service pipes between the water main
and the inlet side joint of the curb stop shall be made by and at the expense
of the city.  All repairs to that portion of the service pipes from, but not
including, the inlet side joint of the curb stop to the premises served and
the plumbing system of the building shall be made by and at the expense of
the owner of the premises served.  All meters shall be maintained, repaired,
and replaced at the expense of the owner of the premises served.



('69 Code, § 20-17)



§ 50.18A  CITY PROPERTY.



   The city's responsibility for any water or sewer break shall be limited
to replacing of lawns and driveways excavated as a result of the break.  The
city shall not be responsible for the damage or destruction of any items
placed upon city-owned property by homeowners, such as, but in no way limited
to, shrubs, landscaping, water sprinklers systems, and the like. 



(Ord. 0-22-82, passed 7-20-82)



§ 50.19  CITY LIABILITIES.



   The city shall not be liable for any damage caused by a leak or break
in any water or sewer service pipe, or for damage shall not be liable for any
damage caused by a leak caused by a failure to repair the same promptly, nor
shall the city be liable for any damage caused by the repair or installation
of such pipes or resulting therefrom. 



('69 Code, § 20-18)



§ 50.20  APPLICATION FOR DELIVERY OF WATER INTO PREMISES.



   No water from the city water supply shall be drawn from the city mains
except on application for permission to draw water from the city mains.  The
application shall be filed by the owner or his duly authorized agent.  The
application shall specify the class of water service requested, and shall
contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all of the
provisions of this chapter as conditions covering the use and consumption of
the city supply delivered to the premises.  The application shall be
accompanied by a fee for the issuance of the permit and for the cost of
turning on the water for service in the premises.  ('69 Code, § 20-19)



§ 50.21  CLASSES OF WATER SERVICE.



   Classes of water service shall be whatever the council shall ordain.



('69 Code, § 20-20)



§ 50.22  WATER, SEWER RATES.



   There shall be and there are established rates or charges for the use
of, and for the service supplied by, the combined waterworks and sewerage
system of the city based upon the amount of water consumed, as shown by the
water meters, as follows:



   (A)   Within the corporate limits.



      (1)   Water service for residential, single-family,
commercial, industrial and other users.



         (a)   For each residential, single-family user, the
charge shall be as follows:



            1.   $11.22 per 1,000 gallons.



            2.   A minimum quarterly charge of $136.97.



            3.   All owner occupied residential property
owners within the corporate limit who have attained the age of 65 years shall
receive a 25% discount from the above rate if they provide proof of age and
property ownership to the city collector.



         (b)   For each commercial or industrial user the charge
shall be as follows:



            1.   $11.22 per 1,000 gallons.



            2.   A minimum monthly charge of $74.89.



         (c)   Other users.  For each school, school directory,
church, church parsonage, or government user of the waterworks system the
charge shall be as follows:



            1.   $11.22 per 1,000 gallons.



            2.   A minimum monthly charge of $64.20.



      (2)   Water service - multiple users.  A MULTIPLE USER is
defined as any additional number of family or commercial units located on the
same premises, or being serviced through a single water meter, such as
apartment buildings, more than one commercial unit in the same building, or
commercial and residential units in the same building, or commercial and
residential units located in the same building.  In all such cases, there
shall be an additional minimum service charge for each additional unit
connected to the system for the type of service as set out above.



   (B)   Without the corporate limits.



      (1)   Water service for residential, single-family,
commercial, industrial and other users.



         (a)   For each residential, single-family user the
charge shall be as follows:



            1.   $13.93 per 1,000 gallons.



            2.   A minimum quarterly charge of $170.15.



         (b)   For each commercial or industrial user the charge
shall be as follows:



            1.   $13.93 per 1,000 gallons.



            2.   A minimum monthly charge of $82.41.



         (c)   Other users.  For each school, school dormitory,
church, church patronage, or government user of the waterworks system, the
charge shall be as follows:



            1.   $13.93 per 1,000 gallons.



            2.   A minimum monthly charge of $82.41.



      (2)   Water service - multiple users.  A MULTIPLE USER is
defined as any additional number of family or commercial units located on the
same premises, or being serviced through a single water meter, such as
apartment buildings, more than one commercial unit in the same building. In
all such cases, there shall be an additional minimum service charge for each
additional unit connected to the system for the type of service as set out
above.



   (C)   Sewer service charge.  In addition to the foregoing charges
for water service, there shall be a charge for sewer service as follows:



      (1)   Single-family residential users shall pay a charge of
$13.15 per month ($157.80 per year).



      (2)   Commercial, industrial, and other users shall pay, as a
sewer service charge, the additional sum of 20% per month of each users
monthly water service bill.  That additional charge of 20%, but no less than
$14.24 per month per user, or in the case of multiple users per unit, shall
be added to the water service bill.



      (3)   Each residential unit in a condominium development shall
pay a sewer charge of $13.15 per month; however, the sewer service charge
shall not be applicable to condominium developments whose sewer lines are not
owned by the city, and do not flow into a city-owned interceptor.  Further,
lines or the flow therefrom becoming received by a city-owned interceptor,
the sewer charge shall immediately become applicable and payable.



   (D)   Special rates and charges.  The city council reserves the
right to enter into separate contracts with any user of the facilities of the
combined system for special rates and charges, where the particular
circumstances render the regular rates for service inadequate or unjust.




(69 Code, § 20-21) (amend. Ord. O-14-73, passed 3-20-73; amend. Ord.
O-30-77, passed 5-17-77; amend. Ord. O-13-81, passed 7-7-81; amend. Ord.
O-21-85, passed 7-2-85; amend. Ord. 89-32, passed 6-20-89; amend. Ord. 91-24,
passed 8-6-91; amend. Ord. O-03-97, passed 1-21-97; amend. Ord. O-4-98,
passed 1-20-98; amend. Ord. O-17-00, passed 5-4-00; amend. Ord. O-1-02,
passed 1-15-02; amend. Ord. O-3- 02, passed 2-5-02; amend Ord. O- 23-03,
passed 4-15-03; amend. Ord. O-11-04, passed 3-2-04; amend. Ord. O-03-05,
passed 2-1- 05; amend. Ord. O-02-06, passed 3-7-06; amend. Ord. O-23-07,
passed 7-17-07; amend. Ord. O-10- 08, passed 3-18-08; amend. Ord. O-31-08,
passed 12-16-08; amend. Ord. O-12-10, passed 3-2-10; amend. Ord. O-15-11,
passed 2-15- 11; amend. Ord. O-02-12, passed 2-7-12; amend. Ord. O-03-13,
passed 2-19-13; amend. Ord. O-33-13, passed 12-3-13; amend. Ord. O-32-14,
passed 12-2-14; amend. Ord. O-02-15, passed 1-6- 15; amend. Ord. O-04-17,
passed 2-21-17; amend. Ord. O-10-18, passed 5-1-18)




§ 50.23  UNPAID CHARGES TO CONSTITUTE LIEN.



   In the event the charges for water and sewer service prescribed by this
chapter are not paid within 60 days after rendition of the bill for quarterly
service, the charges shall be deemed delinquent, and such delinquencies shall
constitute liens upon the real estate for which the service is supplied. 
The city clerk is authorized and directed to file sworn statements showing
the delinquencies in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook County,
Illinois (or with the registrar of titles of Cook County, if the premises are
registered with the registrar of titles under the torrens system), and the
filing of such statements in such offices shall be deemed notice for the
payment of the charges for the service. The lien to be filed against the
property shall cover all expenses, including legal expenses, filing fees and
administrative expenses.



('69Code, § 20-22; amend. Ord. O-27-11, passed 7-19-11)



§ 50.24  LIABILITY FOR SERVICE.



   The owner shall be liable to pay for the service on the premises. The
service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that
the owner of the premises shall be liable therefor to the city.



(Ord. O-14-14, passed 6-17-14)



§ 50.25  TERMINATION OF DELIVERY AND USE OF WATER.



   The delivery of water from the municipal water mains to any premises
within or without the boundaries of the city shall be terminated by the city
if any of the circumstances enumerated in divisions (A), (B), (C), (D) and
(E) of this section occur, after notice is given in accordance with division
(F) of this section. In such instances, the officers and employees of the
city are directed to shut off the service line connecting the municipal water
main with the premises:



   (A)   When the invoice for water theretofore delivered to the
premises is not paid within 60 days following the date of bill to any
occupant of the premises at the time of such billing, even if such billing is
for water service provided to a former occupant of the premises.



   (B)   When a duly authorized official or employee of the city
designated to read, inspect, or test meters is denied permission to read,
inspect, or test a meter installed upon the premises.



   (C)   When a duly authorized official or employee of the city is
denied permission by the occupant of the premises to inspect downspouts which
may be located on any structure on the premises for the purpose of
determining where there any such downspouts are connected to the sanitary
sewer system of the city.



   (D)   When the premises or any occupant thereof has been determined
by a vote of a majority of a quorum of the city council to have violated any
section of Chapters 50, 51, or 52 of this Code of Ordinances, dealing with
water and sewer use.



   (E)   When a majority of a quorum of the city council has determined
that there has been a violation by the premises or any occupant thereof, of
any rule or regulation of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of
Greater Chicago.



   (F)   Notice of the city's intent to terminate the delivery of water
shall be sent by regular mail, postage prepaid to the last known billing
address for the premises, at least 5 days prior to the termination date as
contained in the notice.  The mailing of the notice shall constitute notice
to all entities or persons liable for payment as contained in § 50.24 or
liable for compliance with Chapters 50, 51, and 52 and of the Code of
Ordinances and the rules and regulations of the Metropolitan Water
Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.



('69 Code, § 20-24)  (Ord. 0-34-82, passed 11-23-82; amend. Ord. 90-40,
passed 12-4-90)



Cross-reference:



   Termination of water service for violation of Chapter 52, see § 52.42



§ 50.26  CHARGES FOR RESUMPTION OF SERVICE.



   The following moneys shall be paid by the consumer prior to the
resumption of service, where the service has been discontinued for nonpayment
of accrued charges:



   (A)   A service fee shall be paid prior to a resumption of service
as follows:



      First resumption      $75



      Second resumption      $100



      All subsequent resumptions   $125



   (B)   A deposit equal to the average quarterly billing for the
service.  Upon the current payment of 4 consecutive bills for water service,
the deposit shall be applied toward the next successive water billing.



(69 Code, § 20-25)  (amend. Ord. O-15-14, passed 6-17-14)



§ 50.27  RESALE OF WATER.



   No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from
the municipal supply to any premises other than that for which an application
has been made and the meter installed. 



('69 Code, § 20-26)



§ 50.28  WATER SPRINKLING, WATER EMERGENCIES.



   (A)   During periods an adequate water supply is available, as
determined by the mayor, the following restrictions shall be enforced as to
the use of water for the sprinkling of gardens and lawns:



      (1)   During the months of May, June, July, August and
September, water may only be used for sprinkling gardens or lawns between the
hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. or between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 10:00
p.m., except in the case of an emergency as determined and declared by the
Mayor.



      (2)   During the months of May, June, July, August and
September, water may only be used for sprinkling gardens or lawns on
even-numbered days of the calendar month on premises bearing even-numbered
street numbers, and on odd-numbered days of the calendar month on premises
bearing odd-numbered street numbers.



      (3)   Sprinkling other than pursuant to this schedule is
prohibited unless authorized by the mayor.



   (B)   In the event that an emergency condition occurs consisting of
a shortage of water supplied to the city or a shortage of reserve supply in
the reservoirs, the existence of which water emergency shall be determined
and declared by the mayor, other water emergency water restrictions
determined and declared by the mayor shall be enforced.



('69 Code, § 20-27; amend. Ord. 89-28, passed 6-6-89; amend. Ord. 89-35,
passed 7-18-89) Penalty, see § 50.99



§ 50.29  DISOBEYING RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF WATER DURING EMERGENCIES.



   In the event that the rules for the use of water during emergencies, as
set out in § 50.28, are not complied with by premises served by the city
water system, whether located within or without the boundaries of the city,
the delivery of water from the municipal water mains to the premises shall
terminate without further notice and shall remain terminated for a period of
24 hours for each violation of the rules set out in § 50.28.  In addition,
water service shall not be resumed until there has been paid to the city as a
fee for the resumption of service the amount of $100. 



(Ord. O-37-74, passed 9-17-74)



§ 50.30  PLANTING OF TREES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, or
organization to plant any species or variety of Willow Tree or Cottonwood
Tree anywhere within the boundaries of the city.



   (B)   Application may be made for a variance from the prohibition
contained in this section to the Water and Sewer Committee of the City
Council and may be granted if it appears that the location of the tree will
not pose a danger now or in the future to water and sewer lines.



(Ord. 0-14-83, passed 10-4-83)  Penalty, see § 50.99



§ 50.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person convicted of any violation of the provisions of §
50.30 shall be fined not less than $150 nor more than $500 for each offense.



   (B)   Any person convicted of any violation of the provisions of §
50.28 (A) shall be fined $25 for the first offense and $100 for each
subsequent offense within the same calendar year.



(Ord. 0-14-83, passed 10-4-83; amend. Ord. 89-35, passed 7-18-89)



CHAPTER 51:  WATER REGULATIONS

WATER METERS



§ 51.01  REQUIREMENT OF METERS.



   All buildings for which a public supply of water is to be made
available shall first have installed, either inside the building or in a
meter box or a meter vault outside of the building, a water meter.  No
public water service shall be made available to any building prior to the
installation of a meter, except for the purpose of testing plumbing
facilities pursuant to § 150.11 (C).  The city shall provide meters to be
so installed in buildings, and the meters shall at all times remain the
property of the city after installation.  The city shall designate the
location of the water meters.  The consumer shall protect the meters,
following their installation, from freezing and other hazards to the
operation thereof.  The consumer shall be  liable to  reimburse the city
for any loss or damage to the city's meters installed on the consumer's
buildings.



(Ord. O-4-75, passed 1-7-75)



§ 51.02  METER INSTALLATION.



   The city, through its public works or other designated department,
shall install and sell all meters, including a remote meter reader, as
required in this chapter.  The installation, servicing, tampering, or
disconnection of meters by any private party, including the owner of the
building or any plumber, is prohibited.



(Ord. O-4-75, passed 1-7-75)



§ 51.03  FEES FOR THE USE, INSTALLATION, AND INSPECTION OF CITY- OWNED
WATER METERS.



   For the use, installation, and inspection of a 5/8-inch by 3/4-inch
water meter in a single-family residence, the owner shall pay to the city,
prior to the issuance of a building permit, the sum of $125.  When the
consumer's plumber has completed the installation of all pipes and other work
preliminary to the installation by the city of its meter, an appointment
shall be made with the city for installation.  In the event that an
appointment is made for installation, and the city determines that the
preliminary work has not been satisfactorily completed so as to permit
installation and it therefore becomes necessary for the city to return to the
premises at subsequent times, the consumer shall pay to the city the sum of
$15 for each additional call made by the city to the premises. 



(Ord. O-4-75, passed 1-7-75)



§ 51.04  TYPE, CHARGE FOR OTHER METERS.



   If the dwelling where any water meter is to be installed is for other
than a single-family residence, or the owner requests a larger size meter
than 5/8 inch by 3/4 inch, the type and charge shall be determined by the
city water department.



(Ord. O-4-75, passed 1-7-75)



§ 51.05  WHEN WATER TURNED ON.



   Following installation of the meter, the consumer's plumbing contractor
shall shut off the supply of water to the dwelling at the buffalo box.  The
water shall not be turned on by the city, unless requested by the contractor
and agreed to by the city for testing purposes, until the occupancy
inspection shall have been made by the city and an occupancy permit granted.



(Ord. O-4-75, passed 1-7-75)



§ 51.06  REMOTE METER READER REQUIRED.



   All water meters up to and including one inch in size shall be equipped
as installed with a remote meter reader.



('69 Code, § 20-43)



§ 51.07  CONDUIT TO CONNECT INSIDE AND REMOTE WATER METER.



   A conduit shall be placed through the outer wall of every structure in
proximity to the location of the inside water meter so that the same may be
connected to a remote water meter.  The maximum distance from the inside
meter to the remote meter shall be 10 feet. 



('69 Code, § 20-44)



§ 51.08  SHUTOFF VALVES.



   The shutoff valves on either side of a water meter shall be at least
the same size as the building water service, and shall be gate valves or
ground key stops.



('69 Code, § 20-45)



§ 51.09  ACCESS FOR INSPECTION, READING METERS.



   Employees of the waterworks and sewerage system of the city shall have
the right of access to any premises served by the combined waterworks and
sewerage system for the purpose of reading water meters at the regular
prescribed intervals, or for the purpose of making inspections in order to
maintain in good condition, and provide for the protection and effective
management of, the combined system.  Where the inspections are not of an
immediate or urgent nature, employees of the combined system shall arrange
for appointments mutually convenient to the persons of the premises served
and the employees.  Any person refusing the right to permit the employees of
the waterworks and sewerage system access to his premises shall be subject to
having service discontinued, after written notice has been given.



('69 Code, § 20-46)



§ 51.10  REMOVING METERS FOR TESTING.



   The city shall have the right at any reasonable time to remove a meter
temporarily for the purpose of testing its accuracy.



('69 Code,  § 20-47)



§ 51.11  TAMPERING WITH WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM METER.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, except personnel authorized by the
city authorities, to tamper with, alter, or injure any part of the city
waterworks or supply system, and it shall be unlawful to interfere with, to
bypass, or to tamper with any meter in any manner whatsoever.  No meter
shall be moved or disturbed without authority obtained from the municipal
authorities. 



('69 Code, § 20-48)



§ 51.12  METER READING FOR MODEL HOMES.



   If any contractor wishes to use any dwelling as a model for sales and
has need for water service, the meter in the dwelling shall be read at the
time of inspection for occupancy is made, and the contractor will be billed
for water used up to that time.



('69 Code, § 20-49)



§ 51.13  INSPECTION OF METERS.



   All meters shall be inspected once every 6 months following their
installation.



(Ord. O-26-72, passed 4-25-72)



§ 51.14  WATER METER SEAL.



   Every water meter shall have affixed thereto a seal preventing the
opening thereof or the tampering therewith except by appropriate authority. 
The owner or occupant of premises served by a water meter shall immediately
report the breaking of or damage to any water meter seal.  Any owner or
occupant of any premises served by a water meter who fails immediately to
report damage to any water meter seal shall be subject to a fine, upon
conviction of such offense, of not less than $10 nor more than $200 for each
violation, and each day that the violation continues shall be deemed to be a
separate offense.



(Ord. O-26-72, passed 4-25-72)



§ 51.15  WATER TO BE METERED DURING CONSTRUCTION.



   Contractors shall obtain water meters from the city and all municipal
water used during the course of construction of a structure shall flow
through a water meter.



(Ord. O-17-81, passed 8-4-81)



§ 51.16  WATER AND SEWER TAP-IN AND INSPECTION FEE.



   (A)   Whenever a request is made for a resubdivision of property
within the city, that request shall be accompanied by a $50 water and sewer
tap-in fee covering the cost of inspecting the subject property.



   (B)   All subsequent inspections which may be made of that property
in connection with the resubdivision shall result in payment by the property
owner to the city of $50.



(Ord. 87-50, passed 11-17-87)



WELLS



§ 51.20  WELLS TO BE DRILLED BY LICENSED DRILLER.



   No water well shall be drilled except by a licensed water well driller.



('69 Code, § 20-60)



§ 51.21  PERMIT REQUIRED FOR DRILLING.



   No water well shall be drilled unless a permit therefor is first
obtained from the city clerk. 



('69 Code, § 20-61)



§ 51.22  PERMIT FEE.



   An applicant for a permit to drill a water well shall pay a fee as
shall be fixed from time to time. 



('69 Code, § 20-62)



§ 51.23  WELL TO BE INSPECTED PRIOR TO CONNECTION.



   All wells shall be inspected prior to connection with a household water
system.



('69 Code, § 20-63)



§ 51.24  CONNECTION WITH PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM PROHIBITED.



   There shall be no inner connection between any well and any municipal
or other public water system.  ('69 Code, 20-64)



§ 51.25  EFFECT OF EXISTING WELLS.



   No section or provision of §§ 51.20 through 51.26 shall be deemed as
requiring the abandonment of any existing well, nor shall §§ 51.20 through
51.26 prohibit the use of any well for private use.



('69 Code, § 20.65)



§ 51.26  CONDEMNATION OF WELLS PROHIBITED.



   Wells may continue to exist and be maintained even though a source of
municipal water is available to premises upon which a well is located or is
desired to be located, and nothing herein or hereinbefore contained shall be
construed to prohibit the operation of wells, provided, that the wells shall
not be connected directly or indirectly to the municipal supply of water, and
the well water shall not be permitted to be commingled with the municipal
water supply. 



(Ord. O-35-71, passed 6-15-71)



INSURANCE



§ 51.50  INSURANCE REQUIRED PRIOR TO WORK ON RIGHTS-OF-WAY.



   Contractors shall post certificate of liability insurance prior to the
commencement of construction upon any facility within any city right-of-way
or any city-owned facility within any public right-of-way.  There shall be
posted a certificate of a policy of insurance covering the liability of the
city for any and all personal injuries or property damages occurring during
the course of construction.  The amounts of such liability shall be not less
than $1,000,000 per personal injury and $500,000 for property damage.



(Ord. 88-54, passed 9-6-88)



CHAPTER 52:  SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL
