GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 52.01  ADOPTION OF A MANUAL OF PROCEDURES.



   There is adopted and incorporated among the rules and regulations
pertaining to the installation and maintenance of sewers within the city a
certain Manual of Procedures for the administration of the Sewer Permit
Ordinance of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago, copies of
which are on file with the city clerk.



(Res. R-13-70, passed 10-20-70)



§ 52.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall
have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.



   (A)   APPROVAL.  As applied to plans or mode of construction,
approval and authorization by the respective person so designated by the city
council.



   (B)   DOWNSPOUT.  A leader or conductor pipe which carries water
from the roof or gutter to the ground or to any part of the drainage system.



   (C)   DRAINAGE SYSTEM.  A system of piping or conduits through
which are conveyed liquids or liquid-borne solids from all plumbing fixtures
and appurtenances in buildings and structures and which conveys the liquid or
solids to the house sewer terminating one foot outside of the building walls.



   (D)   EJECTOR.  A device operated to elevate water, sewage, or
liquid wastes from a lower level to a point of discharge into a house sewer.



   (E)   HOUSE SEWER.  A system of piping or conduits through which
are conveyed liquids or liquid-borne solids, extending from a house drainage
system to its connection with the public sewer or other place of sewage
disposal.



   (F)   NEW, EXISTING.  NEW, in connection with a building or
structure, is equivalent to the phrase "constructed since May 1, 1965,"
unless a new provision is made otherwise, and the word EXISTING is equivalent
to the phrase "in existence prior to May 1, 1965."  If neither of these
qualifying words is used, the provisions of this chapter shall be construed
as applying both to NEW and EXISTING buildings or structures.



   (G)   OWNER.  The owner or owners of the freehold of the premises
or of a lesser estate therein, a vendee in possession, or the lessee or joint
lessee of the whole thereof.



   (H)   PERSON.  Any individual, association, corporation (municipal
or private) or firm acting either directly or through a duly authorized agent.



   (I)   PUBLIC SEWER.  A sewer built by or constructed under the
authority of the city in a public place such as a street, or in and through
land for which an easement has been granted for the common use of the
property abutting on the public place or easement.



('69 Code, § 20-76)



§ 52.03  SEWER CONNECTION REQUIRED.



   The owner of every dwelling located on any lot or parcel of real estate
fronting or abutting on any public way, thoroughfare, or granted easement in
which a public sewer is available shall make or cause the connection of the
house sewer to the public sewer within 12 months of acceptance of the sewer
by the city.



('69 Code, § 20-77)



§ 52.04  HOUSE SEWER SYSTEMS GENERALLY.



   The house sewer system of all buildings and premises connected with the
city water and sewer system shall be constructed in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter.  All repairs and alterations to the house sewer
system shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 



('69 Code, § 20-78)



§ 52.05  SEWER CONSTRUCTION, APPLICATION.



   Any person desiring to construct, add to, alter, or repair a house
sewer system in the city shall make written application to the city.  The
application shall contain an agreement on the part of the applicant that all
the rules, regulations, conditions, and provisions of any ordinance relating
to the sewerage system will be complied with.



('69 Code, § 20-79)



§ 52.06  CONSTRUCTION, PERMIT FEES.



   The fees to be charged for a permit to construct, add to, alter, or
repair any part of a house sewer shall be determined in the manner and amount
which shall be prescribed by ordinance. 



('69 Code, § 20-80)



§ 52.07  USE OF NAME OF ANOTHER TO SECURE PERMITS UNDER THIS CHAPTER.



   No property owner or contractor shall allow his name to be used by any
other person or party directly or indirectly for the purpose of obtaining
permits or for doing any work under his license under this chapter.



('69 Code, § 20-81)



§ 52.08  SEPARATE CONNECTION TO EACH HOUSE FROM MAIN REQUIRED.



   The house sewer of each new building and of any existing building shall
be separate from and independent of that of any other building.  One
connection only shall be made into the public sewer from each lot as provided
for at the time of the public sewer construction.



('69 Code, § 20-82)



§ 52.09  MATERIAL STANDARDS GENERALLY.



   All materials used in any house sewer, or part thereof, shall be free
from defects and conform to the requirements of this chapter.  The
abbreviation "A.S.T.M." hereinafter employed, refers to the "American Society
for Testing Materials."



('69 Code, § 20-83)



§ 52.10  VITRIFIED CLAY PIPE; PVC PIPE.



   (A)   All vitrified clay pipe shall be 6 inches in diameter. 



('69 Code, § 20-84)



   (B)   The provisions of the Code of Ordinances shall be amended so
as to remove therefrom any and all prohibitions against the use of PVC pipe
on underground sanitary sewer projects within the city. 



(Ord. 0-23-85, passed 7-16-85)



§ 52.11  NO BELL PVC JOINTS.



   No bell PVC joints are acceptable as an alternative to bell and spigot
vitrified clay joints, provided the no bell PVC joints meet the test
standards as set out by A.S.T.M. The no bell PVC joint shall meet A.S.T.M.
Specification C-425.



(Ord. O-34-77, passed 10-4-77)



§ 52.12  PVC COLLARS.



   PVC collars installed on the vitrified clay pipe in conjunction with
the no bell PVC joints shall meet A.S.T.M. test standards and A.S.T.M.
Specification D-1784.



(Ord. O-34-77, passed 10-4-77)



§ 52.13  CAST-IRON PIPE.



   All cast-iron sewer soil pipe and fittings shall be a minimum of 4
inches in diameter. 



('69 Code, § 20-85)



§ 52.14  HOUSE SEWER PIPE MATERIAL.



   House sewer pipes shall be of extra heavy cast-iron soil pipe, or extra
strength vitrified clay pipe, the designations of which shall be subject to
the provisions of § 52.18, except that whenever the excavation for a house
sewer is made in unstable ground, the material for the house sewer shall be
extra heavy cast-iron pipe. 



('69 Code, § 20-86)



§ 52.15  TRUSS SEWER MAIN MATERIAL.



   Sewer mains may be constructed of truss material only under the
following circumstances and subject to the following conditions:



   (A)   The truss sewer main may be used only to serve commercial and
multifamily developments and may under no circumstances be used to serve
single-family residences.



   (B)   The truss sewer main may be used only when the city council
has received from the city engineer a written recommendation recommending
such use because of conditions of the ground in which the pipe is to be
located which favor such use, including, but not limited to, unstable ground
with a high water content and, in addition to the recommendation of the city
engineer, the city council shall have accepted the recommendation and shall
have adopted a motion approving the use of such main.



   (C)   If the city council authorizes the use of a truss main, the
main shall not be installed until there has been filed with the city a
performance bond with surety to be approved by the city council, in an amount
to be determined by the city council, the condition of which bond shall be
that the truss main to be installed shall adequately and safely serve as
sewer main for a period of not less than 10 years, during which period of
time the performance bond shall remain in force and effect. 



(Ord. O-16-73, passed 4-3-73)



§ 52.16  EXCAVATIONS, TUNNELING; INSPECTIONS.



   Tunneling for sewers is permissible in yards, courts, or driveways of
any building site.  When a pipe is driven, the drive pipe shall be at least
one pipe size larger than the pipe that is to be laid.  At the discretion of
the city inspector, all excavations required to be made for the installation
of a drainage system or house sewer, or any part thereof, shall be open
trench work.  All trenches and tunnels shall be kept open until the piping
has been inspected, tested, and approved by the director of public services.



('69 Code, § 20-87)



§ 52.17  PIPE INSTALLATION GENERALLY.



   The house sewer shall be laid straight on a uniform grade and on a firm
bed.  The minimum gradient for the house sewer shall be 1/8 inch per foot
for pipe 6 inches in diameter or larger, and 1/4 inch per foot for cast-iron
pipe 4 inches or 5 inches in diameter, all with a maximum gradient of 1/2
inch per foot.  Bell holes shall be dug so that the bell and spigot shall
not rest on the sockets.  The bell end of the pipe shall be laid upgrade. 



('69 Code, § 20-88)



§ 52.18  CLEANOUTS.



   Sewer cleanouts shall be full-size wye-branch and shall be located near
to the connection between the house sewer and house drainage system at every
90° turn, and in the house sewer not more than 75 feet apart.



('69 Code, § 20-89)



§ 52.19  SEWER SPECIFICATIONS FOR CERTAIN PRIVATE WATER SYSTEMS.



   Whenever a private water supply is used in any building or premises
located in the city, the following specifications for the house sewer shall
prevail:



   (A)   There shall be no sewer or drain of any kind within 10 feet of
any well.



   (B)   A house sewer located within 20 feet but further than 10 feet
from any well shall be constructed of extra heavy cast-iron pipe with
mechanical or leaded joints, and shall be tested under pressure.



   (C)   A house sewer further than 20 feet from any well shall be
constructed of sewer pipe with watertight joints.



('69 Code, § 20-90)



§ 52.20  WATER PRESSURE EJECTORS, SIPHONS; USE.



   Water pressure ejectors or siphons shall not be installed for the
discharge of any sewage or waste. 



('69 Code, § 20-91)



§ 52.21  BACKFILLING.



   Adequate precaution shall be taken to insure proper compactness of the
backfill around sewer piping without damage to the piping.  Trenches shall
be backfilled in thin layers to 12 inches above the top of the pipe with
clean earth containing no stones, boulders, cinders, or other material which
would damage or break the piping or cause corrosive action.  Mechanical
devices such as bulldozers and graders, may then be used to complete backfill
to grade.  Fill shall be properly compacted.  Suitable precautions shall be
taken to insure permanent stability for pipe laid in filled or made ground.



('69 Code, § 20-92)



§ 52.22  ACCESS FOR INSPECTION, REPAIR.



   Any person designated by the city to act in its behalf shall have ready
access to all premises served by the public sewer, and it shall be unlawful
for any person or corporation to interfere or obstruct such person in his
work. 



('69 Code, § 20-93)



§ 52.23  CLOSED-CIRCUIT INSPECTION OF SEWER REQUIRED; EXCEPTION.



   The department of public services shall, prior to final approval of any
newly installed sewer system or reconstructed sewer, require all contractors
to make an inspection, by closed-circuit television, of the entire sewer
system installed, showing thereby that the sewer system has been constructed
upon a sound engineering basis, that the sewer system is free of
accumulations of foreign substance and nature, that the passage and flow of
sewage and storm water is free and clear, and that there are no structural
defects.  If, in the discretion of the department of public works, the
sewers are larger enough for a visual inspection to be made, in lieu of an
inspection by closed-circuit television, a visual inspection shall be made,
and a report of the inspection shall be submitted to the city. 



('69 Code, § 20-94)



§ 52.24  PRETEST WATER SATURATION.



   Prior to the television test required by § 52.23 sewer trenches shall
be jetted with water at 25-foot intervals until the excavated trench has been
saturated up to the existing grade. 



('69 Code, § 20.95)



§ 52.25  APPROVAL OF SEWER; PRESERVING RECORDS, PHOTOGRAPHS.



   Upon completion of the inspection required by § 52.23, and upon
receipt of a written report of the inspection, together with such photographs
as may have been taken, the department of public works may, if satisfied that
the sewer is free and clear of all foreign substance, and free of all
engineering defects, approve the sewer.  The department shall safekeep all
inspection records and photographs for future reference by the city.



('69 Code, § 20-96)



§ 52.26  COST OF INSPECTION; RECORDS, PHOTOGRAPHS DECLARED CITY PROPERTY.



   The cost of the television inspection or inspection reports required by
§ 52.23 shall be paid for entirely by the contractor or developer of the
land or sewer system, and the inspection report, together with such
photographs as may have been taken, shall remain the property of the city. 



('69 Code, § 20-97)



§ 52.27  USE OF SEWER REQUIRED FOR DISPOSAL.



   No person having his residence or business within the city, which
dwelling or business is located on property to which public sewer disposal
service is available, shall be permitted to dispose of the sewage of the
residence or place of business other than through the city public sewer,
after connection with the sewer. 



('69 Code, § 20-98)



§ 52.28  SEPTIC TANK EFFLUENT NOT TO BE ALLOWED INTO SEWER.



   No effluent from septic tanks shall be pumped or forced or permitted to
flow into a public sewer. 



('69 Code, § 20-99)



§ 52.29  PERMIT FOR REPAIR GENERALLY.



   Repairs are to be made to a house sewer without a permit only in the
case of leaks or obstructions, in which cases the work need not be reported
in advance to the city.  If the repair in any emergency exceeds the limit of
mending leaks or forcing out an obstruction, the repair shall be reported to
the city within 24 hours thereafter and § 52.05 shall apply.



('69 Code, § 20-100)



§ 52.30  REPAIRING BREAK IN HOUSE SEWER.



   When a part of the house sewer is broken into, the break shall be
properly repaired by replacing the broken parts with a corresponding new
part.  No patching of the break will be accepted. 



('69 Code, § 20-101)



§ 52.31  WHEN CITY MAY ORDER SEWER REPAIRS PERFORMED; WHO BEARS COST.



   Whenever a home sewer is obstructed or is found to be broken or
defective so that sewage escapes into the surrounding soil, or into adjacent
premises, repair or replacement may be ordered by the director of public
services of the city.  The repairs shall be performed at the expense of the
owner or person in control of the property.



('69 Code, § 20-102)



§ 52.32  OVERHEAD PLUMBING.



   After December 31, 1970, all new buildings with basements, floors,
rooms, or occupancy areas below ground level at the building site, and served
by a public or private sewer system, shall have overhead plumbing.  No
permit application will be accepted, nor any permits issued after December
31, 1970 to any municipality or local government unless said municipality or
local government shall have adopted an ordinance requiring overhead plumbing,
and a copy of the ordinance shall have been filed with the metropolitan
sanitary district.



(Ord. O-26-70, passed 9-15-70; amend. Ord. O-23-71, passed 3-19-7`; amend.
Ord. O-33-71, passed 4-30-71)



§ 52.33  DISCHARGES PROHIBITED AT CERTAIN LOCATIONS.



   No person, firm, corporation, or other entity shall discharge any
sanitary waste or industrial waste water into any storm sewer or drainage
facility constructed as part of the Cal Sag Road improvement, which
improvement runs between U.S. Route 45 and 135th Street, and a portion of
which passes through the city.



(Ord. 0-06-85, passed 3-5-85)  Penalty, see § 52.99



§ 52.34  WATER AND SEWER TAP-IN AND INSPECTION FEE.



   (A)   Whenever a request is made for a resubdivision of property
within the city, that request shall be accompanied by a $50 water and sewer
tap-in fee covering the cost of inspecting the subject property.



   (B)   All subsequent inspections which may be made of that property
in connection with the resubdivision shall result in payment by the property
owner to the city of $50.



(Ord. 87-50, passed 11-17-87)



EXTRANEOUS FLOWS



§ 52.35  PURPOSE OF SUBCHAPTER.



   It is the purpose of this subchapter that the entry of extraneous flows
into the sanitary sewer system be prohibited and be discontinued, where such
entry may be occurring accidentally or knowingly. Extraneous flows are those
flows, other than domestic sewage or industrial waste, consisting of ground
waters, surface waters, storm waters, and other drainage or clear waters.



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80)  Penalty, see § 52.99(B)



§ 52.36  UNLAWFUL DISCHARGES.



   It shall be unlawful to discharge or cause to be discharged, directly
or indirectly, into the sanitary sewer system of the city any ground waters,
surface waters, storm waters or any other extraneous flows.



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80)  Penalty, see § 52.99(B)



§ 52.37  UNLAWFUL CONNECTIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to make a connection or to maintain or
operate a connection which serves any home, building or any other
establishment, premises or facilities, and which contributes, directly or
indirectly, to the sanitary sewer of the city, any ground waters, surface
waters, storm waters or any other extraneous flows.



   (B)   All drains or connections designed or intended to receive and
discharge ground waters, surface waters, storm waters, and other drainage,
shall be considered illegal connections if they discharge directly or
indirectly into the sanitary sewer system. Such illegal connections include,
but are not limited to, roof drains, downspouts, footing drains, areaway
drains, drain tiles and sump pumps used to collect and discharge same, yard
drains, catch basins and inlets, and these connections shall not be allowed
to discharge directly or indirectly into the sanitary sewers. 



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80)  Penalty, see § 52.99(B)



§ 52.38  MAINTENANCE.



   The proper maintenance and operation of a building service sewer, house
connection or sanitary sewer line to the point of connection to the municipal
sanitary sewer system shall be the responsibility of the owner of the
premises served by the sanitary sewer pipes.  Maintenance means keeping the
sanitary sewer connection, sewer lines or other sewer facilities or
structures in satisfactory working condition and good state of repair
(including but not limited to preventing any obstruction or extraneous
materials or flows from entering the facilities, protecting the facilities
from any damage and keeping them free from defects or malfunctions), and
making necessary provisions and taking necessary precautions to assure that
the sewer facilities are at all times capable of satisfactorily performing
the services and adequately discharging the functions and producing the final
results and purposes the facilities are intended to perform, discharge or
produce.



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80)  Penalty, see § 52.99(B)



§ 52.39  DISCHARGE.



   All downspouts or roof drains shall discharge onto the ground or be
connected to storm sewer, drainage ditches or drainage system.  Footing
drains shall be connected to sump pumps and discharge shall be made into
storm sewers, drainage ditches or drainage system.  Sump pumps installed to
receive and discharge ground waters or other storm waters shall be connected
to the storm sewer or discharge into a drainage ditch or drainage system. 
Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge floor drain flow, laundry tubs
or other sanitary sewage shall be connected to the sanitary sewers.  A sump
pump shall be used for one function only, either the discharge of storm
waters, or the discharge of sanitary sewage, including laundry water. 



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-l-80)  Penalty, see § 52.99(B)



§ 52.40  PROGRAM FOR ELIMINATION OF EXTRANEOUS FLOWS.



   (A)   Because of their almost instantaneous impact, their injurious
results, substantial contributions, and relative ease of correction, the city
will institute a priority program for the elimination of extraneous flows
entering into the sanitary sewer system through downspouts, roof drains and
other visible or outside connections which are connected directly or
indirectly to the sanitary sewer system.



   (B)   Within a period of 60 days starting in mid 1980, and at no
expense to the property owner, the city will make visual outside inspections
of all properties within the city with specific attention to downspouts, roof
drains and other visible or outside connections, and, if requested by the
property owner, the city will enter into the premises and make or assist in
the making of additional inspections of the premises to ascertain if illegal
connections are present. Upon completion of the visual outside or inside
inspection, the city will advise the property owner in writing if any illegal
connections are observed, and will advise on the manner of corrections for
compliance with the provisions of this subchapter.  After the corrections
are made the city will, at no expense to the owner, make further inspections
of the corrections to insure compliance with this subchapter.



   (C)   Within 30 days after notice to the property owner by the city
of the presence of illegal connections, the property owner shall, at his
expense, disconnect all illegal connections observed and all discharges of
extraneous flows into the sanitary sewer system, directly or indirectly,
shall be discontinued. 



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80) Penalty, see § 52.99(B)



§ 52.41  ADDITIONAL INSPECTIONS.



   In addition to visual inspections on the outside or the inside of the
premises as indicated in § 52.40, the city may make other tests and
inspections of the municipal sewer systems as it deems necessary in order to
locate such illegal connections and sources of extraneous flows as may
exist.  The city, at its option, may also invoke other legal powers vested
in it or implied by the statutes for the protection of the health and welfare
of the public, or institute such legal action as it deems necessary to
discover and order the disconnection of any illegal connections that may
exist. 



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80)



§ 52.42  COMPLIANCE WITH METROPOLITAN WATER RECLAMATION DISTRICT OF GREATER
CHICAGO; TERMINATION OF SERVICE.



   Termination of water service pursuant to § 50.25 for a violation of
those rules or any section of Chapter 52.



   (A)   It shall be a violation of this Chapter 52 for any premises
served by the Sanitary Sewerage System to be in violation of the rules and
regulations of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago
or of any provisions of this Chapter 52.



   (B)   In the event any premises are maintained in violation of any
such rules and regulations of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of
Greater Chicago or of any section of this Chapter 52, the water service to
such premises may be terminated pursuant to § 50.25.



(Ord. 90-41, passed 12-4-90)



REGISTRATION AND LICENSE FOR THE COLLECTION AND TRANSPORTATION OF GREASE TRAP
SLUDGE FROM GREASE TRAPS



§ 52.55  DEFINITIONS.




   For purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have
the meanings prescribed:





   GREASE TRAP.  A constructed device, and its appurtenance surfaces and
working parts, with the function of removing fats, oils and grease from
wastewaters before such wastewaters are discharged to city sewers.





   GREASE TRAP SLUDGE.  The solid, lighter than water fraction of
wastewaters from the handling, processing, preparation, cooking or
consumption of food that are discharged to a pretreatment unit or device
commonly referred to as a grease trap. The principal components of grease
trap sludge are fats, oils and grease.





   PROHIBITED CONCENTRATION.  Discharges of wastewaters from a grease
trap in the city shall not exceed 250 mg/L (total) of fats, oils and grease
in any sample, whether obtained as a composite or grab sample.





(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)




§ 52.56  REQUIRED INSTALLATION AND USE OF GREASE TRAPS.




   Each person or operating facility within the city, other that a private
residence, which will be used for the manufacture, processing or preparation
of food or food products must install and use, at its own expense, a grease
trap adequate to prevent a discharge of grease trap sludge to city sewers in
prohibited concentrations.  Any such facility in operation without such
grease trap on the date of enactment of this subchapter shall be required to
install and use such a grease trap within 12 months of enactment.





(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)




§ 52.57  REQUIRED MAINTENANCE OF GREASE TRAPS.




   (A)   Each person who owns or operates a grease trap as required by
§ 52.56 of this subchapter shall cause collected or trapped grease trap
sludge to be cleaned and removed from such device on a periodic basis, and
delivered to a facility authorized to use, treat or dispose of such material.
Such cleanout and removal shall be accomplished on a monthly basis unless the
city, upon receipt of proof from the owner or operator or on the basis of its
own inspection of the grease trap, determines that a less or more frequent
maintenance schedule is required to achieve the purposes of this subchapter
and to minimize the discharge of a prohibited concentration of grease trap
sludge.





   (B)   No grease trap sludge removed from a grease trap may be
offered to a person for transportation nor transported off the site where
such materials were collected except by a hauler licensed as required by §
52.60.





(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)




§ 52.58  PROHIBITION OF DISCHARGE OF FATS, OILS AND GREASE.




   (A)   No person shall discharge a prohibited concentration of grease
trap sludge into city sewers, from a facility required to install and use a
grease trap.





   (B)   No person shall reintroduce or deposit into the city sewers
any grease trap sludge which have been removed from the sewer system by
grease traps.





   (C)   No person shall deposit or discharge into the city sewers any
grease trap sludge which have been removed from a grease trap or sewer system
outside the city.





(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)




§ 52.59  PROHIBITION ON INTRODUCTION OF ENZYMES AND EMULSIFIERS.



   No person shall introduce, nor allow the introduction of physical,
chemical or biological agents into grease traps for the purpose of
re-suspending, dissolving, emulsifying or rendering soluble any grease trap
sludge removed from a waste water by such grease traps and reintroducing them
into the city sewer system.




(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)




§ 52.60  PERMITTING OF GREASE HAULERS.



   No person shall own or operate a vehicle used to transport  grease
trap sludge collected from a grease trap unless that vehicle is validly
permitted by, and is inscribed with such permit numbers issued by, either (a)
the Illinois Department of Agriculture pursuant to ILCS Ch. 225, Act 610, §
9.1 and Act 610, § 9.2 (a scrap and grease permit); or (b) the city,
pursuant to this section.  Applications for city vehicle permits shall be
accepted only from the record owner of the vehicles, and shall include such
owner's name and address, the location of the facility at which each such
vehicle is garaged, the number, type and registration number of vehicles to
be used by the proposed permittee and sworn declaration of the facilities to
which such grease trap sludge are to be delivered for use, treatment or
disposal. Permits issued hereunder shall be renewed annually and shall expire
on December 31. A fee of $100.00 per vehicle shall accompany each application
for an original or renewal permit.




(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)




§ 52.61  REQUIREMENT FOR GREASE HAULERS.



   (A)   No person may cause or allow the transportation of grease trap
sludge away from the grease trap at which such materials were collected
unless such materials are accompanied by a shipping document containing the
information prescribed in division (B). No specific form of shipping document
is required, unless the city prescribes and publishes public notice of the
requirement to use a particular form.



   (B)   Each shipping document shall contain at a minimum the
following information:



      (1)   The name and telephone number of the owner or operator
of the grease trap from which the grease trap sludge were collected, the
street address of the grease trap, the volume of fats, oils or grease and any
associated water removed, the legible signature of an authorized
representative of the owner or operator and the date of the materials
removal; and



      (2)   The name, address, city of Department of Agriculture
permit number, and telephone number of the transporter, an acknowledgment of
receipt of the collected materials, the legible signature of an authorized
representative of the transporter, and the date of collection; and



      (3)   The name, street address, and telephone  number of the
facility to which the material was delivered for use, treatment or disposal,
the date and time of delivery, the volume delivered, and the legible
signature of an authorized representative of the transporter verifying the
delivery.



   (C)   The grease trap owner or operator and transporter shall each
retain a copy of the shipping document for a minimum of two years; and shall
produce the documents upon request of the city or the owner or operator of
the sewage treatment works to which the city's sewers are tributary.



(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)



§ 52.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any violation of this chapter not otherwise provided for shall
be punished by a fine of not less than $10 and not more than $200.  Each day
of violation shall be deemed as a separate violation of this chapter, and in
addition thereto, the city shall not issue permits of any kind within its
jurisdiction to the offending party until the party has complied with the
provisions of this chapter.



('69 Code, § 20-103)



   (B)   Failure on the part of the property owner to comply with the
provisions of §§ 52.35 through 52.42 shall be considered a violation which,
upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not less than $1,000 and, in
addition thereto, the additional sum of $100 for each day that such violation
continues.  Each day shall constitute a separate violation. 



(Ord. 0-05-80, passed 4-1-80; amend. Ord. O-28-93, passed 8-3-93)




   (C)   Penalties for §§ 52.55 through 52.61.





      (1)   Any person violating §§ 52.56, 52.58(B), 52.58(C) or
52.60 shall be liable to civil penalty of not less than $50 nor more than
$500 for such violation. Each day the violation continues shall be a separate
and distinct offense.





      (2)   Any person violating §§ 52.57(A), 52.58(A), 52.59 or
52.61(C) shall be liable to a civil penalty of not less than $50 nor more
than $500 for such violation. Each day the violation continues shall be a
separate and distinct offense.





      (3)   Any person violating §§ 52.57(B), 52.58(A), 52.61(A),
or 52.61(B) shall be liable to a civil





penalty of not less than $50 nor more than $500 for such violation. Each day
the violation continues shall be a separate and distinct offense.





      (4)   Any person who knowingly makes a false material
statement or representation in any writing required to be prepared under
subchapter §§ 52.55 through 52.61 shall be liable to a civil penalty of not
less than $50 nor more than $500 for each submission.





(Ord. O-1-97, passed 1-7-97)
