FENCES



§ 150.80  APPLICATION FOR BUILDING PERMIT; FEE.



   It shall be unlawful to construct or erect a fence in the city without
first having secured a building permit therefor by application duly filed at
the office of the city clerk on a form duly prescribed and furnished for such
purpose.  A $40 fee shall be deposited with the clerk at the time the
application is filed.  If the permit is not granted, the fee shall be
returned to the applicant.  Each applicant shall submit a sketch or diagram
of the proposed fence structure, indicating all dimensions thereon and its
proposed location upon the property.



(Ord. O-45-71, passed 10-5-71; amend. Ord. 89-57, passed 12-5-89; amend. Ord.
O-27-98, passed 6-16-98; amend. Ord. O-05-04, passed 1-20-04)



§ 150.81  FENCES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.



   (A)   Fences in residentially zoned areas may be constructed of
wire, wood, brick, invisible fences or equivalent type, or metal or
combinations thereof, and shall be installed in concrete, and shall be so
anchored or buttressed as to resist a wind force of 100 m.p.h.



   (B)   Fences may only be located on the side yard or rear yard of a
residential lot and are not to extend beyond the front line of the home
located thereon, and further, shall not be more than six feet in height,
including lights and other fixtures or accessories.



   (C)   Variations.  Requests for variations from the provisions and
requirements of this chapter relating to fences shall be governed by the
procedure applicable to variations from the requirements of the city council.



   (D)   Front yard fences of any type relative to the front half or
street side of any property shall not be constructed in any residential area.



   (E)   No fence, boundary-line or otherwise, shall be constructed,
which will obstruct or tend to obstruct the view of vehicular traffic on any
given street or street intersection.



   (F)   Boundary-line fences must be so constructed as to present the
finished side to the adjacent property owner or owners.



   (G)   All fences shall be located upon the lot lines and not in the
front yard of the house.  The Building Commissioner is authorized to make
discretionary decisions in regards to the location of fences in order to
preserve any existing landscape improvements at the time of the erection of a
fence, including moving the fence off the lot line, but only so far as to
protect and preserve the existing landscape improvements or to fence or gate
the area between a residence and detached garage to prevent blocking the
driveway from the garage door.



   (H)   The above and foregoing regulations shall not apply to
protective fences of an unpermanent nature which are erected for the purpose
of closing off areas undergoing building construction. Temporary fence
structures shall be removed upon completion of construction activity or
within 12 months from the completed erection, whichever is less in computing
the time, and no permit shall be necessary.



   (I)   The city is not responsible for any damage to
electrical/invisible fences installed in the public right-of- way from city
improvement or work.



(Ord. O-45-71, passed 10-5-71; amend. Ord. O-21-78, passed 8-1-78; amend.
Ord. O-21-81, passed 8-18-81; amend. Ord. 88-36, passed 5-17-88; amend. Ord.
89-56, passed 11-21-89; amend. Ord. O-33-06, passed 9-19- 06; amend. Ord.
O-05-14, passed 3-4-14; amend. Ord. O-18-15, passed 5-5-15)



§ 150.82  FENCES IN AREAS ZONED OTHER THAN RESIDENTIAL.



   (A)   Fences in areas other than residential zoning shall be of wire
mesh or cyclone type, masonry or equivalent, or painted board, and shall be
set back no less than 3 feet from the front or street side property line or
lines.



   (B)   These fences shall not exceed 8 feet in height.  The top 2
feet of the fences may be finished in barbed-wire type material.



   (C)   The fence shall be so anchored or buttressed as to resist a
wind force of 100 m.p.h.



   (D)   No fence shall be erected which will obstruct or tend to
obstruct the view of vehicular traffic on any given street or street
intersection.



   (E)   Building construction for activities other than residential
shall hereafter provide a painted board fence of not less than 6 feet in
height or more than 8 feet in height at the rear of the premises at locations
where the alleyways abut residential properties.  Doors or gates in the
fences are permissible for ingress and egress of persons or vehicles.



   (F)   General advertising on fences is prohibited unless the same
pertains to the operation of the business itself for identification
purposes. 



(Ord. O-45-71, passed 10-5-71)



§ 150.83  BUILDING COMMISSIONER TO ACT ON APPLICATION.



   The building commissioner shall examine the application of each
applicant to determine whether or not the specifications, exhibits, and
information therein contained conform with the provisions of §§ 150.60
through 150.68.  He shall mark each application "Approved" or "Denied."



(Ord. O-45-71, passed 10-5-71)



§ 150.84  BUILDING COMMISSIONER TO MAKE FINAL INSPECTION.



   The building commissioner is authorized and instructed, among his other
duties, to make a final inspection of the fence construction at such time as
the same is completed by the builder, to ascertain and determine the
applicant's compliance with the detailed representation he has made in the
body of his application.  It shall be the building commissioner's duty to
inform the applicant of any discrepancies contrary to the same.  Should the
applicant fail to comply after notice, the building commissioner shall report
the discrepancies in writing and deposit the same with the city clerk for
such further action as may be necessary. 



(Ord. 0-45-71, passed 10-5-71)



§ 150.85  CONFLICTING WITH SWIMMING POOL ORDINANCE.



   Nothing in §§ 150.80 through 150.85 shall be so construed as to
conflict with or limit the effectiveness of any fence provision contained in
the code, relating to swimming pools.  The provision of Chapter 154 shall
take precedence over §§ 150.80 through 150.85. 



(Ord. O-49-71, passed 11-16-71)



§ 150.86  VARIATIONS.



   Requests for variations from the provisions and requirements of §§
150.80 through 150.85, relating to fences, shall be governed by the procedure
applicable to variations from the requirements of the zoning ordinance,
Chapter 153, except that requirements for variations from the provisions of
§ 150.81(G) shall be reviewed by the plan and zoning committee of the
council and approved by city council.



(Ord. O-49-71, passed 11-16-71; amend. Ord. 89-24, passed 6-6-89)



SATELLITE ANTENNA DISHES



§ 150.90  APPLICATION FOR BUILDING PERMIT; FEE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to construct, erect, install, maintain,
alter, or enlarge a satellite antenna dish, satellite earth station,
satellite receiving dish, or any other device known by any other name,
designed to receive or intercept television broadcasts relayed by microwave
signals from earth-orbiting communications satellites without first obtaining
a building permit therefor by application to the building commissioner. 
Each application shall be accompanied by a plan, drawn to scale, showing dish
location, landscaping and compliance with all other provisions of the city
zoning and building regulations, and a permit fee of $50.



   (B)   Non-residential districts.



      (1)   The erection, installation or maintenance of satellite
antenna dishes for no-residential districts shall be as determined by the
Building Commissioner.



      (2)   Application for such installation shall be made to the
Building Commissioner.



(Ord. 36-85, passed 10-14-85; amend. Ord. 88-62, passed 10-4-88; amend. Ord.
91-32, passed 12-3-91)  Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.91  CONDITIONS.



   The erection, installation, or maintenance of satellite antenna dishes
of the type covered herein must be made in accordance with the following
conditions:



   (A)   Residential districts.



      (1)   The maximum diameter of any such dish shall not exceed
ten feet.



      (2)   All such dishes shall be of the open ribs, rim, and wire
mesh type construction.



      (3)   No such dish shall be located in the front yard area or
within any side yard or within any rear yard setback from the rear lot line
of any property.



      (4)   No such dish shall be located on, mounted, or attached
to any portion of any building or structure situated on the property.



      (5)   A dish not exceeding ten feet in diameter, ground or
pole mounted, may be located in the rear yard, but no closer than ten feet
from the principal building, and shall be no higher than a roof line
established by that building or 27 feet above grade, whichever is less.  The
ground mounted dishes shall be landscaped, including berming, hedging, or
fencing as approved by the building commissioner, and shall be of a neutral
color so as to render them compatible with the surrounding neighborhood in
appearance and character.



      (6)   No more than one such dish shall be installed or located
on any lot or parcel and that dish shall supply television broadcast to that
identified lot only.



   (B)   Non-residential districts.



      (1)   The erection, installation or maintenance of satellite
antenna dishes for non-residential districts shall be as determined by the
mayor and the city council.



      (2)   Applications for such installations shall be made to the
building commissioner who shall make a recommendation to the planning and
zoning committee of the city council which shall, in turn, make its
recommendation to the mayor and the city council who shall review and act
upon such recommendation.



(Ord. 36-85, passed 10-14-85; amend. Ord. 87-51, passed 12-1-87)  Penalty,
see § 150.999



§ 150.92  BUILDING COMMISSIONER TO ACT ON APPLICATION.



   The building commissioner shall examine the application of each
applicant to determine whether or not the specifications, exhibits, and
information therein contained conform with the provisions of §§ 150.90 and
150.91.  He shall mark each application "Approved" or "Denied."



(Ord. 36-85, passed 10-14-85)



§ 150.93  BUILDING COMMISSIONER TO MAKE FINAL INSPECTION.



   The building commissioner is authorized and instructed, among his other
duties, to make a final inspection of the dish construction at such time as
the same is completed by the builder, to ascertain and determine the
applicant's compliance with the detailed representation he has made in the
body of his application.  It shall be the building commissioner's duty to
inform the applicant of any discrepancies contrary to the same.  Should the
applicant fail to comply after notice, the building commissioner shall report
the discrepancies in writing and deposit the same with the city clerk for
such further action as may be necessary.



(Ord. 36-85, passed 10-14-85)



§ 150.94  VARIATIONS.



   Requests for variations from the provisions and requirements of §§
150.90 through 150.93, relating to satellite antenna dishes, shall be
governed by the procedure applicable to variations from the requirements of
the zoning ordinance, Chapter 153.



(Ord. 36-85, passed 10-14-85)



§ 150.95  INSPECTION OF HOMES AND HOME IMPROVEMENTS IN RESIDENTIAL UNITS
OCCUPIED BY SENIOR CITIZENS.



   At the request of any resident of 65 years of age or older, the
Building Commissioner shall cause an inspection to be made of any residential
unit, any proposed improvement to that unit (including the costs thereof), or
any improvement in process or completed in or about that unit.  This
inspection shall include advice to the resident as to the necessity for any
improvements, the reasonable costs of any proposed or completed improvements,
the quality and acceptability of any workmanship of any completed
improvement, whether or not the contractor who is proposed to perform any
improvement is licensed by the city and whether any complaints have been
lodged with the city regarding the work of any such contractor.  This
service shall be performed at no cost for any party requesting the same age
65 or older.



(Ord. 93-04, passed 2-16-93)



PERSONAL WIRELESS COMMUNICATION FACILITIES



§ 150.100  LOCATION OF FACILITIES TO BE REGULATED.




   The city has received inquiries regarding possible locations for
personal wireless communication facilities and wishes to establish
regulations to ensure the appropriate location of such facilities with the
least amount of impact on existing and future development, particularly
residential areas of the City of Palos Heights.




(Ord. O-35-98, passed 8-4-98)



§ 150.101  DEFINITIONS.




   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.





   ANTENNA.  Any exterior apparatus or apparatuses at a fixed location
designed for telephonic, radio, data, Internet, or other communications
through the sending and/or receiving of electromagnetic waves, including
equipment attached to a tower or building for the purpose of providing
personal wireless services as defined herein.





   ANTENNA HEIGHT.  The vertical distance measured from the lowest grade
level within five feet of the base of an antenna support structure to the
highest point of the structure even if said highest point is an antenna.





   PERSONAL WIRELESS SERVICE/PERSONAL WIRELESS SERVICE FACILITIES.  As
defined in Title 47, United States Code, Section 332 (c)(7)(C), as amended
now or in the future.





   TOWER, FREESTANDING.  A structure that is designed and constructed
primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including
self-supporting lattice towers, guy towers, or monopole towers.  The term
encompasses personal wireless service facilities,  radio transmission
towers, microwave towers, common-carrier towers, cellular telephone towers or
personal communications services towers, alternative tower structures, and
similar structures.




(Ord. O-35-98, passed 8-4-98)



§ 150.102  REGULATIONS AND PERSONAL WIRELESS SERVICE FACILITIES.




   (A)   Locations.





      (1)   Subject to site plan approval, any such personal
wireless service facilities shall be considered a permitted use if located
either on (1) an existing freestanding tower and/or (2) on city-owned
property pursuant to an agreement with the city and further provided that
such facilities are so designed so as to allow and encourage co-location by
other potential users.  Prior to construction of such facilities, the
petitioner must receive site plan approval from the Plan Commission pursuant
to the site plan review process.





      (2)   A special use may be requested for any use that
satisfies the definition of personal wireless service facility, as defined
herein, provided that the proposed location satisfies any one of the criteria
listed below:





         (a)   Personal wireless service facilities attached to
existing freestanding towers used for other personal wireless services.





         (b)   The proposed location of the personal wireless
service facilities is within the M-Manufacturing District (a) is not within
1000 feet of a residential district or (b) is separated from residential
districts by a freeway or principal arterial as defined by the City of Palos
Heights Comprehensive Plan.





         (c)   The proposed location of the personal wireless
service facilities is attached to an existing building or structure within a
non-residential district.





   (B)   Maximum Height for Personal Wireless Service Facilities.  An
applicant for approval of a personal wireless facility shall demonstrate that
the personal wireless facilities do not exceed the minimum height required to
function satisfactorily.  Under any circumstances, personal wireless
facilities shall not exceed the following height restrictions unless
otherwise specifically approved by the Mayor and City Council.





      (1)   The maximum height of a freestanding tower shall not
exceed 100 feet; provided, however, that an applicant requesting a
freestanding tower shall demonstrate that the tower/antenna is the minimum
height required to function satisfactorily.





      (2)   If mounted on the roof of an existing building or
structure, the height of an antenna shall not exceed 10 feet above the height
of the existing structure; provided, however, that the maximum height may be
increased if (1) the radio signal would be impaired or blocked off if the
antenna was located near the middle of the roof and (2) the City Council
determines that it is preferable to locate the antenna at a location other
than near the edge of the roof.





      (3)   An antenna attached to the side of a building,
structure, or tower shall not extend above the roof of the building,
structure, or tower; provided, however, if the radio signal is distorted or
blocked by structures located on the roof of the building, the city may allow
the height to exceed the height of the building structure or tower in its
discretion.





   (C)   Screening and Site Location for Personal Wireless Service
Facilities Attached to Freestanding Towers.





      (1)   Support structures and antennas shall have a
non-contrasting blue, gray or similar color that minimizes their visibility
and is compatible with the surrounding landscape.





      (2)   Personal wireless service facilities should be
architecturally compatible with the surrounding buildings and land uses or
otherwise integrated, through location and design, to blend in with the
existing characteristics of the site to the extent practical.





      (3)   Personal wireless service facilities attached to a
free-standing tower shall not be located between a principal building and a
street or in the front yard of the lot in question.  Such free-standing
tower shall be located adjacent to the rear wall of the principal building
unless (1) it is shown that an alternate location results in more effective
screening or blending of the tower into the surrounding landscape or (2) the
location has the affect of interfering with the operations of the principal
use on the subject property; provided, however, such personal wireless
service facilities nevertheless may not be located between the principal
building and the street or in the front yard of the lot in question.





   (D)   Screening and Site Location for Personal Wireless Service
Facilities Attached to Existing Buildings or Structures.





      (1)   Personal wireless service facilities may be attached to
the wall or roof of a building subject to height restrictions in division (B)
of this section.  Such facilities shall not be attached to the front wall of
a building unless it can be shown that other locations are not feasible and
that the facilities shall be made to effectively blend into the architecture
of the building.





      (2)   Personal wireless service facilities and their support
structures attached to an existing building or structure shall be of a color
identical to the building or that maximizes the blending of the facilities
and support structures into the architecture of the building or structure.





      (3)   Personal wireless service facilities and their support
structures attached to an existing building or structure shall not extend
more than 24 inches beyond the wall of such building or structure.





   (E)   Screening and Site Location for Ground Level Equipment and
Buildings.





      (1)   Personal wireless service facilities may be attached to
the wall or roof of a building subject to the height restrictions set forth
in division (B) of this section.





      (2)   Landscaping consisting of shrubs and similar materials
shall be provided surrounding the foundation of ground level buildings,
structures, and fences subject to the review and approval of the Building
Commissioner.





      (3)   Ground level buildings and structures shall be designed
and located to blend with the existing architecture and landscaping of the
subject property and the surrounding area.  Masonry facades shall be
required for such buildings or structures unless otherwise allowed as a
condition of the special use approval.





      (4)   Fencing may be provided as a condition of the special
use approval for the purpose of enclosing and screening freestanding towers
or antennas and their support facilities.  Such fencing shall comply with
the requirements for residential fences contained in this subchapter, except
as specifically authorized by conditions for approval of a special use.





   (F)   Compliance with Governmental and other Safety Regulations.





      (1)   The applicant shall demonstrate that the proposed
antennas and support structure are safe and that surrounding areas will not
be negatively affected by support structure failure, falling ice, or other
debris.  All support structures shall be fitted with anti-climbing devices,
as approved by the manufacturers.





      (2)   All towers and antennas shall comply with the current
standards and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, the
Federal Aviation Administration, and any other agency of the federal
government with the authority to regulate towers and antennas.





      (3)   Upon application and approval, the Building Commissioner
shall issue a permit prior to construction of any tower or antenna.  Said
permit shall verify that towers and antennas are constructed in compliance
with applicable city building codes and any requirements of the Electronic
Industries Standards and the Federal Communications Commission, as well as
the provisions herein.





   (G)   Co-Location and Location on Existing Structures Preferred. 
In order to minimize adverse visual impacts associated with the proliferation
of towers, co-location of antennas by more than one provider on existing or
new towers and location of antennas on existing buildings or structures shall
take precedence over the construction of new, freestanding towers.  If a
new, freestanding tower is proposed, special use approval shall not be
granted unless the applicant demonstrates compliance with the following:





      (1)   A diligent effort has been made to locate the antenna on
an existing structure and that due to valid considerations including physical
constraints and economic or technological feasibility, no other appropriate
location is available.





      (2)   Covenants shall be recorded which require that the
applicant allow, on a commercially reasonable basis, other providers of
personal wireless service facilities and other antennas to co-locate on the
proposed freestanding tower, where such co-location is technologically
feasible.





      (3)   The site plan for the construction of a new,
freestanding tower shall delineate an area, either on site or on adjacent
property, near the base of the tower to be used for the placement of
additional equipment and buildings for other users.  To the extent that the
site for the new free-standing tower is adequate to allow co-location on such
site, the applicant must allow, on a commercially reasonable basis, other
providers to locate on site.





   (H)   Abandonment of Towers or Antennas.  In the event the use of a
tower or antenna is discontinued for a period of 60 consecutive days, the
tower or antenna shall be deemed to be abandoned.  The Building Commissioner
shall determine the date of abandonment based on documentation required from
the tower owner/operator or other appropriate sources.  Upon abandonment,
the tower owner/operator shall have an additional 60 days within which to:





      (1)   Reactivate the use of the tower either by said
owner/operator or transfer of the tower to another owner/operator for such
use within the aforesaid 60-day period.  Transfer of the tower to another
owner/operator shall not require special use approval provided use of the
tower is re-activated within the 60-day period and that the use of the tower
complies with all conditions of the original special use approval and the
terms of this subchapter.





      (2)   Dismantle and remove the tower at which time any special
use shall become null and void.





      (3)   Request approval from the City Council to allow the
abandoned tower or antenna to remain for a specified period of time.  If
said approval is granted the tower shall be reactivated or removed within the
time period approved by the City Council as per the regulations herein.




(Ord. O-35-98, passed 8-4-98)



COMMERCIAL TENTS



§ 150.110 PERMIT REQUIRED FOR TENTS.



   (A)   A permit shall be obtained for the erection of any tent to be
utilized for commercial and/or retail purposes within the city in accordance
with the provisions of this section.



   (B)   Application shall be submitted to the Building Commissioner on
the form provided by the City. The application shall be accompanied by the
applicable fee as set forth in § 150.113 and a certificate of liability
insurance in the amount of not less than $1,000,000.



   (C)   The application, fee, and certificate of insurance must be
submitted no later than 30 days prior to the erection of the tent.



(Ord. O-14-04, passed 4-6-04)



§ 150.111  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   TENT. A portable shelter usually of canvas or like material stretched
over a supporting frame work of poles, ropes and pegs.



(Ord. O-14-04, passed 4-6-04)



§ 150.112  EXEMPTIONS.



   (A)   This subchapter shall not be applicable to tents erected as
part of any city sponsored event, carnivals and festivals, or residential
use, however, other inspection fees may be required as set forth in city
ordinances.



   (B)   Tents with a size of 400 square feet or less are also exempt
from obtaining a permit hereunder.



   (C)   Upon proper evidence of a not-for-profit corporation, the fee
may be waived.



(Ord. O-14-04, passed 4-6-04)



§ 150.113 PERMIT REVIEW.



   The Building Commissioner or his designate representative shall review
all permit applications including all specifications for the tent, its use
and location to ensure that the use, site and specifications are reasonably
safe.



(Ord. O-14-04, passed 4-6-04)
