IN GENERAL




§ 152.01  OVERVIEW OF SUBDIVISION PROCESS.



   (A)   Pre-application.



      (1)   Subdivider.  Gathers information and data on existing
conditions; studies site suitability and development opportunity; discusses
financing, planning, and marketing with those interested; with his land
planner, develops a preliminary plan in sketch form, which is submitted to
the plan commission for advice and assistance.



      (2)   Plan commission.  Reviews preliminary plan and program
as they relate to the community master plan, design standards, and
improvement requirements; informs and discusses with subdivider the results
of review.



   (B)   Preliminary plat.



      (1)   Subdivider.  Arrives at preliminary conclusions.  If
he decides to continue, reaches tentative agreements or understandings with
those associated with him, and others concerned, such as the lender; prepares
a preliminary plat for submission with his application for conditional
approval.



      (2)   Plan commission.  Reviews application and preliminary
plat for conditional approval to determine conformity to subdivision
standards.  Grants conditional approval, subject to conditions agreed upon,
or disapproves.



   (C)   Final plat.



      (1)   Subdivider.  Stakes out the tract, or that portion to
be first subdivided, in accord with the preliminary plat as conditionally
approved; prepares final plat and submits it, with other required material
and documents, with application for approval by the plan commission.



      (2)   Plan commission.  Reviews application and grants
approval of final plat, or informs subdivider what is lacking to obtain
approval for recording.



      (3)   Subdivider.  Records the approved final plat and other
documents; proceeds with his development plans and program and thereafter his
sales of lots and houses.



Statutory reference:



   Power of plan commission in regard to subdivisions, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5,
§ 11-12-5



§ 152.02  TITLE.



   This chapter shall be known, cited, and referred to as the "Subdivision
Regulations of the City of Palos Heights, Illinois."



('69 Code, App. B, Article I)



§ 152.03  PURPOSE.



   This chapter is adopted to promote and protect the public health,
safety, morals, comfort, convenience, and the general welfare of the people;
to protect the character and maintain the stability of the city and
contiguous unincorporated territory; and to establish reasonable standards of
design and procedure for subdivisions and for resubdivisions within the city
and contiguous unincorporated territory. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 2.1)



§ 152.04  AUTHORITY.



   Authority for the administration of these regulations shall be and is
vested in the plan commission of the city.



('69 Code, App. B, § 2.2)



§ 152.05  JURISDICTION.



   These regulations shall be applicable to all subdivisions and
resubdivisions of land within the corporate limits of the city and contiguous
unincorporated territory not more than 1-1/2 miles beyond the corporate
limits of the city.



('69 Code, App. B, § 2.3)



§ 152.06  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall
have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.



   (A)   ALLEY.  A minor public right-of-way used primarily for
vehicular service access to the rear or side of properties.



   (B)   BUFFER PLANTING STRIP.  A narrow area planted with trees and
shrubs for screening purposes.



   (C)   BUILDING SETBACK LINE.  The line indicating the minimum
horizontal distance between the property line and buildings, either at the
front or side of the lot.



   (D)   CITY ENGINEER.  The person or firm designated by the city
council to serve as the city's engineering representative.



   (E)   CROSSWALKWAY.  A public right-of-way, 10 feet or more in
width through a block, which provides pedestrian access between streets.



   (F)   CUL-DE-SAC.  A short street having one end open to traffic
and being terminated at the other end by a vehicular turn-around.



   (G)   EASEMENT.  A grant by the owner of the use of a strip of land
by others for specific purposes.



   (H)   FINAL PLAT.  The final map or drawing on which the
subdivision plan is submitted to the plan commission for approval and which,
if approved by the plan commission and the city council, will be submitted to
the county recorder for recording.  The final plat must be prepared by a
registered Illinois land surveyor.



   (I)   IMPROVEMENTS, PUBLIC.  Any sanitary sewer, storm sewer,
drainage ditch, water main, roadway, parkway strip, sidewalk, planting strip,
crosswalkway, off-street parking areas, or other facility for which the city
may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation.



   (J)   LOTS.  A portion of a subdivision intended as a unit for
transfer of ownership or for development.



   (K)   MAJOR STREET PLAN.  A part of the official plan showing the
location and dimensions of principal thoroughfares.



   (L)   OFFICIAL PLAN.  The comprehensive plan or any portion thereof
made and adopted by the plan commission in accordance with the laws of the
state and the ordinances of the city, indicating the general or specific
locations recommended for streets, parks, public buildings, zoning districts,
and all other public improvements.  This chapter is a part of the official
plan.



   (M)   PARKWAY STRIP.  A strip of land between the roadway and the
sidewalk or sidewalk site.



   (N)   PLAN COMMISSION.  The plan commission of the city.



   (O)   PLAZA.  A tract of land consisting of a group of stores,
offices, or where approved, a combination thereof, formed by subdividing a
larger tract of land, or by combining a number of smaller tracts or lots. 
The development of the tract of land for the PLAZA shall conform insofar as
practical to the appropriate sections in Chapter 152.



   (P)   PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.  The preliminary map or drawing on which
the proposed layout of a subdivision is submitted to the plan commission for
consideration and tentative approval.



   (Q)   ROADWAY.  The portion of a street available for vehicular
traffic; where curbs are laid, the portion between curbs.



   (R)   SIDEWALK.  The portion of a street or crosswalkway, paved or
otherwise surfaced, intended for pedestrian use only.



   (S)   SIDE YARD.  An open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a
building located between the building and the side line of the lot, and
extending from the street line to the rear yard.



   (T)   STREET.  A public right-of-way having the primary purpose of
providing for vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent properties.



   (U)   STREET, MAJOR.  A street of great continuity, sometimes
called an arterial street or highway, which serves, or is intended to serve
as a principal trafficway for fast or heavy traffic.  Taken together, major
streets comprise the basic structure of the street system of the city and
surrounding area.



   (V)   STREET, MARGINAL ACCESS.  A street running parallel to, and
adjacent to or in the immediate vicinity of, a major street or highway, and
which has as its purpose the relief of the major street or highway from the
local service of abutting properties.



   (W)   STREET, MINOR.  A street which serves primarily for access to
the abutting properties.



   (X)   STREET, SECONDARY.  A street of considerable continuity,
sometimes called a collector street, which serves or is intended to serve as
a secondary trafficway and as a feeder between minor streets in a
neighborhood and one or more major streets.



   (Y)   SUBDIVIDER.  Any person, group, or corporation acting as a
unit, or any agent thereof, dividing or proposing to divide land so as to
constitute a subdivision as defined herein.



   (Z)   SUBDIVISION.  A division of any tract or parcel of land into
2 or more lots or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate
or future, of transfer of ownership, for building development, or, if a new
street is involved, and division of such parcel; provided, however, that the
division of land into parcels of more than 5 acres, not involving any change
in street lines or public easements, shall not be deemed a SUBDIVISION within
the meaning of this chapter.  The term includes resubdivision  and, where
appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to
the land subdivided. Application for a permit to construct 2 or more
dwellings on a parcel or tract of land or to construct one or more additional
dwellings on a parcel or tract of land where one or more dwellings already
exist shall be construed as a building development envisioning future
transfer of ownership, and shall be regarded as a subdivision.  For the
purpose of administration of this chapter, a parcel or tract of land shall be
deemed to have the boundaries and dimensions given in the current maps of
record of Cook County.



('69 Code, App. B, § 3.1; amend. Ord. O-9-81, passed 4-21-81)



PROCEDURE



§ 152.10  COMMENCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION.



   No grading, building, or construction of any kind relating to the
development of land within the definition of subdivision shall be started
except in accordance with this chapter.  Construction of improvements shall
be in accordance with §§ 152.100 through 152.117.  Construction of
buildings and dwellings shall be started only after issuance of building
permits, and no building permit shall be issued prior to recording of the
final plat. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.1)



§ 152.11  INFORMAL CONSIDERATION.



   While the subdivision plan is still in sketch form, the subdivider may
(and should) consult with the plan commission to determine conformity to the
official plan, including the major street plan, the zoning ordinance, and
compliance with this chapter and with other city ordinances not in conflict
with this chapter.  Within 15 days, the plan commission shall inform the
subdivider that the plans and data as submitted or as modified do or do not
meet the objectives of this chapter.  When the plan commission finds that
the plans and data do not meet the objectives of this chapter, it shall
express its reasons therefor.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.2)



§ 152.12  PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.



   Prior to the completion of the final survey of streets and lots of any
subdivision, and before any map of the subdivision is made in a form suitable
for recording, a preliminary layout (general subdivision plan), prepared in
accordance with the regulations set forth herein, shall be submitted to the
plan commission for its review and recommendations.  (Also see §§ 152.120
through 152.125.) In the event a proposed subdivision is one acre or less in
area, the subdivider shall have the right to dispense with the preparation of
the preliminary layout, and to proceed directly with submission of the final
plat.  In such case, the fee provided for in § 152.18 shall be payable upon
submission of the final plat.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.3)



§ 152.13  SUBMISSION OF PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.



   (A)   An application in writing in quadruplicate for the conditional
approval of the subdivision, together with ten prints of the preliminary
layout, shall be filed with the city clerk at least ten days prior to the
regular monthly meeting of the commission, to receive action at the meeting.



   (B)   The plan commission shall determine whether the preliminary
layout is in proper form, and shall not receive or consider the application
as filed until all documents are in accordance with the requirements set
forth herein. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.4)



§ 152.14  CONSIDERATION OF PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.



   The plan commission will study the preliminary layout in connection
with the official plan, the zoning code, and the topography of the area, and
will take into consideration the general requirements of the community, the
particular requirements of the neighborhood, and the best use of the land to
be subdivided.  Particular attention will be given to specific requirements
for parks, playgrounds, school sites, major streets, the adequacy of street
connections, and the suitability of the land for development.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.5)



§ 152.15  ACTION ON PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.



   The plan commission will communicate its conditional approval or its
disapproval, in writing, to the subdivider within 60 days of the time the
application for conditional approval is made, giving, in cases of conditional
approval, the specific changes which it will require in the preliminary
layout, and the character and extent of the required public improvements.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.6)



§ 152.16  CONDITIONAL APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.



   Conditional approval of the preliminary layout by the plan commission
does not constitute acceptance of the plat of the proposed subdivision,
acceptance of the proposed improvements, or the final agreement as to
improvement specifications or costs. It is to be considered only as an
approval of general layout design.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.7)



§ 152.17  EFFECTIVE PERIOD OF CONDITIONAL APPROVAL.



   Conditional approval of the preliminary layout shall be effective for a
maximum period of 12 months, except that submission, within this period, of a
final plat applying to a portion of the area covered by the preliminary
layout shall extend the effective period of conditional approval to a maximum
of 24 months from the date of submission of the preliminary layout.  If a
final plat has not been submitted to the plan commission within these time
limits, the preliminary layout shall again be submitted to the plan
commission for conditional approval.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.8)



§ 152.18  FEES.



   (A)   Conditions.  In order to cover the costs of examining the
layout, advertising, holding public hearings, and other expenses incidental
to approval of a subdivision, the subdivider shall pay a fee at the time of
application for the conditional approval of a preliminary layout.  The fee
shall be based on the estimated number of lots created.  At the time of
application for approval of the final plat, the required fee will be
recalculated on the basis of the actual number of lots created, and an
adjustment of the fee will be made.  The subdivider shall pay an additional
amount or shall receive a refund, if the adjusted fee differs from the
original fee.  There will be no refund of any portion of the fee if the
subdivider fails to apply for final approval of the subdivision. If, because
of the failure of the subdivider to submit a final plat within 12 months
after receiving conditional approval of a preliminary plat, it is necessary
to resubmit a preliminary plat for conditional approval, the subdivider shall
be required to pay the fee currently in effect at the time of resubmission.



   (B)   Amount. The fees for approval of a subdivision shall be $500
plus $25 per each newly created lot, and the cost of legal and engineering
fees incurred by the city.



   (C)   Separate charge.  All fees established by this section are in
addition to any sums paid to cover the costs of field inspection of
construction as required under the provisions of § 152.105.



('69Code, App. B, § 4.9) (Amend. Ord. O-12-07, passed 3-6-07)



§ 152.19  SUBMISSION OF FINAL PLAT.



   After approval of the preliminary layout by the plan commission, and
fulfillment of the required conditions, the subdivider shall apply in writing
to the chairman of the plan commission for approval of a final plat
(subdivision) plan.  The final plat shall conform substantially to the
preliminary layout given conditional approval.  The application shall be in
duplicate and shall be accompanied by the original inked plat on tracing
cloth or vellum, one reproducible and ten prints. Specifications for the plat
and for other documents to accompany the application are given in §§
152.120 through 152.125 of this chapter.  The final plat will not be
considered as submitted unless in agreement with specifications and
accompanied by the required documents. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.10)



§ 152.20  HEARING.



   The chairman of the plan commission will notify the subdivider or his
or her representative of the time and place at which he or she will be heard
on behalf of his or her application.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.11)



§ 152.21  ACTION ON FINAL PLAT.



   The plan commission will communicate in writing to the subdivider its
disapproval together with the reasons therefor, or notice of its
recommendation for approval, of the final plat, within 60 days after the date
on which the application for approval is made. If the plan commission
approves the final plat, the approval will be entered upon the tracings by
the signature of the chairman. The tracings shall then be transmitted to the
city council by the plan commission with the recommendation for council
approval.  Upon approval by council action, the tracing shall be signed by
the mayor and the city clerk, and affixed with the city seal.  Approval by
the council shall be by resolution setting forth all conditions upon which
approval is predicated.  The original tracing shall be recorded with the
appropriate officials of Cook County and, after recording a certified copy
and a signed reproducible, shall be returned to the city and filed by the
clerk. Appropriate notifications shall be given to the plan commission and
the subdivider, advising of council approval or disapproval. If the plat is
disapproved, the tracings are to be returned to the plan commission with a
statement of reasons.



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.12)



§ 152.22  EFFECTIVENESS OF FINAL APPROVAL.



   Approval of the final plat by the plan commission and the city council
shall be null and void if the plat is not acceptable for recording in the
office of the recorder of deeds of the county. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 4.13)



GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF ACCEPTABILITY



§ 152.30  CONFORMANCE TO OFFICIAL PLAN.



   The subdivision shall conform to the official plan or the existing
portions thereof, and shall not encroach upon areas designated in the
official plan for future public facilities. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 5.1)



§ 152.31  PROVISION FOR FUTURE SUBDIVISION.



   If a tract is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building
lots, the parcels shall be arranged to allow the opening of future streets
and logical further subdivisions. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 5.2)



§ 152.32  RESERVE STRIPS PROHIBITED.



   There shall be no reservation of strips of land that prevent or limit
access to land dedicated or intended to be dedicated to public use. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 5.3)



§ 152.33  BUFFER PLANTING STRIPS AND FENCES.



   Where a residential subdivision adjoins a railroad right-of-way, a
waterway, an industrial area, a business area, or other land use which would
have a depreciating effect on the residential use of the property, a buffer
planting strip 10 to 15 feet in width and suitably planted to form a screen
or fence may be required by the plan commission. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 5.4)



§ 152.34  BUILDING SITES.



   (A)   Every lot must contain a suitable building site and be able to
conform to the requirements of the building and zoning code for the erection
and location of building structures.



   (B)   No land will be approved for subdivision which is subject to
periodic flooding or which contains extremely poor drainage facilities. 
However, if the subdivider agrees to make improvements which will, in the
opinion of the city engineer, make the area completely safe for residential
occupancy and provide adequate drainage, the preliminary plan for subdivision
may be approved. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 5.5)



§ 152.35  TREES.



   (A)   Valuable large trees shall be preserved whenever possible. 
Where planting strips are provided with trees, the trees shall not be of a
low bushy species that might obstruct vision.  Trees or shrubs within a
40-foot radius from intersecting property lines at a street intersection
shall not have branches closer to the ground than 8 feet.



   (B)   Street trees having a trunk diameter (measured 12 inches above
the ground) of not less than 2 inches shall be planted along all streets
where trees do not exist, no more than 40 feet apart.  This requirement will
be satisfied, and it is preferable, if an equivalent number of trees of the
same size are planted in a naturalistic way in the front yards of the
abutting lots.  Only oak, honey locust, sycamore, Norway maple, ginkgo,
little leaf linden, or other long-lived shade trees, acceptable to the plan
commission, shall be planted. 



   (C)   All Oak, Honey, Locust, Sycamore, Norway Maple, Ginkgo, Little
Leaf Linden or other long-lived shade trees six inches or more in diameter,
outside the proposed buildable area, on site and in the public right-of-way
adjacent to the site, shall be protected from unreasonable damage by the use
of acceptable tree protection measures in accordance with a manner approved
by the Building Commissioner. Such protection shall remain in place during
construction, and removed as authorized by the Building Commissioner at the
completion of the construction.



   (D)   All trees on property adjacent to the site that are within ten
feet of a property line shared with the site, or that have a critical root
zone extending into the site, shall be protected from unreasonable damage by
the use of acceptable tree protection measures approved by the Building
Commissioner.



   (E)   For purposes of this section, acceptable tree protection
measures are those measures designed and implemented to reasonably limit the
damage to trees while enabling lawful construction activity consistent with
best construction practices as determined by the city. Acceptable tree
protection measures include:



      (1)   The installation of tree protection fencing along the
perimeter of the critical root zone located within construction site, which
shall remain in place during construction and removed only when construction
is complete or as authorized by the Building Commissioner. The fencing shall
be wood slat fencing, or such other fencing as approved by the Building
Commissioner. The proposed location of tree protection fencing shall be shown
on the demolition plan, redevelopment plan, or lot improvement plan. Tree
protection fencing shall be placed along the perimeter of the critical root
zone of each tree to the extent practical. Such fencing shall be contained
within the limits of the site and within the limits of the adjacent public
parkway. Such fencing shall not encroach on the public streets or sidewalks.



      (2)   Tree protection measures recommended by a professional
arborist and approved by the Building Commissioner to reasonably involve the
least amount of damage to trees.



('69 Code,App. B,§ 5.6)  (Amend. Ord. O-19-05, passed 5-17-05)



§ 152.36  NEIGHBORHOOD PLAN.



   If a suggested plan for the neighborhood or area in which the tract to
be subdivided is located has been made by the plan commission, the street
layout of the subdivision shall be in general conformance thereto. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 5.7)



§ 152.37  VARIATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   Variations and exceptions from the design and dimensional
standards and improvement requirements of this chapter may be made by the
plan commission in cases where, owing to exceptional conditions, there are
extreme difficulties or hardships in the way of carrying out the strict
letter of this chapter.  Resubdivision of a single lot of a platted block of
an old subdivision shall be considered as an exceptional condition meriting
departure from the strict letter of this chapter.  No variation or exception
shall be made that will be detrimental to the public welfare or that will
affect adversely the official plan.



   (B)   In no case shall a residential resubdivision of a lot or lots
be granted if one or more of the following conditions exist:



      (1)   The resubdivision will result in one or more lots less
than 11,000 square feet in area.  This section shall only apply to lots
which are subdivided after April 21, 1987, and shall not apply to existing
lots.



      (2)   The resubdivision will result in the creation of a side
yard or rear yard violation.



      (3)   The resubdivision will tend to damage or change the
nature or character, or be a detriment to the nature and character, of an
existing subdivision.



(Ord. O-50-71, passed 11-16-71; amend. Ord. 12-87, passed 4-21-87)



STREETS



§ 152.40  MAJOR STREETS.



   Wherever a subdivision embraces a major street, as shown on the major
street plan, the major street shall be platted in the location and of the
width indicated on the major street plan. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.1)



§ 152.41  SECONDARY STREETS.



   Secondary streets shall be included when it is apparent that sufficient
traffic will flow from the minor streets within the subdivision and that the
traffic will need to be channeled in control of the number of access points
to the major street.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.2)



§ 152.42  STREET LAYOUT.



   The street layout shall be devised for the most advantageous
development of the entire neighborhood area.  Where necessary to the
neighborhood pattern, existing principal streets in adjoining subdivisions
shall be continued, and shall be at least as wide as existing streets and in
alignment with them. The street layout shall provide for the future
projection of the principal streets into unsubdivided lands adjoining.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.3)



§ 152.43  MINOR STREETS.



   Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic
will be discouraged. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.4)



§ 152.44  RESERVE STRIPS.



   Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be prohibited except
where their control is definitely placed in the city under conditions
approved by the plan commission. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.5)



§ 152.45  STREET JOGS.



   Street jogs with center line offsets of less than 125 feet shall be
avoided.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.6)



§ 152.46  INTERSECTIONS.



   There shall be a minimum number of intersections of minor streets with
major streets. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.7)



§ 152.47  MARGINAL ACCESS STREETS.



   Where a subdivision has frontage on a major street, as shown on the
major street plan, or on a superhighway or other high volume trafficway, and
where it is not feasible to have the lots back to such high volume streets,
provision shall be made for marginal access streets.  These marginal access
streets shall be approximately parallel to and on each side of the major
street right-of-way and separated from the right-of-way by a strip of land at
least 10 feet wide.  Separation strips may be provided with screen planting,
but such planting shall be so placed that it does not obstruct vision at
intersections.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.8)



§ 152.48  STREETS FOR USES ADJACENT TO RAILROADS, WATERWAYS, OR MAJOR
STREETS.



   Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way,
waterway, or major street, the plan commission may require a street
approximately parallel to and on each side of the right-of-way, waterway, or
major street, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the
intervening land.  The distance shall be determined with due regard also for
the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.9)



§ 152.49  STREETS AT BUSINESS CENTERS.



   In front of areas zoned or designed for commercial use, the street
width and the roadway width shall be increased on the side or sides on which
the property for commercial use is located by a merging lane at least 15 feet
wide.  This is to insure the free flow of traffic without interference by
vehicles entering or leaving parking areas.  This is not a parking space
requirement and shall in no way affect or diminish requirement by the zoning
code or otherwise for off-street parking facilities; neither shall
fulfillment of this requirement and its acceptance by the plan commission be
deemed an approval or endorsement of any change in zoning necessary for
commercial use.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.10)



§ 152.50  ALLEYS.



   Paved rear alleys not less than 20 feet wide will be required in all
business and industrial districts of subdivisions, except where special
conditions make alleys impracticable; in such cases, adequate off-street
loading space, suitably surfaced, shall be provided.  Dead-end alleys will
not be approved for residential districts of subdivisions. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.11)



§ 152.51  HALF-STREETS.



   (A)   Whenever a subdivision is proposed to be located adjacent to
unsubdivided lands, a half-street shall be platted and constructed within the
proposed subdivision at its boundary with the unsubdivided lands.



   (B)   Whenever there is an existing half-street adjacent to a tract
proposed to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted
within the tract proposed to be subdivided so as to form a full width street
at the boundary of the two adjacent subdivisions.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.12; amend. Ord. O-18-81, passed 8-4-81)



§ 152.52  STREET GRADES.



   Unless otherwise approved by the plan commission, street grades shall
conform in general to the terrain and shall be not less than 0.35% nor more
than 5%.  Street grades shall be such as to provide natural surface drainage
of storm water regardless of the presence or absence of storm sewers.  The
intent is to avoid depressions or inverts that will flood  in flash storms,
or for which storm sewers are inadequate.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.13)



§ 152.53  CUL-DE-SACS.



   Cul-de-sacs shall normally not exceed 400 feet in length and shall have
a turnaround not less than 120 feet in diameter of the right-of-way and a
pavement diameter of 90 feet at the closed end.



§ 152.54  RIGHT-OF-WAY WIDTHS.



   The minimum right-of-way widths for streets, alleys, and crosswalkways
shall be:



   (A)   Major streets, including section line streets (except in cases
where a greater or lesser width is shown on the major street plan) - 100 feet.



   (B)    Half-section line streets - 80 feet.



   (C)   Secondary streets - 66 feet.



   (D)   Minor street for other residences -60 feet.



   (E)   Cul-de-sac - 60 feet.



   (F)   Marginal access street (without intersecting streets) - 35
feet.



   (G)   Alley - 20 feet.



   (H)   Crosswalkway - 10 feet.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.15)



§ 152.55  ROADWAY WIDTHS (OUTSIDE OF CURBS).



   (A)   Major street (except in cases where a greater width is shown)
- 36 feet.



   (B)   Secondary streets - 33 feet.



   (C)   Minor streets - 28 feet.



   (D)   Cul-de-sac - 28 feet.



   (E)   Marginal access street (without intersecting streets) - 20
feet.



   (F)   Alley (in business or industrial district) - 20 feet.



   (G)   Alley (in residential district, where permitted by exception)
- 16 feet.



   (H)   Crosswalk - 5 feet.



   (I)   Sidewalk - 5 feet. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.16)



§ 152.56  CURVATURE OF STREETS.



   The minimum curvature of streets on the center line shall be:



   (A)   Major street - 600 feet.



   (B)   Secondary street - 300 feet.



   (C)   Minor street - 100 feet.



   (D)   Cul-de-sac - 100 feet. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.17)



§ 152.57  REVERSED CURVES.



   Between reversed curves on major and secondary streets there shall be a
tangent at least 100 feet long.



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.18)



§ 152.58  INTERSECTIONS.



   Street intersections shall be at right angles, or nearly so.  Where,
because of topographic or other reasons, an intersection cannot be at right
angles, the intersection shall be so designed as to insure safety, and no
street shall intersect any other street at less than 60°. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.19)



§ 152.59  CURB RADII.



   Curb radii shall be not less than 20 feet.  ('69 Code, App. B, § 6.20)



§ 152.60  STREET SIGNS.



   The subdivider shall erect a metal sign or the equivalent at each
street intersection, indicating the names of the streets.  Each sign shall
conform to the specifications of § 94.15.  The posts shall be not less than
10 feet in length and approximately 7 feet above ground level and shall
otherwise conform to plan commission requirements. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 6.21)



§ 152.61  RESIDENTIAL ROAD STANDARDS.



   (A)   Residential roads shall be constructed with the following
minimum composition of materials or approved equal, unless otherwise approved
by the City Council:



      (1)   Ten inch sub-base granular materials;



      (2)   Two and one-half inch bituminous concrete binder course;
and



      (3)   One and one-half inch bituminous surface course.



   (B)   All materials and required testing shall conform in accordance
with the latest edition and amendments of the IDOT's "Standard Specification
for Road and Bridge Construction" and the "Procedures for Urban Soil Erosion
and Sedimentation Control in Illinois" by the Urban Committee of the
Association of Illinois Soil and Water Conservation Districts.



(Ord. O-03-06, passed 4-4-06)



BLOCKS



§ 152.70  SIZE AND SHAPE OF BLOCKS.



   The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due
regard to:



   (A)   Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special
needs of the type of use contemplated.



   (B)   Zoning requirements (if zoning applies, otherwise official
plan requirements) as to lot sizes and dimensions.



   (C)   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control, and safety
of street traffic.



   (D)   Limitations and opportunities of topography. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 7.l)



§ 152.71  BLOCK LENGTHS.



   Block lengths shall not exceed 600 feet unless a functional street
design is used, in which case they shall not exceed 1,600 feet.



('69 Code, App. B, § 7.2)



§ 152.72  CROSSWALKWAYS.



   Pedestrian crosswalkways not less than 10 feet wide shall be required
where deemed essential to provide circulation, or access to schools,
playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation, and other community
facilities. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 7.3)



§ 152.73  BLOCKS FOR INDUSTRIAL OR COMMERCIAL USE.



   Blocks intended for industrial or commercial use shall be designed
specifically for such purpose, with adequate space set aside for off-street
parking and loading, and shall meet minimum ordinance requirements for
parking.



('69 Code, App. B, § 7.4)



Cross-reference:



   Off-street parking and loading requirements of  zoning code, Ch. 153



§ 152.74  BLOCKS ON MAJOR STREETS OR RAILROADS.



   Where a subdivision borders upon or is traversed by a railroad
right-of-way or major street, the plan commission may require a street (on
one or both sides of the right-of-way or street) approximately parallel to,
and removed at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening
land, i.e., park purposes, deep residential lots with a visual barrier
established in a nonaccess reservation strip along the rear property lines,
and off-street parking, business, or other uses as permitted by the zoning
code.



('69 Code, App. B, § 7.5)



LOTS



§ 152.80  WIDTH AND AREA.



   (A)   The lot size, width, depth, shape, and orientation, and the
minimum building setback lines, shall be appropriate for the location of the
subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated.



   (B)   Resubdivision of any existing lot or lots shall be permitted
only if it is determined that none of the conditions listed in § 152.37 (B)
exist.



(Ord. O-50-71, passed 11-16-71)



§ 152.81  LOT DIMENSIONS.



   (A)   Lot dimensions and setback lines shall conform to the
requirements of the zoning code, if applicable; otherwise to the requirements
of the official plan.



   (B)   Lot dimensions may be altered through resubdivision within the
scope of § 152.37(B) only.



(Ord. O-50-71, passed 11-16-71)



Cross-reference:



   Zoning, Ch. 153



§ 152.82  MAXIMUM DEPTH.



   The maximum depth of any lot, exclusive of unusable land, shall be
3-1/2 times the width of the lot.



('69 Code, App. B, § 8.3)



§ 152.83  LOT TO ABUT ON STREET.



   Every lot shall abut on a dedicated and improved street for at least 50
feet.



('69 Code, App. B, § 8.4)



§ 152.84  PROPERTY LINES AT CORNERS.



   Property lines at street intersection corners shall be arcs having
radii of at least 10 feet or shall be chords of such arcs. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 8.5)



§ 152.85  SIDE LINES OF LOTS.



   Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial to
the street line. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 8.6)



§ 152.86  DOUBLE-FRONTAGE LOTS.



   Double-frontage lots, other than corner lots, will be permitted only
under unusual circumstances. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 8.7)



§ 152.87  GRADING FOR STORM WATER.



   (A)   Lots and blocks shall be so graded as to eliminate depressions
that would accumulate storm water.  Grades at building sites shall bear such
relationships to roadway and curb grades as to prevent flooding of basement
windows or of entryways either to basements or to first-floor levels in the
absence of basements.  Where deemed necessary, the plan commission may
require the subdivider to submit working drawings showing contours to which
the property is to be graded to provide for the requirements of this
division.  The plan commission shall transmit a copy of the approved drawing
to the director of public services.  In such cases, building permits shall
not be issued unless the plot plan indicates site and building grades
consistent with the grading drawing.



   (B)   The subdivider of a new subdivision shall submit to the plan
commission a development plan which shall provide a lot and block grading
plan.  This  plan shall satisfy the data sheet #72 specifications therefor
as set out by the Federal Housing Authority and shall also be approved by the
city engineer.



('69 Code, App. B, § 8.8)



Cross-reference:



   Flood control, Ch. 151



PUBLIC PLACES



§ 152.90  NATURAL AND CULTURAL FEATURES.



   Outstanding natural and cultural features such as scenic spots and
watercourses shall be preserved insofar as possible. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 9.1)



§ 152.91  PARKS AND OTHER PUBLIC AREAS.



   For the purpose of meeting reasonable requirements for parks,
playgrounds, school grounds, and other public grounds to serve any proposed
subdivision exceeding a gross area of 5 acres, and to facilitate the
establishment and maintenance of such public facilities conveniently located
near the lots located in the proposed subdivision, the plan commission or the
city council may require that, at the time of approval of the plat by the
city council, the subdivider will convey or dedicate for parks, playgrounds,
school grounds, or other public grounds, as shall be determined and located
by the plan commission, an amount of land in the proposed subdivision of not
more than 10% of the gross area included in the subdivision.  All land
conveyed or dedicated shall be of sufficient size and character to meet the
minimum frontage and area requirements for lots under the ordinances of the
city, and shall otherwise be suitable for the purposes intended.



('69 Code, App. B, § 9.2)



§ 152.92  EASEMENTS.



   All aboveground utilities shall be placed on rear or side property
lines.  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, an appropriate
easement shall be provided for the watercourse in either an open cut or in an
underground conduit, depending upon the density of the development.  Where
water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, gas mains, telephone lines, power
lines, or other utilities are located on or adjacent to property lines,
adequate easements together with the right of ingress or egress thereto and
therefrom shall be provided and platted. Where utility lines cross public
streets they shall be placed underground.  Easements shall be not less than
10 feet in width and shall be centered upon the center line of the utility. 
Where more than one utility is to occupy the easement, the easement shall be
of such width as to extend 5 feet on each side beyond the center line of the
outermost utilities.  Additional width shall be provided where necessary to
accommodate utility pole bracing. The plan commission may require evidence of
approval by the public utility company of easement width.  Where side lot
easements occur adjacent to a driveway, there shall be not less than 10 feet
clearance between the easement line and the extreme projection of the
building structure. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 9.3)



§ 152.93  NAMES.



   The name of the subdivision and new street names shall not duplicate,
nor too closely approximate phonetically, the name of any other subdivision
or street within or near the city.  Street names shall be subject to the
approval of the plan commission.



('69 Code, App. B, § 9.4)



IMPROVEMENTS



§ 152.100  WORKING DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS REQUIRED.



   Before considering the approval of the final plat for any subdivision,
the city council will require that complete working drawings and
specifications be submitted for those improvements requested at the time of
conditional approval of the preliminary layout.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.1)



§ 152.101  SOURCE OF DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The subdivider shall have the working drawings and
specifications for improvements prepared by a registered professional
engineer.



   (B)   All working drawings, specifications, and cost estimates shall
be checked by the city engineer or by a consulting firm duly retained by the
city.  The subdivider shall reimburse the city for checking working
drawings, specifications, and cost estimates in accordance with § 152.115.



   (C)   Working drawings and specifications shall be in strict
accordance with city standards and requirements and shall be subject to
written approval by the city engineer. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.2)



§ 152.102  PERMISSION REQUIRED.



   Approval of the city council shall be secured before the commencement
of the construction of any improvement.  Approval of the final plat by the
city council shall constitute permission to proceed with construction,
provided the plat is accepted for recording by the county recorder.  The
city council shall not have the authority under this chapter to grant
permission to any subdivider to construct any improvements prior to approval
of the final plat.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.3)



§ 152.103  OTHER PERMISSION.



   The subdivider shall also secure any permission of state and county
officials required by law, and permission extended by the city council shall
not relieve the subdivider of the responsibility to secure state and county
approval.  If permission is required, a copy of the written permission is to
be filed with the building commissioner. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.4)



§ 152.104  TYPES OF IMPROVEMENTS.



   The plan commission shall have the power to require one or more of the
following improvements depending upon the nature and scope of the
subdivision.  Particular attention shall be given to the means for
disposition of storm water and to the desirability of curb and gutter or
other provisions to prevent the breakdown of pavement edges.  The design,
layout, and carrying capacities of storm water, sanitary sewer, and water
facilities shall recognize the future requirements of adjacent undeveloped
areas.



   (A)   Street and alley grading and surfacing;



   (B)   Curb and gutter;



   (C)   Sidewalks;



   (D)   Crosswalks;



   (E)   Sanitary sewage facilities;



   (F)   Water mains and hydrants;



   (G)   Storm water drainage facilities;



   (H)   Street signs;



   (I)   Street lights;



   (J)   Driveways;



   (K)   Survey monuments;



   (L)   Topsoil where appropriate.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.5)



§ 152.105  PALOS HEIGHTS STANDARDS.



   All improvements shall be in accordance with city standards and
requirements as given in ordinances and regulations in effect at the time of
submission of the final plat.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.6)



§ 152.106  QUALIFICATION OF CONTRACTORS.



   The developer shall file with the city engineer a list of all
contractors and subcontractors who are to participate in the construction of
public improvements.  The contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to
the licensing provisions of the city ordinances and shall be subject to
disqualification by reason of faulty performance upon past construction work.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.7)



§ 152.107  INSPECTION REQUIRED.



   All improvements shall be subject to inspection by duly authorized and
qualified city inspectors, both during the course of construction and after
construction is complete.  The inspector shall have authority over the
materials of construction, the methods of construction, and the workmanship,
to ensure compliance with the working drawings and specifications.  The
contractor shall provide for reasonable tests and proof of the quality of
materials as requested by the inspector.  Upon due cause the inspector may
require that work be suspended; and due cause shall include weather
conditions, questionable materials of construction, methods of construction,
workmanship, or nonadherence to specifications and drawings.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.8)



§ 152.108  INSPECTION REPORTS.



   The inspector shall prepare and submit to the city engineer each day a
report stating the progress of the work, and giving his findings as to the
quality and quantity of materials used, and the quality of methods and
workmanship.  He shall in particular call attention to any circumstances
that entail departures from the working drawings and specifications, such as
unforeseen difficulties of drainage, ground  water, poor subsoil, unstable
fill material, unconventional or faulty practices of the contractors, or
other circumstances. Whenever, in his opinion, the departures are likely to
cause either a lower ultimate standard of performance, or a higher
maintenance cost, than could reasonably be anticipated, he shall immediately
notify the city engineer.  When an improvement has been completed, he shall
prepare a summary report.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.9)



§ 152.109  SUBDIVIDER RESPONSIBLE.



   Approval by the inspector, or the absence of inspection, shall in no
way relieve the subdivider of full responsibility for adherence by his
contractors to specifications and working drawings or for high standards of
materials, methods, and workmanship.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.10)



§ 152.110  APPROVAL NOT ACCEPTANCE.



   Approval by the inspector shall not be deemed acceptance of the
improvement by the city. Acceptance shall be only by the action of city
council, and acceptance shall be contingent upon a favorable inspection
report signed by the city engineer. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.11)



§ 152.111  NOTIFICATION.



   It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider or his contractor to
notify the city engineer when work is to be started and to request assignment
of an inspector.  The initial notification that a particular improvement is
to be started shall be in writing and shall reach the city engineer in
advance of the date that inspection is to begin.  The notice shall be
accompanied by an inspection bond in accordance with § 152.115.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.12)



§ 152.112  GUARANTEE OF COMPLETION.



   The plan commission shall not consider approval of the final plat
unless and until the subdivider has guaranteed the completion of all required
improvements within a reasonable period and in compliance with working
drawings and specifications.  This guarantee shall be by one, or a
combination of 2 or more, of 3 methods.



   (A)   The subdivider may post a performance bond prepared in a form
approved by the city attorney, and underwritten by a surety company listed as
approved by the city council.  The amount of the bond shall be not less than
125% of the final estimate of the cost of the improvement as estimated by the
city engineer.  There shall be no reduction in the amount of that portion of
the bond applying to a particular improvement unless and until that
improvement is complete and accepted or approved by the city council. From
the standpoint of acceptance, the subgrade, base course, and surface course
of a street, alley, or parking area shall be considered as a single
improvement.



   (B)   The subdivider may deposit a cash bond with the city in
accordance with a specific escrow agreement approved by the city attorney and
the city engineer and in an amount not less than 125% of the final estimate
of the cost of the improvements as estimated by the city engineer.  The
deposit shall be held in a special account by the city, and the agreement may
provide for partial payouts, as work progresses, in amounts approved by the
city engineer as corresponding to the original estimate of unit costs. 
Partial payouts shall be contingent upon favorable inspection reports, and
the sum of the partial payouts for a single improvement shall not exceed 90%
of the original deposit for the improvement, until and unless the improvement
is complete and accepted or approved by the city council. From the standpoint
of acceptance, the subgrade, base course, and surface course of a street,
alley, or parking area shall be considered a single improvement.



   (C)   Upon specific permission of the city council, as recommended
by the plan commission, the subdivider may elect to complete one or more
improvements prior to approval of the final plat.  Where the subdivider
elects to guarantee completion of an improvement by this method, approval of
the final plat shall be contingent upon certification by the city engineer
that the improvement has been completed in accordance with drawings and
specifications, and that the inspection reports are favorable. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.13)



§ 152.113  MAINTENANCE BOND.



   The subdivider shall furnish the city a maintenance bond in the amount
of 15% of the final contract price to insure the maintenance of the
improvements furnished by the subdivider.  The bond shall be valid for a
period of 15 months commencing with the date of acceptance of the improvement
by the city, and shall be in a form, and underwritten by a surety company,
approved by the city attorney and the city council.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.14)



§ 152.114  ACCEPTANCE.



   Acceptance of an improvement for the city shall be only by resolution
of the city council upon the recommendation of the city engineer. 
Recommendation shall be contingent upon:



   (A)   Fulfillment of the requirements of § 152.113.



   (B)   An opinion by the city attorney that satisfactory and proper
conveyances and dedications have been made by the subdivider to the city.



   (C)   Improvements being complete and in good repair in accordance
with city standards and requirements.



   (D)   Inspection reports indicating compliance with working drawings
and specifications.



   (E)   A single improvement shall not be accepted in part; it shall
be complete throughout the subdivision as indicated in the final plat and
working drawings.  The subgrade, base course, and surface course of a
street, alley, or parking area shall be considered as a single improvement.



   (F)   Acceptance of an improvement shall constitute release of the
applicable portion of the performance bond or of the applicable portion of
the balance of the cash deposit covering construction of improvements.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.15)



§ 152.115  FEES, BONDS.



   To defray the engineering and inspection expenses incurred by the city
in checking preliminary and final cost estimates, working drawings,
specifications, and the final plat, and in executing inspection
responsibilities, the subdivider shall be required to reimburse the city as
follows.  These are separate and distinct charges from the fee paid at the
time of submission of the preliminary layout.



   (A)   The subdivider shall apply in writing to the city engineer,
making a request that the working drawings, specifications, and estimates for
improvements be checked.  The application shall be accompanied by 2 sets of
construction prints, specifications, and estimates.  The city engineer shall
inform the subdivider of the amount of the charge for this service, and the
charge shall be based upon practices recommended by the Schedule of
Recommended Fees for Engineering Services, published by the Illinois Society
of Professional Engineers.  Checking shall proceed after the subdivider has
paid over this fee to the city clerk.  Additional fees shall be paid for the
rechecking of drawings, specifications, and estimates, arising from revisions
made by or required of the subdivider.  There shall be no refund of
engineering fees if the project is abandoned for any reason whatsoever.



   (B)   The engineering fee is intended to include the preparation or
checking of preliminary and final cost estimates, working drawings,
specifications, and staking, but is not intended to include inspection.



   (C)   Before the grading or construction of improvements is started,
the subdivider or his contractor shall post with the city clerk a cash
inspection bond in an amount agreed upon between the city engineer and the
subdivider or contractor as being sufficient to provide for inspection
charges at the current per diem rates.  Any excess of the bond over total
inspection charges will be refunded to the depositor, and any overdraft on
the bond shall be provided for immediately by the contractor, to ensure
continuity of inspection.  Payments to the city engineer for inspection
services shall be made monthly in accordance with progress of the work.



   (D)   It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider or contractor
to notify the city engineer in advance as to the dates that construction work
will commence and complete for purposes of determining the number  of days
of the inspection charge.  In the event of a dispute, only notification in
writing shall be considered as proof of notice.



   (E)   Per diem inspection rates shall be equal to 100% of the
engineer's quoted charge to the city.  If the inspection is performed by an
inspector on the city payroll, the charge shall be 135% of the regular salary
paid to the inspector, computed on an hourly basis.  There shall be not less
than a 4-hour charge for time spent in any one day.  For time spent outside
of the regular working hours of the inspector, the hourly charge shall be
250% of the regular salary paid to the inspector, computed on an hourly basis.



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.16)



§ 152.116  PROTECTION AND REPAIR OF EXISTING IMPROVEMENTS.



   The subdivider or his contractors and suppliers shall be responsible
that existing improvements and the property of the city are not damaged, or
rendered less useful, or unsightly, by the operations of the subdivider or
his contractors and suppliers. This provision is intended to include damage
or nuisance with respect to the land, improvements, or landscaping of the
city; damage to existing streets, sidewalks, curbs, and gutters, or parkways,
by passage thereover of equipment or trucks, or by excavation, for any
purpose; the spillage or tracking of earth, sand, rock, or other material
onto existing streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, or parkways; the washing
by storm water of earth or sand onto streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters or
parkways or into catchbasins; damage to water mains, sanitary sewers,
culverts, or storm sewers. To reduce or localize the possibility of damage to
streets by heavy trucking, the city engineer shall instruct the subdivider as
to the streets to be used for access to the subdivision by equipment and
trucks, and the subdivider shall be responsible for enforcement of this
instruction upon his contractors and their suppliers.  The subdivider shall
make provisions to prevent washing of earth or sand onto sidewalks, streets,
or curbs and gutters, and into catchbasins by storm water.  Where deemed
advisable, the city engineer shall have the power to require, either prior to
the commencement of construction or after construction is in process, that
the subdivider post a surety to guarantee the repair of damages or abatement
of nuisance. Where the need for surety becomes apparent after the
construction is in process, the city engineer shall have the power to order
the construction discontinued until a surety has been posted.  Expenses
incurred by the city in repairing damages, and cleaning streets, catchbasins,
and sewers, shall be deducted from the surety. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.17)



§ 152.117  OTHER REGULATIONS PREVAIL.



   None of the provisions of this chapter pertaining to permission,
surety, fees, acceptance, and approval shall be construed as exempting
subdividers, general contractors, or any other contractors or craftsmen from
any other ordinance or regulation of the city, county, or state, with respect
to licenses, fees, surety, inspection, or other control. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 10.18)



DOCUMENTS



§ 152.120  PRELIMINARY LAYOUT.



   The preliminary layout tracings shall be submitted rolled in a mailing
tube, and prints shall be submitted folded to 9 inches by 12 inches.  The
drawing shall be to a scale of not smaller than one inch to 100 feet.  The
preliminary layout shall contain the following information:



   (A)   Name of the subdivision.



   (B)   Legal description of the location.



   (C)   Scale of the layout or plat.



   (D)   Date of preparation.



   (E)   Statement of whether the North point is true or magnetic and
whether bearings shown on the plat are true or magnetic.



   (F)   Boundary lines of the subdivision with length and bearing of
lines.



   (G)   Relationship of the subdivision to section and half-section
lines and to any adjacent city boundary lines, and the distances and bearings
to nearest official monuments.



   (H)   The location, widths, and names of streets or other public
ways, easements, or railroad and utility rights-of-way, both within the
subdivision and adjacent to or leading into the subdivision.



   (I)   Existing and proposed center line profile of each street and
alley.



   (J)   Typical cross-sections of the streets together with an
indication of the direction of the proposed storm water runoff from streets,
lots, and blocks.



   (K)   Proposed methods of providing for storm water, sanitary
sewage, and water.



   (L)   Location of the land intended to be dedicated to the public
use or reserved in the deeds for the use of all property owners in the
subdivision.



   (M)   Numbers and dimensions of lots and blocks.



   (N)   Minimum front and side setback lines.



   (O)   Location of watercourses and other important features. 
Indicate flood levels of watercourses.



   (P)   A layout, including necessary easement areas, of an adequate
system of street lighting for public streets.



   (Q)   Contours, with intervals of 2 feet or less, referred to the
City of Chicago, Illinois datum.



   (R)   Name and address of the owner and subdivider, and the name of
the designer of the preliminary layout.



   (S)   The names of subdivisions immediately adjacent and the names
of the owners of record of adjacent unsubdivided tracts.



   (T)   An outline of the proposed protective covenants.



   (U)   Existing permanent buildings or structures within or adjacent
to the tract.



   (V)   Where the preliminary layout covers only a part of the
subdivider's entire holding, a sketch of the prospective street system of the
unsubmitted part shall be furnished; and the street system of the submitted
part will be considered in the light of adjustments and connections with the
street system of the part not submitted.



   (W)   If the informal consideration indicates that the subdivision
is a portion of a unit area for development on the official plan, the
preliminary layout shall include a small scale study of the unit area.



('69 Code, App. B, § 11.1)



§ 152.121  FINAL PLAT.



   The final plat shall conform to the dimensions for all lines, angles,
and curvatures, with functions used to describe all boundaries, including the
perimeter survey of tracts, streets, alleys, easements, areas to be reserved
for public use, and other important features.  Error of the closure of
boundary-line surveys shall not exceed one in 10,000 (one foot for each
10,000 feet of perimeter survey).  Angular error shall not exceed plus or
minus 20 seconds.  Lot lines are to show dimensions in feet and hundredths,
and when an angle occurs in any lot line between lot corners, the measurement
of the angle shall be shown in degrees, minutes, and seconds.  The area of
each lot is to be shown individually in square feet.



   (B)   An identification system for all lots and blocks.



   (C)   True angles and distances to the nearest established street
lines and official monuments (not less than 3), which shall be accurately
described in the plat by location, size, and elevation.



   (D)   Municipal, township, county, or section lines accurately tied
to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles.



   (E)   Accurate location of all monuments, which shall be placed at
all block corners and angle points, and at intermediate points as shall be
required by the city.  The monuments shall be of a permanent character, as
determined by the city engineer, and installed in such a manner that they may
be found by a licensed surveyor.  All U.S.G.S., state, county, city, or
other official benchmarks, monuments, or triangulation stations in or
adjacent to the property shall be preserved in a precise position.



   (F)   Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be
dedicated or reserved for public use, or for the exclusive use of property
owners within the subdivision, with the purposes indicated thereon.



   (G)   Protective covenants shall be lettered on the final plat or
appropriately referenced thereon.



('69 Code, App. B, § 11.2)



§ 152.122  CERTIFICATIONS AND APPROVALS.



   The final plat shall contain the following certifications, in the forms
suggested in §§ 152.130 through 152.134.



   (A)   Certification by a registered land surveyor to the effect that
the plat represents a survey made by him, that the monuments shown thereon
actually exist as located, and that all dimensional and other details, such
as curve data, are correct.



   (B)   Notarized certification by the owner or owners of the land, or
other persons having an interest therein (including mortgagees), of the
adoption of the plat and the dedication of streets and other public areas.



   (C)   Certification by the signature of the proper officials of Cook
County that there are no tax delinquencies.



   (D)   Certification by the signature of the city treasurer that
there are no special assessment delinquencies or other liens.



   (E)   Space for the approval of the plan commission by date and the
signature of the chairman of the commission.



   (F)   Space for the approval of the city council by date and the
signature of the mayor; and space for the signature of the city clerk, and
for the city seal.



('69 Code, App. B, § 11.3)



§ 152.123  ATTENDANT ITEMS.



   The final plat shall be accompanied by documents including the
following:



   (A)   A letter to the city council, signed by the city engineer,
indicating that the plat has been checked, that all working drawings and
specifications for improvements have been prepared in conformance with city
standards and requirements, and that the engineering fees have been paid.



   (B)   A letter to the city council, signed by the city attorney,
stating that satisfactory provisions have been made for the guarantee of
performance for the construction of the required improvements, and for
payment of legal fees in the matter of the city attorney, engineering fees
for the city engineer, and any other professional fees or costs that the city
may incur as a result of the subdivision.  On items where construction has
already been completed, there shall be a statement by the city engineer that
construction has been completed and inspected and found to be in accordance
with city standards and requirements, and that a surety has been posted to
provide for maintenance.



   (C)   Two copies of working drawings and specifications for
improvements.



   (D)   Two copies of restrictions to be incorporated into the deeds
or covenants to be recorded with the plat to be approved by the city
attorney. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 11.4; amend. Ord. 36-86, passed 9-16-86)



§ 152.124  AGREEMENTS.



   The final plat shall be accompanied by a statement signed by the owner
or subdivider setting forth:



   (A)   That the plans and specifications for the required public
improvements have been completed and approved by the city engineer;



   (B)   That the required public improvements will be installed in
accordance with such plans and specifications; and



   (C)   That in respect to subdivisions wholly or partly within the
city limits, the bonds or guarantees provided for by §§ 152.112, 152.113,
152.115, and 152.116 have been furnished to the city.



('69 Code, App. B, § 11.5)



§ 152.125  AS-BUILT DRAWINGS.



   Prior to or at the time of the acceptance of any improvement by the
city council, the subdivider shall furnish the city engineer with 2 copies of
drawings showing the location and actual construction of the improvements.




('69 Code, App. B, § 11.6)

APPEALS



§ 152.140  PROCEDURE FOR APPEAL.



   Any party aggrieved by a decision of the plan commission may, within 15
days thereafter, appeal therefrom to the city council, and he shall file with
the commission a written notice of appeal, specifying the decision from
which  the appeal is taken. 



('69 Code, App. B, § 13.1)



§ 152.141  PROCEEDINGS.



   Upon receiving the notice of appeal, the plan commission shall transmit
to the city council a certified copy of the minutes in the case upon which
the appeal is taken.



('69 Code, App. B, § 13.2)



PRIVATE RESTRICTIONS



§ 152.150  CHAPTER NOT TO IMPAIR.



   It is not intended by this chapter to abrogate, impair, or interfere
with private restrictions placed upon property by deed, covenant, or other
private agreement, or with restrictive covenants running with the land. Where
the provisions of this chapter impose a greater restriction upon land than is
imposed or required by existing provisions of law, ordinance, contract, or
deed, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 



('69 Code, App. B, Article XVII)



§ 152.999  PENALTY.



   Anyone violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, forfeit to the city not less than $10 nor more $200 for each
violation, plus the costs of the action, and each day that the violation
continues shall be deemed to be a separate offense.
