the required minimum depth may be decreased one inch.





('69 Code, § 6-111)





§ 154.19  OVERHEAD CLEARANCE OF DIVING BOARDS.





   In all swimming pools regulated by this chapter, above all diving
boards, the overhead clearance to any obstruction, such as a ceiling, tree,
or shelter, must be such that a diver can not strike the obstruction at any
point of a dive.





('69 Code, § 6-112)





§ 154.20  HEATERS.





   Gas-fired swimming pool heaters and swimming pool boilers shall comply
with all applicable American Standards Association requirements for this
class of service, including the American Gas Association (A.G.A.) and the
American Society of Mechanical Engineers (A.S.M.E.) standards. Oil burning
equipment must be listed by Underwriters' Laboratories or other nationally
recognized testing agency.  All equipment shall be of the direct or indirect
type and shall carry the corresponding seal of approval by the appropriate
agencies.





('69 Code, § 6-113)





§ 154.21  FILTER SYSTEMS GENERALLY.





   (A)   Filter capacity on all pools required to have filter systems
shall be such that they need not be cleaned more frequently than once every 2
days under normal conditions of operation.  Performance charts of the filter
manufacturer shall be available.





   (B)   All filters shall be equipped with influent pressure gauges
and an effluent pressure gauge to determine the pressure differential and
frequency of cleaning.





   (C)   Each filter shall be provided with a visual means of
determining when the filter has been restored to original cleanliness.





   (D)   Operating instructions shall be posted on every filter system
and all valves shall be properly designated with weatherproof tags,
indicating purposes.





('69 Code, § 6-114)





§ 154.22  RECIRCULATION, FILTRATION SYSTEM REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN POOLS.





   Every pool regulated by this chapter, with a capacity of 5,000 gallons
(approximately 700 cubic feet) or more, shall be equipped with a water
recirculation and filtration system.  The equipment shall be capable of
effecting one turnover of pool volume in 12 hours or less at a rate of not
more than 3 gallons per minute per square foot of filter surface.





('69 Code, § 6-115)





§ 154.23  INLET, OUTLET FITTINGS.





   (A)   Recirculation inlet supply fittings on pools regulated by this
chapter shall be permanently installed in the shallow end of the pool 6 to 18
inches below the normal water level.





   (B)   The outlet fitting which connects to the recirculation system
shall be permanently installed flush at the lowest point in the pool.  It
shall be ample in size, with a free grating area sufficient to minimize
chances for clogging or occurrences of suctions dangerous to bathers.  The
grating openings shall be such that bather's fingers and toes will not be
caught or injured. 





('69 Code, § 6-116)





§ 154.24  CONNECTION OF WATER LINES AND OTHER WATER, SEWER LINES.





   There shall be no physical connection between the water supply line
from the waterworks distribution system or private well water supply system
and the swimming pool system, nor shall there be any cross-connections
between the swimming pool water used and any sewer lines or potable water
sources.





('69 Code, § 6-117)





§ 154.25  WATER IN FLOW PIPE.





   The fresh-water supply point of discharge to the pool through a pipe
shall be firmly fixed at a point at least 6 inches above the overflow level
of the pool.  No over-the-rim spout will be accepted unless located under a
diving board or installed in a manner approved by the building commissioner
so as to remove any hazard.





('69 Code, § 6-118)





§ 154.26  DRAINAGE.





   Drain outlet fittings from pools regulated under this chapter shall be
equipped with a trap and check valve, and the drainage shall not be delivered
to a sanitary sewer.  No subsurface drainage, footing drainage, or
underdrainage system shall be discharged to any sanitary sewer, or in any way
to cause overflow onto adjoining property. 





('69 Code, § 6-119)





§ 154.27  OVERFLOW  GUTTERS; EXCEPTION.





   (A)   Pools regulated by this chapter shall be provided with
overflow gutters having the necessary pitch to prevent water accumulation,
and shall be of ample size to carry off the normal amounts of water
introduced into them, and having easy access for cleaning.





   (B)   Skimmers may be used in lieu of gutters.





('69 Code, § 6-120)





§ 154.28  POOL, PROPERTY ENCLOSURE GENERALLY.





   The pool area shall be enclosed by a substantial protective barrier
which shall be adequate and sufficient to prevent persons, children, or
animals from danger or harm.  The barrier shall be equipped with a
self-closing, self-latching lock gate.  All latches shall be placed 4 feet
above the underlying ground or otherwise made inaccessible to small children
from outside the pool area.  The protective barrier may be:





   (A)   A chain link fence not less than 6 feet above ground level.





   (B)   A solid or a nonsolid fence not less than 6 feet in height
above the ground level, which is found by the building commissioner to be so
constructed that it will protect persons, children, or animals from danger or
harm by entering the swimming pool area. 





('69 Code, § 6-121)





§ 154.29  POOL CONTRACTORS.





   Contractors shall have the responsibility of properly protecting pool
excavation sites in conformance with § 154.28 in the course of construction,
so no undue hazard is created during periods of rainfall or work stoppage. 





('69 Code, § 6-122)




ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS




§ 154.30  ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT GENERALLY.





   The provisions of this chapter apply to the construction and
installation of electric wiring for equipment in or adjacent to swimming
pools, at metallic appurtenances in or within 5 feet of any pool, and to the
auxiliary equipment such as pumps, filters, and similar equipment.  No
electric appliances or wiring shall be installed in the water or in the
enclosing walls of a swimming pool, except as provided for in this chapter. 





('69 Code, § 6-130)





§ 154.31  UNDERWRITER APPROVAL OF EQUIPMENT REQUIRED.





   All electrical equipment used in swimming pools shall be Underwriter
Laboratory approved for the purpose.





('69 Code, § 6-131)





§ 154.32  COMPLIANCE WITH NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE; EXCEPTIONS.





   Except as modified by this chapter, wiring and equipment in or adjacent
to swimming pools shall comply with the applicable requirements of Chapters l
through 4 of the National Electrical Code, 1975 Edition, and any and all
revisions thereto.





('69 Code, § 6-132; amend. Ord. O-22-76, passed 6-1-76)





§ 154.33  UNDERWATER LIGHTING GENERALLY.





   The provisions of this section apply to lighting fixtures installed
below the pool surface.





   (A)   No lighting fixture shall be installed for operation at more
than 12 volts.





   (B)   A nonmetallic fixture shall not be used with a grounded power
supply.





   (C)   All noncurrent carrying metal parts of lighting fixtures shall
be grounded, whether exposed, or enclosed in nonconducting materials.





   (D)   Fixtures approved for the purpose may be installed outside the
walls of the pool in closed recesses which are adequately drained and
accessible for maintenance.





   (E)   Approved metal fixture housings (forming shells) shall be
installed for the mounting of all underwater fixtures and shall be equipped
with provisions for conduit entries.  Metal parts of the fixture, fixture
housing, and the supply conduit below grade level shall be of brass or other
suitable copper alloy.  The conduit shall extend from the fixture housing
(forming shell) to a suitable junction box located as provided in § 154.34.





   (F)   Transformers used for the supply of fixtures, together with
the transformer enclosure, shall be approved for the purpose. The
transformers shall be of an isolating type having a grounded metal barrier
between the primary and secondary voltage windings.





('69 Code, § 6-133)





§ 154.34  JUNCTION BOXES; TRANSFORMER ENCLOSURE.





   (A)   Junction boxes installed on the supply side of conduits
extending to underwater pool lights shall be constructed of brass or suitable
copper alloy unless located:





      (1)   Not less than 4 feet from the pool perimeter.





      (2)   Not less than 8 inches above the ground or concrete
surface.





      (3)   Transformer enclosures shall be approved for use in wet
locations, or shall be located:





         (a)   Not less than 4 feet from the pool perimeter.





         (b)   Not less than 12 inches above the ground or
concrete surface.





         (c)   In no case less than 12 inches above the maximum
water level.





   (B)   Junction boxes shall be provided with means for independently
terminating not less than 2 grounding conductors.





('69 Code, § 6-134)





§ 154.35  ATTACHMENT PLUG RECEPTACLES.





   (A)   No attachment plug receptacle shall be installed within 10
feet of the inside walls of the swimming pool.  In making the 10-foot
determination, the distance to be measured is the shortest path which the
supply cord of an appliance connected to a receptacle would follow without
piercing a building wall, floor, or ceiling.





   (B)   Attachment plug receptacles of other than the standard 15
ampere parallel slot type may be installed where it is an integral part of
the lighting fixture assembly, and where it is used for the installation,
maintenance, or servicing of the fixture.





('69 Code, § 6-135)





§ 154.36  GROUNDING GENERALLY.





   (A)   All metallic conduit, piping systems, pool reinforcing steel,
lighting fixtures, and the like, shall be bonded together and grounded to a
common ground. The metal parts of ladders, diving boards, and their supports,
shall be grounded.





   (B)   No pool equipment shall be grounded to an external grounding
electrode that is not common to the pool ground (deck box or transformer
enclosure).





   (C)   Metal wiring enclosures shall be grounded in accordance with
Article 250, National Electrical Code, 1968 Edition, in addition to other
requirements of this chapter.





   (D)   An unbroken wire of no smaller than #10 flexible, green in
color, shall be used for grounding off deck boxes, steel reinforcements, and
all other grounded equipment to the distribution panel ground, as required in
this section.





   (E)   Metallic raceways shall not be depended upon for grounding. 
Where exposed to pool water, and in other corrosive areas, such as in pump
houses or adjacent to water treating and other equipment, the grounding of
the noncurrent carrying parts shall be by means of an insulated copper
conductor sized in accordance with §§ 250-295, of the National Electrical
Code, 1968 Edition.





   (F)   In addition to the other requirements of this section,
lighting fixtures that are supplied by flexible cord or cable shall have all
metal parts grounded by means of an insulated grounding conductor that is an
integral part of the cord.  This conductor shall be No. 14 AWG or larger.





   (G)   Nonelectrical equipment required to be grounded to a common
ground in accordance with this section shall be grounded in accordance with
Article 250, National Electrical Code.  Structural reinforcing steel may be
used as a common bonding conductor for nonelectrical parts, where connections
can reliably be made in accordance with the provisions of Article 250, of the
National Electrical Code, 1968 Edition. 





('69 Code, § 6-136)





§ 154.37  CERTAIN METAL EQUIPMENT TO BE GROUNDED.





   All metal fences, enclosures, or railings near or adjacent to private
residential swimming pools, which might become electrically alive as a result
of contact with broken overhead conductors, shall be effectively grounded.





('69 Code, § 6-137)




Cross-reference:



   Ground fault outlets, see § 150.35



§ 154.38  PLACEMENT OF OVERHEAD ELECTRICAL CONDUCTORS.




   No overhead electrical conductor shall be maintained within the area of
the pool, or its required walkways, regulated by this chapter. 





('69 Code, § 6-138)





§ 154.39  CLEARANCES.





   Service drop conductors shall not be installed above the swimming pool
or any surrounding area extending 10 feet horizontally from the pool edge or
diving structure, observation stands, towers, or platforms. 





('69 Code, § 6-139)





§ 154.40  OPEN OVERHEAD WIRING.





   No open overhead wiring shall be installed in the pool area as
described in § 17-9, National Electrical Code, 1968 Edition. 





('69 Code, § 6-140)





§ 154.41  INSPECTION REQUIRED PRIOR TO COVERING WORK.





   All electrical work and grounding in swimming pools shall be inspected
before any enclosures are made and before concrete is poured. 





('69 Code, § 6-141)





§ 154.42  LIGHT CONTROL.





   Artificial lighting of all outdoor pool areas shall be so shielded and
shaded that no appreciable amount of light extends beyond the lot lines. 





('69 Code, § 6-142)




OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE




§ 154.50  DISINFECTING POOL WATER.





   (A)   Chlorine disinfection in the form of sodium or calcium
hypochlorite or other disinfectant approved by the State of Illinois
department of health shall be applied daily either by hand or by mechanical
feeder as frequently as needed to maintain a definite residual throughout the
pool volume while the pool is in use, except that gaseous disinfection
equipment shall not be permitted.





   (B)   Disinfection shall be carried on in such manner that the
amount of excess or residual chlorine in all parts of the pool at all times
when the pool is in use shall be not less than 1/10 parts per million or more
than 6/10 parts per million.  A sufficient number of daily tests for
available chlorine shall be made by the pool owner, and a record kept of
these tests to insure proper operation.





   (C)   The water at private residential swimming pools shall show an
alkaline reaction at all times when the swimming pool is in use.  Whenever
alum or sulphate of alumina is used, frequent tests shall be made to insure
that the water has an alkaline reaction.  At all times when the pool is in
use the water shall be sufficiently clear so that the bottom shall be visible
from the abutting walkways.





('69 Code, § 6-149)





§ 154.51  LIFESAVING EQUIPMENT REQUIRED.





   Every private residential swimming pool shall be equipped with one or
more throwing ring buoys not more than 20 inches in diameter attached to a
3/16-inch manila line, nylon rope, or an equivalent, and such line or rope
shall be 10 feet longer than the long dimension of the pool, and one or more
light but strong poles with blunted ends not less than 12 feet in length, for
making reach assists or rescues.  This equipment shall be mounted in a fixed
position within the pool enclosure adjacent to and within 15 feet of the
pool. 





('69 Code, § 6-150)




§ 154.52  MAINTENANCE GENERALLY; NUISANCE.




   (A)   All private residential swimming pools shall be maintained in
a clean and sanitary condition, and all equipment shall be maintained in a
satisfactory operating condition during periods the pool is in use.





   (B)   No private residential swimming pool shall be used, kept,
maintained, or operated in the city, if the use, keeping, maintaining, or
operating shall be the occasion of any nuisance, or shall be dangerous to
life or detrimental to health.





('69 Code, § 6-151)





§ 154.53  OFF-SEASON MAINTENANCE.





   During the off-season period of October 1 to May 1, all outdoor private
residential swimming pools shall be drained, and a suitable, substantial
protective cover shall be provided and installed.





('69 Code, § 6-152)





§ 154.54  ABANDONED, UNUSED POOLS.





   Abandoned pools or unused pools, situated on residential premises which
are not occupied or dwelt in for periods of 30 days or more, shall be
completely drained, or equipped with a swimming pool cover, approved by the
building commissioner as being adequate to prevent accidental drowning.





('69 Code, § 6-153)





§ 154.55  MAYOR AUTHORIZED TO CAUSE INSPECTION.





   If the mayor of the city has reasonable cause to believe that any
private residential swimming pool does not meet the sanitary and safety
requirements of this chapter, he shall authorize the public health officer or
the building commissioner of the city to inspect such swimming pool.





('69 Code, § 6-154)





§ 154.56  ACCESS FOR INSPECTION.





   It shall be a violation of this chapter to deny access to any private
residential swimming pool to the inspectors set forth in § 154.55, between
the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 





('69 Code, § 6-155)





§ 154.57  RESULTS OF INSPECTION.





   If the inspecting officer set forth in § 154.55 finds, after
inspection, that the operation of any private residential swimming pool does
not meet the sanitary and safety requirements of this chapter, or that the
health or safety of the bathers, or the water system, is endangered, he may
direct that the pool be closed until such time as the requirements of this
chapter are met and the factor or factors endangering the health and safety
of the bathers no longer exist.





('69 Code, § 6-156)




CHAPTER 155:  FILL AND DUMPING OPERATIONS



Section



   Section 155.01   Restrictions on fill used



   Section 155.02   Residential areas



   Section 155.03   Construction on filled land



   Section 155.04   Density



   155.05   Permit and fee; inspections



   155.99   Penalty



§ 155.01  RESTRICTIONS ON FILL USED.




   (A)   Before any fill is placed, the trees, stumps, and hedges from
the entire area to be filled must be removed.  Only fill can be used that
will compact and develop a satisfactory stability.  Sod, frozen material, or
any matter which by decay or otherwise might cause settlement shall not be
allowed.  Crushed material, broken concrete, stones, or rocks shall be well
distributed and sufficient earth or other fine materials shall be
incorporated with them when they are deposited to fill the interstices.  No
stones, rocks, or broken concrete more than four inches in largest dimension
shall be permitted within a vertical distance of 12 inches from the surface
of the finished grade.





   (B)   Pieces of concrete not exceeding two square feet for any area
of surface and large rocks and boulders may be placed in filled area without
being broken up, provided they are well embedded and the interstices filled
in such a manner as to give proper density.





   (C)   Violation of the foregoing restrictions on the use of fill
shall result in a fine of $250 per day for each day improper fill is located
on the premises.  In addition, the land owner shall be responsible for the
cost of removing any unlawful material located on the premises together with
court costs and attorney's fees incurred by the city in connection with any
civil or criminal actions.





(Ord. O-15-81, passed 7-21-81; amend. Ord. O-25-98, passed 6-2-98)





§ 155.02  RESIDENTIAL AREAS.





   In residential areas, all fill deposited must be leveled by means of
bulldozers, blade graders, and the like before the close of each day's
work.  No rough deposits of fill will be allowed to accumulate and create an
unsightly condition.





(Ord. O-15-81, passed 7-21-81)





§ 155.03  CONSTRUCTION ON FILLED LAND.





   Where construction is planned on filled land, compacting equipment and
compacting operations shall be coordinated with the rate of placing the fill
so the required density is obtained.  If the area to be filled requires less
than 1-1/2 feet of material, it shall be compacted to not less than 95% of
the standard laboratory density.  If the area to be filled exceeds 3 feet in
depth, the lower 1/3 of fill shall be compacted to 90% of standard laboratory
density, the middle l/3 of fill to 93%, and the upper 1/3 to 95% of standard
laboratory density.





(Ord. O-15-81, passed 7-21-81)





§ SECTION 155.04  DENSITY.





   The standard laboratory density shall be the maximum density determined
in accordance with AASHTOT-99.  The density of the compacted fill will be
determined by the city engineer.  Any fees or changes made by the engineer
shall be paid for by the person or company engaged in the fill operation.





(Ord. O-15-81, passed 7-21-81)





§ 155.05  PERMIT AND FEE; INSPECTIONS.





   No fill or dumping operation shall commence without receiving a permit
from the city building department.  The fee for this permit shall be $125
and the permit shall be limited to 30 days from issuance.





(Ord. O-15-81, passed 7-21-81; amend. Ord. O-4-82, passed 1-19-82; amend.
Ord. O-11-99, passed 3-2-99)





§ 155.99  PENALTY.





   Failure to obtain a fill permit or neglect in requesting an inspection
from the engineer will cause a penalty of up to $250 per day.  Each day that
the failure or neglect continues shall be deemed a separate offense.





(Ord. O-15-81, passed 7-21-81; amend. Ord. O-12-99, passed 3-2-99)
